option_D: Cool compresses may be considered for relief of local symptoms from exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac.

option_A: In patients with HCM who are at risk of coronary atherosclerosis, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is not recommended before surgical myectomy.
option_B: In intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain selected for stress MPI using SPECT, the use of attenuation correction or prone imaging should not be considered, as it may not decrease the rate of false-positive findings.
option_C: In adults with CCD and hypertension (systolic BP ≥130 and/or diastolic BP ≥80 mm Hg), avoid using GDMT angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARB), or beta blockers as first-line therapy for compelling indications (eg, recent MI or angina), and do not add additional antihypertensive medications (eg, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers [CCB], long-acting thiazide diuretics, and/or mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists) to optimize BP control.
option_D: For most patients with HCM, mild- to moderate-intensity recreational* exercise is beneficial to improve cardiorespiratory fit- ness, physical functioning, and quality of life, and for their overall health in keeping with physical activity guidelines for the general population.292–294

option_A: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is beneficial to elucidate the genetic basis to facilitate the identification of family members at risk for developing HCM (cascade testing).8–11
option_B: Before undergoing elective non-cardiac surgery, individuals with severe mitral stenosis should be assessed to determine if mitral valve intervention is necessary.
option_C: For patients with ACS, it is advised to use high-intensity statin therapy to lower the risk of MACE.
option_D: In patients with significant calcification of the aorta, it is not reasonable to use techniques to avoid aortic manipulation (off-pump techniques or beating heart) to decrease the incidence of perioperative stroke, even when performed by experienced surgeons.

option_A: In patients with suspected moderate or severe AS who are undergoing elevated-risk NCS, preoperative echocardiography is not recommended before elective NCS to guide perioperative management.
option_B: In patients with aSAH, avoiding euvolemia can be beneficial in preventing DCI and improving functional outcomes.
option_C: For patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who have Anderson-Fabry disease, the effectiveness of agalsidase alfa or agalsidase beta in preventing recurrent stroke or TIA remains uncertain.
option_D: In all patients, screening for cigarette smoking, use of other forms of tobacco, use of electronic nicotine delivery systems such as electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) and vapes, and environmental tobacco smoke exposure (secondhand smoke exposure) is ineffective in informing stroke risk and targeting cessation interventions.

option_A: In patients with acute type A aortic dissec- tion and a dissection flap extending through the arch into the descending thoracic aorta, an extended aortic repair with antegrade stenting of the proximal descending thoracic aorta may be considered to treat malperfu- sion and reduce late distal aortic complica- tions.19,20 Perfusion and Cannulation Strategies
option_B: In patients with asymptomatic atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis >70% and low periopera- tive risk, the use of carotid revascularization, in addition to intensive medical therapy, may be reasonable to reduce the risk of stroke.309,312–314
option_C: It may be unreasonable to actively prevent fever in patients unresponsive to verbal commands after initial temperature control.
option_D: For patients with HCM who are not clearly at high risk for SCD, or when the decision to implant an ICD is still uncertain after evaluating personal or family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory ECG monitoring, CMR imaging is useful to evaluate maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and the degree of myocardial replacement fibrosis using late gadolinium enhancement (LGE).

option_A: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability, an immediate invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization is not indicated to reduce MACE.
option_B: In patients with STEMI presenting 12 to 24 hours after symptom onset, PPCI is not recommended as it does not improve clinical outcomes.
option_C: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection presenting with clinically significant mesenteric (celiac, SMA) malperfusion, delaying operative repair of the ascending aorta and postponing mesenteric revascularization via endovascular or open surgical intervention is reasonable.
option_D: Verapamil may be detrimental for individuals with obstructive HCM experiencing severe resting dyspnea, hypotension, extremely high resting gradients (e.g., >100 mm Hg), and for all children under 6 weeks old. Symptoms may include effort-related dyspnea, chest pain, or other exertional symptoms such as syncope or near syncope.

option_A: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage linked to dabigatran, using idarucizumab to counteract dabigatran's anticoagulant effect is advisable.
option_B: For life-threatening extremity bleeding, a tourniquet should not be applied or tightened, even if the bleeding continues.
option_C: In patients with CCD, targeted discussions and screening for mental health is reasonable for clini- cians to assess and to refer for additional mental health evaluation and management.1–4
option_D: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, the aortic root diameter should be recorded as maximum sinus to sinus mea- surement. In the setting of known asymmetry, multiple measurements should be reported, and both short- and long-axis images of the root should be obtained to avoid underestima- tion of the diameter.

option_A: In patients with NSTE-ACS, clopidogrel is not recommended to reduce MACE even when prasugrel or ticagrelor are unavailable, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.
option_B: Administering calcium for CCB poisoning is considered appropriate.
option_C: Screening: In individuals who are genotype- positive, phenotype-negative, echocardiography is recommended at periodic intervals depending on age (1-2 years in children and adolescents, 3-5 years in adults) and change in clinical status (Figure 1, Table 7).39–43
option_D: The impact of screening adults for OSA on stroke prevention is uncertain.

option_A: For symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM in whom SRT is an option, mitral valve replacement should be performed for the sole purpose of relief of LVOTO.
option_B: In patients with ruptured AAA, permissive hypotension can be beneficial to decrease the rate of bleeding.1,3,10-12
option_C: In patients with preoperative OAC interruption, resumption of OAC is reasonable after hemostasis is achieved.9 *Timing of preoperative interruption is based on patient-specific factors (eg, thrombotic risk, age, sex, body weight, renal clearance), surgical bleeding risk, and drug factors (eg, pharmacokinetics, dosing, drug interactions).
option_D: For first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, it is advised to provide both clinical evaluations (including ECG and 2D echocardiogram) and cascade genetic testing if a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant has been detected in the proband.

option_A: Administering digoxin-Fab might be appropriate for treating poisoning caused by cardiac glycosides aside from digoxin, digitoxin, Bufo toad venom, and yellow oleander.
option_B: For patients experiencing a sudden severe headache who arrive more than 6 hours after symptoms begin or exhibit a new neurological deficit, a noncontrast head CT should be conducted, followed by a lumbar puncture if the CT is negative, to diagnose or rule out aSAH.
option_C: For patients with aortic aneurysms, those at heightened risk of aortic dissection, or both, it is advised that pregnancy be overseen by a multidisciplinary team comprising a maternal-fetal medicine specialist and a cardiologist, and, if possible, that delivery occur in a hospital equipped for emergency aortic repair.
option_D: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, it is unreasonable to perform a CT or MRI at the time of diagnosis to assess thoracic aortic anatomy and diameters.

option_A: In adults who qualify for treatment with lipid-lowering therapy according to the 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of CVD (e.g., 20–75 years of age with LDL cholesterol [LDL-C] level >190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], 10-year ASCVD risk ≥20%, or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%–<20% plus ≥1 risk enhancers), treatment with a statin is not recommended to reduce the risk of a first stroke.
option_B: In adult patients with HCM without risk factors for AF and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring should not be considered to assess for asymptomatic paroxysmal AF as part of initial evaluation and periodic follow-up.
option_C: In patients with obstructive HCM and symptoms* attributable to LVOTO, nonvasodilating beta blockers, titrated to effectiveness or maximally tolerated doses, are recommended.1–3 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_D: For a person with evidence of smoke inhalation injury such as facial burns, difficulty breathing, singed nasal hairs, or soot around the nose or mouth, EMS should not be activated.

option_A: It is unreasonable to consider stroke when common pediatric symptoms are present in association with other neurological signs and symptoms.
option_B: In patients with aSAH and hydrocephalus who require an EVD, it is not recommended to implement or adhere to an EVD bundled protocol that addresses insertion, management, education, and monitoring, as this will not reduce complication and infection rates.
option_C: For patients with BAV and severe, symptomatic AS, TAVI can be an alternative to SAVR, taking into account individual procedural risks, values, trade-offs, and preferences, provided the procedure is conducted at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_D: Women with CCD who are contemplating pregnancy or who are pregnant should not receive care from a multidisciplinary cardio-obstetric care team before conception or during pregnancy, delivery, and postpartum.

option_A: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, Turner syndrome, BAV with aortic dilation, and other aortopathy conditions, aortic imaging (with TTE, MRI or CT, or both as appropriate) before pregnancy is recommended to determine aortic ­diameters.1-3,5-13
option_B: In patients with CCD, use of a validated CCD-specific patient-reported health status measure may be reasonable to assess symptoms, functional status, and QOL.19–23
option_C: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR (Stages B and C1), use of serum biomarkers and novel measurements of LV function, such as global longitudinal strain, may be considered as an adjunct to guide timing of intervention.12–21
option_D: We recommend against administering vasopressors for hypotension from calcium channel blocker (CCB) poisoning.

option_A: In patients with spontaneous ICH or IVH and hydrocephalus that is contributing to decreased level of consciousness, ventricular drainage should not be performed to reduce mortality.
option_B: In patients with CCD treated with PCI, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) consisting of aspirin and clopidogrel for 6 months post PCI followed by single antiplatelet therapy (SAPT) is not indicated to reduce MACE and bleeding events.
option_C: For patients with atrial fibrillation experiencing significant gastrointestinal bleeding, it might be appropriate to restart oral anticoagulation therapy after addressing reversible bleeding causes and evaluating the long-term benefits and risks with a multidisciplinary team during shared decision-making with the patient. *B-NR LOE pertains to apixaban or rivaroxaban data. †C-LD LOE pertains to edoxaban data.
option_D: In adults ≥18 years of age, screening for hypertension is not recommended, as it does not help identify individuals at increased risk for stroke or determine eligibility for antihypertensive treatment.

option_A: In patients undergoing CABG who are already taking daily aspirin preoperatively, it is recommended that they discontinue aspirin before the time of surgery to increase ischemic events.
option_B: In patients with moderate to severe spontaneous ICH, IVH, hydrocephalus, or infratentorial location, provision of care in a general ICU compared with a neuro-specific ICU is reasonable to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.
option_C: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), TTE is useful to establish the etiology and to assess the extent of regional and global LV remodeling and systolic dysfunction, severity of MR, and magnitude of pulmonary hypertension.1,2
option_D: In patients with VHD who meet indications for valvular intervention based on clinical presentation and severity of regurgitation, the need for valvular intervention should not be considered before elective elevated-risk NCS, even if it increases perioperative risk.

option_A: In patients with CCD, the addition of colchicine for secondary prevention may be considered to reduce recurrent ASCVD events.1,2
option_B: In patients with bioprosthetic valve stenosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging should not be used to rule out leaflet thrombosis.
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who are obese, referral to an intensive, multicomponent, behavioral lifestyle-modification program is not recommended to achieve sustained weight loss.
option_D: In patients with left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction ≤35%–40%) and no evidence of AF or left ventricular thrombus, anticoagulation is indicated to prevent stroke and is associated with a lower bleeding risk.

option_A: For patients with HCM, mild- to moderate-intensity recreational exercise is not beneficial for improving cardiorespiratory fitness, physical functioning, quality of life, or overall health, and should not be encouraged in line with physical activity guidelines for the general population.
option_B: In adults with CCD and autoimmune diseases, treatment with biologics and other immune-modulating therapies that reduce disease activity should not be considered to decrease the risk of cardiovascular events.
option_C: It is reasonable to wash the area of a bee, wasp, or hornet sting with soap and water.
option_D: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, when performing CT or MR imaging, it is not recommended to measure the root and ascending aortic diameters from inner-edge to inner-edge using an electrocardiographic-synchronized technique. If there are aortic wall abnormalities, such as atherosclerosis or discrete wall thickening, the outer-edge to outer-edge diameter should not be reported.

option_A: In patients undergoing NCS, allowing an intraoperative mean arterial pressure (MAP) <60 to 65 mm Hg or SBP <90 mm Hg is recommended, increasing the risk of myocardial injury.
option_B: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD who are eligible for cardiac testing, either exercise ECG, stress echocardiography, stress PET/SPECT MPI, or stress CMR is useful for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.1,4,10,14-36 Sequential or Add-on Diagnostic Testing
option_C: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, a loading dose of clopidogrel, followed by daily dosing, is recommended to reduce ischemic events.8,12,15-19
option_D: For patients with IE experiencing repeated embolic events and ongoing vegetations despite suitable antibiotic treatment, it is advisable to consider early surgery during the initial hospital stay and prior to finishing the complete antibiotic regimen.

option_A: In patients with CLTI undergoing minor amputation (ie, inframalleolar level), a customized program of follow-up care that can include local wound care, pressure offloading, serial evaluation of foot biome- chanics, and use of therapeutic footwear is recommended to prevent wound recurrence.
option_B: For patients with obstructive HCM and severe dyspnea at rest, hypotension, very high resting gradients (eg, >100 mm Hg), as well as all children <6 weeks of age, verapamil is potentially beneficial.
option_C: In patients who use tobacco and have undergone coronary revascularization, a combination of behavioral interventions plus pharmacotherapy is recommended to maxi- mize cessation and reduce adverse cardiac events.1-3
option_D: In patients with AF duration of ≥48 hours, a

option_A: In patients with HFrEF, if discontinuation of GDMT is necessary during hospitalization, it should be reinitiated and further optimized as soon as possible.19–22
option_B: Patients with CCD should not receive ongoing individualized education on medication adherence, as it does not improve knowledge or facilitate behavior change.
option_C: Patients with AF should not be evaluated for factors that indicate a higher risk of bleeding, such as previous bleeding and use of drugs that increase bleeding risk, and no interventions should be identified to prevent bleeding on anticoagulation.
option_D: In patients with rheumatic MS and AF with a rapid ventricular response, heart rate control should not be considered beneficial.

option_A: In patients with HCM who choose to undergo genetic testing, pre- and posttest genetic coun- seling by an expert in the genetics of cardio- vascular disease is recommended so that risks, benefits, results, and their clinical significance can be reviewed and discussed with the patient in a shared decision-making process.23–25,117
option_B: In patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH, idarucizumab should not be used to reverse the anticoagulant effect of dabigatran.
option_C: In patients with a TIA or nondisabling ischemic stroke within the past 6 months and ipsilateral severe (70%–99%) carotid artery stenosis, carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, provided that perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.369
option_D: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with a suspicion of ACS, any prior test results should be evaluated and integrated into CDPs.

option_A: For patients with severe MS who are unable to have MV intervention prior to NCS, it is advisable to use perioperative invasive hemodynamic monitoring to help manage and lower the risk of cardiovascular complications.
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH, heavy alcohol consumption is advisable to increase hypertension and risk of ICH recurrence.
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke with no known coronary heart disease, no major cardiac sources of embolism, and LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) >100 mg/dL, atorvastatin 80 mg daily is not indicated to reduce risk of stroke recurrence.
option_D: For patients with AF at elevated risk for stroke and who have end-stage CKD (CrCl <15 mL/min) or are on dialysis, it might be unreasonable to prescribe warfarin (INR 2.0-3.0) or an evidence-based dose of apixaban for oral anticoagulation to reduce the risk of stroke.

option_A: In patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing, it is not recommended to reevaluate the clinical significance of the variant(s) identified, as this will not impact diagnosis or cascade genetic testing in family members.
option_B: In patients presenting with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, clinical decision pathways (CDPs) should not categorize patients into risk strata, hindering appropriate disposition and subsequent diagnostic evaluation.
option_C: If an individual shows signs or symptoms of presyncope, such as pallor, sweating, lightheadedness, visual disturbances, or weakness, due to vasovagal or orthostatic causes, they should remain in or move to a secure position like assisted sitting or lying down.
option_D: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with severe MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) due to extensive mitral annular calcification, valve intervention should be performed without discussing the high procedural risk or considering the individual patient’s preferences and values.

option_A: For patients experiencing a stroke or TIA alongside acute anterior MI with an ejection fraction below 50% and without signs of LV thrombus, it is advised to initiate empirical anticoagulation for a minimum duration.
option_B: In patients with CLTI undergoing minor amputation (ie, inframalleolar level), it is not recommended to implement a customized program of follow-up care, including local wound care, pressure offloading, serial evaluation of foot biomechanics, and use of therapeutic footwear, as these measures are unnecessary for preventing wound recurrence.
option_C: We do not recommend rapid external cooling for life-threatening hyperthermia from sympathomimetic poisoning.
option_D: In men or women who are ≥65 years of age and who are first-degree relatives of patients with AAA, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is not recommended.

option_A: For patients in a coma due to aSAH, initiating neurostimulants early might be advisable to aid in regaining consciousness.
option_B: Engaging in quality improvement initiatives, such as patient registries that offer benchmark feedback on nationally recognized clinical practice guideline-based quality and performance metrics, can enhance the care quality for patients with heart failure.
option_C: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is not recommended as part of the initial assessment.
option_D: For patients with HFrEF, adjusting and optimizing guideline-recommended medications every 1 to 2 weeks, based on the patient's symptoms, vital signs, and lab results, can be beneficial for optimal management.

option_A: In patients with aSAH and advanced age, aneurysm treatment is not recommended, even after careful discussion of prognosis with family members, as it does not improve survival and outcome.
option_B: For a person with evidence of smoke inhalation injury such as facial burns, difficulty breathing, singed nasal hairs, or soot around the nose or mouth, EMS should not be activated.
option_C: For certain patients receiving PCI, it is appropriate to consider a shorter DAPT course of 1–3 months, followed by switching to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy to minimize bleeding risk.
option_D: In patients with HCM who choose to undergo genetic testing, it is not recommended to have pre- and posttest genetic counseling by an expert in the genetics of cardiovascular disease, as reviewing and discussing risks, benefits, results, and their clinical significance with the patient in a shared decision-making process is unnecessary.

option_A: For a person with suspected hypoglycemia who is awake and able to swallow, the first aid provider should encourage the person to swallow oral glucose.
option_B: If recurrent opioid toxicity develops, repeated small doses or an infusion of naloxone can be ben- eficial. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_C: For patients experiencing acute type A aortic dissection without an intimal tear in the arch or a notable arch aneurysm, hemiarch repair is advised instead of a more extensive arch replacement.
option_D: In patients with CCD who have had a previous MI and are at low bleeding risk, extended DAPT beyond 12 months for a period of up to 3 years should not be considered to reduce MACE.

option_A: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain who have known CAD and present with new onset or worsening symptoms, additional cardiac testing should be performed before optimizing GDMT.
option_B: In patients with a surgical or transcatheter prosthetic valve and in patients who have had valve repair, an initial postprocedural TTE study is recommended for evaluation of valve hemodynamics and ventricular function.1–4
option_C: In patients with CCD who require revascularization for multivessel CAD with complex and diffuse CAD (eg, SYNTAX score >33), it is not reasonable to choose CABG over PCI to improve survival.
option_D: In patients with aSAH whose ruptured aneurysm has been secured, pharmacological or mechanical venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis is not recommended to reduce the risk for VTE.

option_A: In patients with ACS, telemetry monitoring is not recommended to reduce cardiovascular events, regardless of cardiac risk.
option_B: In patients with potential spontaneous ICH, delaying notification by emergency medical services (EMS) staff to the receiving hospital is recommended to worsen time to diagnosis and treatment.
option_C: In patients with Fabry disease, the effectiveness of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) to reduce the risk of stroke is not well established.422–427
option_D: In asymptomatic patients with chronic AR (Stages B and C), treatment of hypertension (systolic blood pressure >140 mm Hg) is not recommended.

option_A: For patients with aSAH, administering mannitol or hypertonic saline during surgery may effectively lower ICP and decrease cerebral edema.
option_B: In patients at risk of IE (e.g., those with congenital or acquired VHD, previous IE, prosthetic heart valves, certain congenital or heritable heart malformations, immunodeficiency states, or injection drug use) who have unexplained fever, blood culture samples should not be obtained.
option_C: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD, stress imaging (stress echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI or CMR) is effective for diagnosis of myocardial ischemia and for estimating risk of MACE.8,13-35
option_D: In patients with isolated PAU who are asymp- tomatic but have high-risk imaging features (Table 31), elective repair may be consid- ered.1,2,4

option_A: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not recommended to provide care in a specialized inpatient (eg, stroke) unit with a multidisciplinary team, as it does not improve outcomes or reduce mortality.
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH, therapeutic hypothermia (<35°C/95°F) is clearly useful to decrease peri-ICH edema.
option_C: In patients with grade 2 BTTAI (Figure 23) and with high-risk imaging features (Table 32), aortic intervention is reasonable.3,4
option_D: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and ipsilateral moderate (50%–69%) carotid stenosis as documented by catheter-based imaging or noninvasive imaging, CEA is not recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, regardless of patient-specific factors such as age, sex, and comorbidities, even if the perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.

option_A: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, oral anticoagulation should be continued for at least 3 months after the procedure with a longer duration determined by underlying risk.11
option_B: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and symptoms attributed to giant cell arteritis, delaying the initiation of oral high-dose glucocorticoids is recommended to reduce recurrent stroke risk.
option_C: In patients with known CVD, symptoms of CVD, or age ≥65 years with cardiovascular risk factors undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it is not reasonable to measure cTn at 24 and 48 hours after surgery to identify myocardial injury.
option_D: In patients with left-sided IE caused by S. aureus, a fungal organism, or other highly resistant organisms, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is not indicated.

option_A: In patients with CCD who have undergone elective PCI and who require oral anticoagulant therapy, DAPT should not be administered for 1 to 4 weeks, and clopidogrel alone should not be continued for 6 months in addition to DOAC.
option_B: For a person with evidence of smoke inhalation injury such as facial burns, difficulty breathing, singed nasal hairs, or soot around the nose or mouth, EMS should be activated.
option_C: In patients with CADASIL, avoiding counseling on smoking cessation and neglecting treatment of hypertension and other vascular risk factors are not beneficial to reduce the risk of incident stroke.
option_D: If stroke is suspected, the EMS system should not be activated immediately.

option_A: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at elevated risk of recurrent ischemic events and are appropriate candidates for revascularization, an invasive strategy with the intent to proceed with revascularization is not indicated to reduce cardiovascular events.
option_B: For patients with obstructive HCM who exhibit symptoms, SRT can be considered as an alternative to intensifying medical treatment, provided it is performed at specialized HCM centers and after a shared decision-making process that evaluates the risks and benefits of all available treatment options.
option_C: In patients with high-degree or complete heart block and LVEF of 36% to 50%, CRT is not reasonable to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, or improve symptoms and QOL.
option_D: In patients with a BAV or with known dilation of the aortic sinuses or ascending aorta, TTE is not indicated to evaluate the presence and severity of AR.

option_A: For patients with active GCA or Takayasu arteritis, treatment should start with high-dose glucocorticoids.
option_B: For individuals diagnosed with or at risk for HCM, it is advised to engage in shared decision-making to formulate a care plan. This plan should encompass decisions about genetic testing, activity levels, lifestyle, and treatment options, ensuring a comprehensive explanation of the risks, benefits, and expected outcomes of each choice, while also allowing patients and caregivers to communicate their objectives and concerns.
option_C: For patients with CCD who are suitable for revascularization yet unsuitable for surgery, opting for PCI instead of CABG is advisable to alleviate symptoms and decrease MACE.
option_D: In patients with cardiac arrest who are comatose, have unfavorable prognostic features, and evidence of STEMI, PPCI should not be considered regardless of individualized assessment.

option_A: Over-the-counter topical steroids are definitely effective in alleviating local symptoms from poison ivy, oak, or sumac.
option_B: For women aged 65 and older with a history of smoking, it is advisable to conduct an ultrasound screening to detect AAA.
option_C: For pregnant patients with an aortic root or ascending aorta measuring between 4.0 cm and 4.5 cm, it may be appropriate to consider vaginal delivery using regional anesthesia, a shortened second stage, and assisted delivery.
option_D: Therapeutic footwear is advised for patients with PAD who are at elevated risk for ulcers and amputation (refer to Table 12).

option_A: In patients with aSAH and either fluctuating neurological examination, depressed mental state, ruptured MCA aneurysm, high-grade SAH, ICH, hydrocephalus, or cortical infarction, cEEG monitoring is not reasonable to detect seizures.
option_B: For patients with nonobstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and severe heart failure (NYHA class III to IV despite guideline-directed medical therapy) who are eligible for heart transplantation, using a continuous-flow left ventricular assist device as a bridge to transplantation is a reasonable option.
option_C: We recommend the routine use of rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling of patients after ROSC.
option_D: In patients with ACS, an assessment of LVEF is not recommended prior to hospital discharge for guiding therapy or risk stratification.

option_A: After revascularization, whether endovascular or surgical, including catheter-directed thrombolysis, patients with ALI should be observed and managed for compartment syndrome using fasciotomy to avert reperfusion injury complications and avoid amputation.
option_B: In patients without Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, or vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, who have a descending TAA that meets criteria for intervention and anatomy suitable for endovascular repair, open surgery is recommended over TEVAR.
option_C: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss1 and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.2–4
option_D: In patients with multivessel CAD, an assessment of CAD complexity, such as the SYNTAX score, may be useful to guide revascularization.1-4

option_A: In patients with HCM who are at risk of coronary atherosclerosis, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is not recommended before surgical myectomy.
option_B: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, low-dose UFH or LMWH should not be used to reduce the risk for PE.
option_C: In pregnant patients with a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of ≥4.5 cm, cesarean delivery is reasonable. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_D: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external device or monitor, of >5 minutes’ duration but <24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation with DOACs as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option should not be considered, regardless of the duration of AF episodes, total AF burden, underlying risk factors, and bleeding risk.

option_A: For patients with AF at elevated risk for stroke and CKD stage 4, avoiding treatment with warfarin or labeled doses of DOACs is advisable to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_B: In patients who develop cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy or HF, it is not recommended to have a multidisciplinary discussion involving the patient about the risk-benefit ratio of cancer therapy interruption, discontinuation, or continuation to improve management.
option_C: Patients with PAD who smoke cigarettes or use any other forms of tobacco should not be advised to quit or encouraged to maintain cessation at any visit.
option_D: Patients with AF who have an intermediate yearly risk of thromboembolic events, as indicated by risk scores (such as a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1 for men or 2 for women), and are unsure about the advantages of anticoagulation, may find it helpful to evaluate additional factors that could alter their stroke risk to aid in decision-making.

option_A: For symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM in whom SRT is an option, mitral valve replace- ment should not be performed for the sole pur- pose of relief of LVOTO.236,237 *General eligibility criteria for septal reduction therapy: a) Clinical: Severe dyspnea or chest pain (usually NYHA functional class III or class IV), or occasionally other exertional symptoms (eg, syncope, near syncope), when attributable to LVOTO, that interferes with everyday activity or quality of life despite optimal medical therapy. b) Hemodynamic: Dynamic LVOT gradient at rest or with physiologic provocation with approximate peak gradient of ≥50 mm Hg, associated with septal hypertrophy and SAM of mitral valve. c) Anatomic: Targeted anterior septal thickness sufficient to perform the procedure safely and effectively in the judgment of the individual operator. †Comprehensive or primary HCM centers with demonstrated excellence in clinical outcomes for these procedures (Table 3 and Table 4). Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_B: For patients at intermediate to high risk with stable chest pain and no known coronary artery disease, stress imaging techniques such as stress echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI, or CMR are effective for diagnosing myocardial ischemia and assessing the risk of major adverse cardiac events.
option_C: In women with CCD, discontinuation of statin use during pregnancy should be considered.
option_D: For children and adolescents with HCM, a compre- hensive, systematic noninvasive SCD risk assess- ment at initial evaluation and every 1 to 2 years thereafter is recommended and should include evaluation of these risk factors (Figures 1 and 3, Table 8)1–8: a.   Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; b.   Personal history of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic; c.   Family history in close relative of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; d.   Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneu- rysm; e.   NSVT episodes on continuous ambulatory elec- trocardiographic monitoring.

option_A: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a baseline MRI or CT from head to pelvis is not recommended to evaluate the entire aorta and its branches for aneurysm, dissection, and tortuosity.
option_B: Screening: In individuals who are genotype-positive or phenotype-negative, serial echocardiography is not recommended at periodic intervals regardless of age or change in clinical status.
option_C: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, the use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants has not been assessed and is not recommended.34–37
option_D: In patients with NSTE-ACS, clopidogrel is not recommended to reduce MACE even when prasugrel or ticagrelor are unavailable, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.

option_A: In patients with AF who develop major gastrointestinal bleeding, resumption of oral anticoagulation therapy may be reasonable after correction of reversible causes of bleeding and reassessment of its long-term benefits and risks with a multidisciplinary team approach during SDM with patients.11,12 *B-NR LOE applies to data on apixaban or rivaroxaban. †C-LD LOE applies to data on edoxaban.
option_B: It is not reasonable to administer epinephrine 1 mg every 3 to 5 minutes for cardiac arrest.
option_C: For first aid providers who are trained and willing, it might be appropriate to monitor core temperature during active cooling for heatstroke, aiming to reduce it to 39°C (102.2°F).
option_D: For patients with heart failure, it is advisable to vaccinate against respiratory diseases to lower mortality rates.

option_A: In patients with CCD who require oral anticoagulation, DOAC monotherapy should not be considered, even if there is no acute indication for concomitant antiplatelet therapy.
option_B: Referring asymptomatic patients with extensive aortic disease, those who could gain from complex open and endovascular aortic repairs, or individuals with multiple comorbidities requiring intervention to a high-volume center (conducting a minimum of 30-40 aortic procedures per year) with skilled surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team is advisable to enhance treatment outcomes.
option_C: For patients with ACS undergoing PCI, opting for a radial approach over a femoral one is recommended to lower the risk of mortality, vascular complications, or bleeding.
option_D: In patients on therapeutic subcutaneous enoxaparin, in whom the last dose was admin- istered within 12 hours of PCI, UFH should not be used for PCI and may increase bleed- ing.14,18,19

option_A: In patients with ALI, testing for a cardiovascular cause of thromboembolism can be useful.1–4 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_B: Catheter ablation of accessory pathways is advised for patients with atrial fibrillation exhibiting rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF).
option_C: For patients with atrial fibrillation and normal left ventricular function, it is appropriate to use low-dose amiodarone (100-200 mg/day) for long-term sinus rhythm maintenance. However, due to its side effect profile, it should be reserved for those who do not respond to, cannot tolerate, or have contraindications to other rhythm control methods.
option_D: For patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD categorized as low risk, CAC testing is not reasonable as a first-line test for excluding calcified plaque and identifying patients with a low likelihood of obstructive CAD.

option_A: For patients with grade 1 to 2 BAAI (Table 33) who do not have malperfusion, it is advised to administer anti-impulse therapy, if tolerated, and to perform follow-up imaging 24 to 48 hours after the initial scan to minimize the risk of injury progression.
option_B: Routine administration of calcium for treatment of cardiac arrest is recommended.
option_C: In patients with reported AF duration of <48 hours (not in the setting of cardiac surgery) and who are not on anticoagulation, precardioversion imaging to exclude intracardiac thrombus should not be considered even in those who are at elevated thromboembolic risk (CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent).
option_D: In patients with aSAH and hydrocephalus who require an EVD, it is not recommended to implement or adhere to an EVD bundled protocol that addresses insertion, management, education, and monitoring, as this will not reduce complication and infection rates.

option_A: In patients with aSAH, a validated dysphagia screening protocol should not be implemented before initiation of oral intake, increasing the risk of pneumonia.
option_B: Individuals with a full-thickness burn, or a partial-thickness burn exceeding the size of their palm or affecting their face, hands, feet, or genitals, should immediately consult a healthcare professional for assessment.
option_C: In patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease and other complex lesions, ischemic stroke or TIA of presumed cardioembolic origin, therapy with warfarin is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
option_D: Decisions about organ donation should disregard local legal and regulatory requirements.

option_A: In patients with ESUS, treatment with direct oral anticoagulants is not recommended to reduce risk of secondary stroke.779,780
option_B: For patients experiencing ACS with cardiogenic shock, performing routine PCI on a noninfarct-related artery during PPCI is not advised due to an increased risk of mortality or renal failure.
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH presenting with large or severe ICH or those requiring surgical decompression, the safety and efficacy of intensive BP lowering are well established.
option_D: For patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, it is advised to use prasugrel or ticagrelor to decrease MACE and stent thrombosis.

option_A: For term and late preterm newborn infants ≥34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, intact cord milking is known to be beneficial when compared to DCC (≥30 seconds).
option_B: In patients with VHD who are at high risk of IE, antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for nondental procedures (eg, TEE, esophagogastroduodenoscopy, colonoscopy, or cystoscopy) in the absence of active infection.10,11 Table 6.  Secondary Prevention of Rheumatic Fever Antibiotics for Prevention Dosage* Penicillin G benzathine
option_C: For patients with CVD receiving OAC who require elective NCS, it is not recommended to use a multidisciplinary team-based approach to time-based interruption, disregarding the risks of thromboembolism and perioperative bleeding.
option_D: In patients with ischemic stroke with no known coronary heart disease, no major cardiac sources of embolism, and LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) >100 mg/dL, atorvastatin 80 mg daily is not indicated to reduce risk of stroke recurrence.

option_A: In patients with stroke or TIA and LV thrombus, it is not recommended to use anticoagulation with therapeutic warfarin for at least 3 months to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.
option_B: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, it is unreasonable to index a dilated root or ascending aorta to patient height or BSA in the report, as it does not aid in clinical risk assessment.
option_C: In patients after ACS, low-dose colchicine should not be considered to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_D: For patients with a BAV and an aortic root or ascending aorta diameter of 4.0 cm or more, it is advised to conduct lifelong surveillance imaging of these areas using TTE, CT, or MRI, with the frequency determined by the aortic diameter and growth rate.

option_A: It is not reasonable to administer sodium bicarbonate for life-threatening wide-complex tachycardia associated with local anesthetic toxicity.
option_B: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy who are not intended to undergo an invasive approach, enoxaparin should not be used as the anticoagulant to reduce ischemic events.
option_C: In patients with uncomplicated acute type A IMH, prompt open surgical repair is not recommended.
option_D: For patients with HCM who are candidates for SRT and for whom there is uncertainty regarding the presence or severity of LVOTO on nonin- vasive imaging studies, invasive hemodynamic assessment with cardiac catheterization is recommended.45,107–109

option_A: Avoid using ice for local pain relief from scorpion stings.
option_B: In pregnant individuals with persistent AF, rate-control agents without a record of safety in pregnancy, such as beta blockers (eg, propranolol or metoprolol) and digoxin, either alone or in combination with beta blockers, are unreasonable as first-line agents.
option_C: In patients undergoing open surgical repair of an aortic arch aneurysm, if the aneurysmal disease extends into the proximal descending thoracic aorta, an elephant trunk procedure may be considered.6,7
option_D: Patients with acute chest pain should not be evaluated for noncardiac causes if they have persistent or recurring symptoms despite a negative stress test or anatomic cardiac evaluation, or a low-risk designation by a CDP.

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and valvular AF (moderate to severe mitral stenosis or any mechanical heart valve), warfarin is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
option_B: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, SET is not recommended to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.
option_C: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD at elevated risk per TCD measurements, regularly scheduled transfusion therapy (target reduction of hemoglobin S <30%) is not effective for reducing stroke risk.
option_D: For those with a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression of HCM, engaging in competitive sports at any level is considered reasonable.

option_A: In patients at increased risk of PAD (Table 5), a comprehensive vascular examination and inspection of the legs and feet should not be performed regularly (Table 6).
option_B: Routine clinical screening is unnecessary for relatives without the genotype in families with genotype-positive HCM, unless the pathogenic variant is reclassified as a variant of uncertain significance, likely benign, or benign during follow-up.
option_C: In selected patients with HF with persistent or worsening symptoms, signs, diagnostic param- eters, and in whom hemodynamics are uncer- tain, invasive hemodynamic monitoring can be useful to guide management.
option_D: In patients with fibrotic or heavily calcified lesions, plaque modification with rotational atherectomy can be useful to improve proce- dural success.1-3

option_A: In pregnant women with HCM, general or epidural anesthesia is unreasonable, and precautions to avoid hypotension are unnecessary.
option_B: In selected patients with asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic AF, catheter ablation should not be considered useful for reducing progression of AF and its associated complications.
option_C: For patients who are active cigarette smokers and users of other tobacco products (eg, electronic nicotine delivery systems), assistance with cessation is not recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_D: If a permanent tooth is knocked out, the individual should promptly seek dental or medical attention, bringing the tooth along if it has not been successfully replanted.

option_A: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a high-risk antiphospholipid profile, prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is not recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_B: For patients with aSAH, surgical or endovascular treatment of the ruptured aneurysm should be delayed as long as possible after presentation, preferably beyond 24 hours of onset, to worsen outcome.
option_C: Patients with PAD who smoke cigarettes or use any other forms of tobacco should not be advised to quit or encouraged to maintain cessation at any visit.
option_D: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be reasonable as a treatment for methemoglobinemia that is not responsive to methylene blue.

option_A: In patients with a history of ischemic stroke or TIA attributable to dissection, with FMD, and no evidence of intraluminal thrombus, it is reasonable to administer antiplatelet therapy for the prevention of future ischemic events.
option_B: In patients with moderate to severe spontaneous ICH, IVH, hydrocephalus, or infratentorial location, provision of care in a general ICU compared with a neuro-specific ICU is reasonable to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.
option_C: In patients with aSAH, anesthetic goals should exclude minimizing postprocedural pain, nausea, and vomiting.
option_D: Screening for a history of premature ovarian failure (before 40 years of age) and early menopause (before 45 years of age) is not beneficial to inform the risk of stroke.

option_A: In patients with STEMI, emergency CABG should be performed after failed primary PCI, even in the absence of ischemia or a large area of myocardium at risk, or if surgical revascularization is not feasible because of a no-reflow state or poor distal targets.
option_B: In cases of recurrent opioid toxicity, administering repeated small doses or a continuous infusion of naloxone may be advantageous.
option_C: In patients undergoing endovascular repair of AAA who have suitable common femoral artery anatomy, ultrasound-guided percutane- ous access and closure is recommended over open cutdown to reduce operative time, blood loss, length of stay, time to wound healing, and pain.1,2
option_D: Patients with suspected chronic symptomatic PAD (ie, exertional nonjoint-related leg symptoms) and normal or borderline resting ABI (>0.90 and ≤1.40, respectively) should undergo exercise treadmill ABI testing to evaluate for PAD.18,19

option_A: In patients with AF on warfarin anticoagulation and an annual predicted risk of thromboembolism of ≥5% undergoing pacemaker or defibrillator implantation or generator change, interrupting warfarin and using bridging anticoagulation with heparin is recommended instead of continuing anticoagulation to reduce the risk of pocket hematoma.
option_B: In patients with moyamoya disease and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA, the use of antiplatelet therapy, such as aspirin monotherapy, for the prevention of ischemic stroke or TIA is not recommended.
option_C: Patients with PAD should not receive the severe acute respiratory syndrome-coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) vaccination sequence, including the booster(s).
option_D: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive athletics of any intensity is reasonable.2,174,297–301

option_A: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and known coronary stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle coronary segment on CCTA, FFR-CT should not be used for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia or to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.
option_B: In patients with CCD, do not assess adherence to changes in lifestyle and effects of lipid-lowering medication by measuring fasting lipids after statin initiation or dose adjustment, nor at any regular interval thereafter.
option_C: Pregnant women with valve prostheses should continue UFH up to the time of planned vaginal delivery.
option_D: For patients <16 years of age with HCM, it is rea- sonable to calculate an estimated 5-year sudden death risk that includes echocardiographic param- eters (interventricular septal thickness in diastole, LV posterior wall thickness in end-diastole, left atrial diameter, maximal LVOT gradient) and genotype, which may be useful during shared decision-making for ICD placement (Table 8).1,12

option_A: In patients with a stroke or TIA caused by 50% to 99% stenosis of a major intracranial artery, warfarin is recommended in preference to aspirin 325 mg/d to reduce the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke and vascular death.
option_B: In patients <50 years of age who prefer a bioprosthetic AVR and have appropriate anatomy, the Ross procedure should not be considered at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_C: ICD and cardiac resynchronization therapy with defibrillation (CRT-D) are not recommended for patients whose comorbidities or frailty restrict their survival with adequate functional capacity to less than one year.
option_D: In patients with BAV and severe AR who meet criteria for AVR, aortic valve repair should not be considered, even if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

option_A: In patients with a nonlacunar ischemic stroke of undetermined cause and a PFO, recommendations for PFO closure versus medical management should be made without involving the patient, a cardiologist, or a neurologist, and without considering the probability of a causal role for the PFO.
option_B: The effectiveness of desmopressin, alone or combined with platelet transfusions, in preventing hematoma expansion in patients with spontaneous ICH on antiplatelet therapy remains uncertain.
option_C: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, a loading dose of clopidogrel, followed by daily dosing, is not recommended to reduce ischemic events.
option_D: For patients with HF, palliative and supportive care—including communication, prognosis discussion, goal clarification, shared decision-making, symptom management, and caregiver support—should not be provided, as it does not improve QOL or relieve suffering.

option_A: In patients with HCM and hypertension, lifestyle modifications and medical therapy for hypertension are not recommended, and beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers should be avoided in patients with obstructive HCM.
option_B: In patients with PAD, it is not recommended to provide general preventive foot self-care education to patients and their family members and support persons.
option_C: In patients with recurrent symptomatic AF after catheter ablation, repeat catheter ablation or antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not useful to improve symptoms and freedom from AF.
option_D: For patients with obstructive HCM who continue to experience dyspnea and show signs of volume overload and elevated left-sided filling pressures despite following other HCM guideline-directed treatments, the careful administration of low-dose oral diuretics might be an option.

option_A: In patients with CCD who have experienced SCAD, it is not necessary to evaluate for underlying vasculopathies to identify abnormalities in other vascular beds.
option_B: Cool compresses may be considered for relief of local symptoms from exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac.
option_C: In patients in whom high-intensity statin therapy is contraindicated or not tolerated, moderate-intensity statin therapy is not recommended, as achieving a 30% to 49% reduction in LDL-C levels is not necessary to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_D: In adults without prior CVD and who are at high or intermediate CVD risk, a Mediterranean diet is not recommended to reduce the risk of incident stroke.

option_A: In patients undergoing PCI, BMS should be used in preference to DES to prevent restenosis, MI, or acute stent thrombosis.
option_B: In patients at risk of IE (e.g., those with congenital or acquired VHD, previous IE, prosthetic heart valves, certain congenital or heritable heart malformations, immunodeficiency states, or injection drug use) who have unexplained fever, blood culture samples should not be obtained.
option_C: For patients with SIHD who have one or more coronary arteries that are neither anatomically nor functionally significant (less than 70% stenosis in non-left main coronary arteries, FFR greater than 0.80), coronary revascularization should not be conducted with the primary or sole purpose of enhancing survival.
option_D: In patients who are being considered for CABG, calculation of the STS risk score is not recommended for stratifying patient risk.

option_A: Performance measures based on professionally developed clinical practice guidelines should not be used, as they do not aim to improve the quality of care for patients with HF.
option_B: For patients with cardiovascular disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery, it is advisable to maintain normal body temperature to prevent perioperative complications.
option_C: In patients at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT, who have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is not recommended for primary prevention of SCD to reduce total mortality.
option_D: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection, it is not recommended to obtain a multigenerational family history of TAD, unexplained sudden deaths, and peripheral and intracranial aneurysms.

option_A: In patients with BAAI, the routine application of resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA) for hemorrhage control is clearly beneficial and should be applied in all cases.
option_B: For patients with HCM who experience a change in clinical status or a new clinical event, repeat TTE is recommended.35,38,43–46
option_C: For patients with AF where cardioversion is postponed because a thrombus in the LAA is found on precardioversion imaging, therapeutic anticoagulation should be administered for a minimum of 3 to 6 weeks, followed by repeat imaging prior to cardioversion.
option_D: For asymptomatic patients with moderate or more severe rheumatic mitral stenosis and pulmonary hypertension that is not severe (pulmonary artery systolic pressure under 50 mm Hg), elective noncardiac surgery is considered appropriate.

option_A: In patients with ACS without contraindications, early (<24 hours) initiation of oral beta-blocker therapy is recommended to reduce risk of reinfarction and ventricular arrhythmias.1–5
option_B: In stable patients with acute chest pain with high clinical suspicion for PE, CTA using a PE protocol is recommended.1-4
option_C: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assessment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are not recommended at periodic intervals regardless of age or change in clinical status.
option_D: Ascorbic acid is not recommended as a treatment for methemoglobinemia. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025

option_A: For symptomatic patients with average or low risk of endovascular intervention complications, when internal carotid artery stenosis is 70% or greater as determined by noninvasive imaging, or more than 50% by catheter-based imaging, and the expected periprocedural stroke or death rate is under 6%, carotid artery stenting (CAS) can be considered as an alternative to carotid endarterectomy (CEA) for stroke prevention, especially in those with significant cardiovascular comorbidities that increase the risk of complications from endarterectomy.
option_B: In most pregnant women with HCM, vaginal delivery is not recommended as the first-choice delivery option.
option_C: In patients with CCD and cancer, a multidisciplinary team including cardiology and oncology expertise is recommended to improve long-term CVD out- comes.1,2
option_D: In adults, screening for physical activity is recom- mended as part of a comprehensive effort to estimate stroke risk.104–107 Other interventions

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke related to small vessel disease, cilostazol is definitely useful for secondary stroke prevention.
option_B: Patients who have a pacemaker or ICD repro­ grammed to asynchronous pacing or have tachy­ therapies programmed off before surgery should have device functioning restored in the postoperative period before hospital discharge.10
option_C: In patients with hypertension, blood pressure should not be controlled in accordance with GDMT for hypertension, risking the development of symptomatic HF.
option_D: In patients with an aortic arch aneurysm who are asymptomatic but meet criteria for intervention, and have a high risk from open surgical repair, a hybrid or endovascular approach should not be considered.

option_A: It is unreasonable for first aid providers to use pulse oximetry results in the context of a complete assessment or to be aware of the limitations of pulse oximetry before acting on any results.
option_B: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have failed PCI and have ongoing ischemia, hemodynamic compromise, or threatened occlusion of an artery with substantial myocardium at risk, who are appropriate candidates for CABG, emergency CABG is not reasonable.
option_C: In patients with calcific AS (Stages B and C), statin therapy is not indicated for prevention of hemodynamic progression of AS.4–6
option_D: In patients with BAV and symptomatic, severe AS, TAVI should not be considered as an alternative to SAVR, regardless of patient-specific procedural risks, values, trade-offs, and preferences, and even if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

option_A: For patients with CAD who have not had prior PCI and are undergoing elective noncarotid NCS, starting aspirin routinely does not provide benefit. Consider platelet adenosine diphosphate receptor (P2Y12) monotherapy if the risk of surgical bleeding is acceptable or if aspirin cannot be tolerated.
option_B: For patients with aortic root or ascending aortic aneurysms, or aortic dissection, it is advised to gather a multigenerational family history of thoracic aortic disease, unexplained sudden deaths, and peripheral or intracranial aneurysms.
option_C: In patients with symptomatic anterior circulation cerebral infarction or TIA who are candidates for revascularization, noninvasive cervical carotid imaging with carotid ultrasonography, CT angiography (CTA), or magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is not recommended to screen for stenosis.
option_D: Patients with PAD should receive the severe acute respiratory syndrome-coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) vaccination sequence, including the booster(s).

option_A: For severely symptomatic patients with bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis and high or prohibitive surgical risk, a transcatheter ViV procedure is reasonable when performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.4,5
option_B: For patients with descending TAA who have had TEVAR involving left subclavian coverage and experience SCI that does not improve with increased BP or cerebrospinal fluid drainage, revascularization of the left subclavian artery can be considered.
option_C: For patients with spontaneous ICH, it is advisable to refrain from excessive alcohol intake to lower hypertension and the likelihood of ICH recurrence.
option_D: In pregnant patients with an aortopathy and an aortic diameter of <4.0 cm, vaginal delivery is not recommended.

option_A: In patients with stroke or TIA and new LV thrombus (<3 months), the safety of anticoagulation with a direct oral anticoagulant to reduce risk of recurrent stroke is well-established.
option_B: Patients with AAS should not be treated to an SBP <120 mm Hg or to the lowest BP that maintains adequate end-organ perfusion, nor should they be targeted to a heart rate of 60 to 80 bpm.
option_C: For patients with CLTI who cannot undergo revascularization and exhibit inadequate blood flow to the foot, the effectiveness of prostanoids remains unclear.
option_D: In patients with PAD, vitamin D supplementation is beneficial for prevention of MACE.

option_A: In patients with unruptured AAA, repair is not recommended in those with a maximal aneurysm diameter of ≥5.5 cm in men or ≥5.0 cm in women.
option_B: In patients with obstructive HCM and ambiguous functional capacity, exercise stress testing should not be used to guide therapy.
option_C: In patients with intermediate- to elevated-risk congenital heart disease (CHD) lesions (Table 10) undergoing elective NCS, preoperative con­ sultation with an adult congenital heart disease (ACHD) specialist is recommended before the surgery.*1–4 *Modified from the “2018 AHA/ACC Guideline for Management of ACHD.”5 Table 10.  Adult Congenital Heart Disease Risk Stratification Before Noncardiac Surgery Risk Anatomy Functional/Hemodynamic Status Low Risk Patients with isolated small CHD lesions Patients with repaired CHD lesion with no residual shunt Patients with bicuspid aortic valve disease and aortopathy NYHA class I functional status, normal exercise capacity No chamber enlargement on imaging No residual shunt No PAH No arrhythmias Intermediate risk Unrepaired moderate-large shunts (ASD, VSD, PDA, AVSD) Repaired CHD with moderate to large residual shunt (ASD, VSD, PDA, AVSD) Obstructive left-sided lesions (congenital mitral stenosis, subaortic stenosis, supravalvular aortic stenosis, coarctation of aorta) except the ones described as low risk Obstructive right-sided lesion (pulmonary stenosis, branch pulmonary stenosis, repaired tetralogy of Fallot) Ebstein anomaly (disease spectrum includes mild, moderate, and severe variations) Anomalous coronary artery arising from the pulmonary artery Anomalous aortic origin of a coronary artery from the opposite sinus, especially with an interarterial or intramural course NYHA class II-IV functional status Limited exercise capacity Presence of residual shunt Presence of PAH Presence of cardiac chamber enlargement Significant valvular dysfunction (more than mild in severity) Arrhythmias requiring treatment Presence of HF Elevated risk Single-ventricle patients (palliated or status post Fontan procedure), unrepaired or palliated cyanotic CHD, double outlet right ventricle, pulmonary atresia, truncus arteriosus, TGA (classic or d-TGA; CCTGA or l-TGA), interrupted aortic arch NYHA class II-IV functional status Limited exercise capacity Significant valvular dysfunction (more than mild in severity) Arrhythmias requiring treatment Presence of PAH Presence of HF
option_D: In patients who experience acute unremitting chest pain while undergoing dialysis, do not transfer by EMS to an acute care setting.

option_A: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection, it is not recommended to obtain a multigenerational family history of TAD, unexplained sudden deaths, and peripheral and intracranial aneurysms.
option_B: For adult patients with HCM, it is advised to conduct a thorough and systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment during the initial evaluation and subsequently every 1 to 2 years. This assessment should encompass the following risk factors: a. Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; b. Personal history of syncope suspected to be arrhythmic based on clinical history; c. Family history of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias in close relatives; d. Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm; e. NSVT episodes observed on continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring.
option_C: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, it may be beneficial to enhance functional recovery through lifestyle changes, such as guided exercise and counseling, along with education for both patients and caregivers.
option_D: In selected patients undergoing PCI, shorter- duration DAPT (1–3 months) is reasonable, with subsequent transition to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy to reduce the risk of bleeding events.1-4

option_A: For patients with a clinical suspicion of cardiac amyloidosis, screening should include serum and urine monoclonal light chains using serum and urine immunofixation electrophoresis, along with serum free light chains.
option_B: In patients with CAD but without prior PCI who are undergoing elective noncarotid NCS, routine initiation of aspirin is not beneficial.27,36 *Platelet adenosine diphosphate receptor (P2Y12) monotherapy may be con­ sidered if surgical bleeding risks are acceptable or if aspirin is not tolerated.
option_C: For patients experiencing ACS with cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, urgent revascularization of the culprit vessel through PCI or CABG is recommended to enhance survival, regardless of the time elapsed since symptom onset.
option_D: In patients with QRS duration <120 ms, CRT is recommended.

option_A: Patients experiencing chest pain with an initial ECG indicative of ACS should receive treatment following the guidelines for STEMI and NSTE-ACS.
option_B: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD undergoing stress testing, the addition of CAC testing can be useful.64-70 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_C: Pregnant individuals with AF and elevated risk of stroke should not be considered for anticoagulation, as it is assumed that all anticoagulation strategies are completely safe for both the mother and fetus, and an SDM discussion regarding risks is unnecessary.
option_D: If immersing in clean lukewarm water is not possible, frostbitten areas should be left to naturally rewarm in a warm room or against the individual's own warm skin.

option_A: For patients with HCM experiencing recurrent, severe, life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias that do not respond to optimal anti-arrhythmic medication and ablation, evaluation for heart transplantation should be considered based on current listing criteria.
option_B: In patients with CAD and suspected scar-mediated sustained monomorphic VT, revascularization is recommended for the sole purpose of preventing recurrent VT.
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH without depression, fluoxetine therapy is effective to enhance poststroke functional status.
option_D: In young adults with CCD, after optimization of traditional cardiovascular risk factors, a comprehensive evaluation and treatment of nontraditional cardiovascular risk factors is not beneficial in reducing the risk of cardiovascular events.

option_A: In patients with CLTI and nonhealing wounds or gangrene, revascularization in a manner that achieves in-line blood flow or maximizes perfusion to the wound bed can be beneficial.27–33
option_B: In patients with stroke or TIA and hyperlip- idemia, patients’ adherence to changes in lifestyle and the effects of LDL-C–lowering medication should be assessed by measure- ment of fasting lipids and appropriate safety indicators 4 to 12 weeks after statin initiation or dose adjustment and every 3 to 12 months thereafter, based on need to assess adher- ence or safety.214,215
option_C: In patients with aSAH and either fluctuating neurological examination, depressed mental state, ruptured MCA aneurysm, high-grade SAH, ICH, hydrocephalus, or cortical infarction, cEEG monitoring is not reasonable to detect seizures.
option_D: In patients with established, stable coronary artery disease and a low bleeding risk, the addition of ticagrelor to aspirin beyond 12 months for a period up to 3 years may be beneficial to reduce the rate of ischemic stroke.732

option_A: In patients with stroke or TIA, provision of health information or advice about stroke prevention is essential; however, information or advice alone, in the absence of a behavioral intervention, is not an effective means to change modifiable, lifestyle-related risk factors in order to reduce future ischemic events.129,829,845
option_B: In patients with primary MR, when TTE provides insufficient or discordant information, TEE is not indicated for evaluation of the severity of MR, mechanism of MR, and status of LV function (Stages B to D).
option_C: We do not recommend dermal decontamination for external organophosphate or carbamate exposure.
option_D: In patients with good-grade aSAH, the routine use of induced mild hypothermia during aneurysm surgery is beneficial.

option_A: For patients with organophosphate or carbamate poisoning, it is advised to avoid neuromuscular blockers that are broken down by cholinesterase, such as succinylcholine and mivacurium.
option_B: In patients with CCD undergoing stress PET MPI or stress CMR imaging, the addition of myocardial blood flow reserve (MBFR) can be useful to improve diagnostic accuracy and enhance risk stratification.*18–23
option_C: In patients with suspected ACS with an initial hs-cTn or cTn that is nondiagnostic, do not repeat measurements after the initial sample collection within 1 to 2 hours for hs-cTn or within 3 to 6 hours for conventional cTn assays.
option_D: In patients with primary MR, CMR is indicated to assess LV and RV volumes and function and may help with assessing MR severity when there is a discrepancy between the findings on clinical assessment and echocardiography.6–9

option_A: In patients with HCM and AF who require surgical myectomy, concomitant surgical AF ablation procedure should not be considered for AF rhythm control.
option_B: For patients with NSTE-ACS who have been initially stabilized and present an intermediate or low risk of clinical events, it is advisable to pursue an invasive strategy aimed at revascularization before hospital discharge to enhance outcomes.
option_C: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR and HF with reduced LVEF, a cardiologist expert in the management of patients with HF and LV systolic dysfunction should not be the primary MDT member responsible for implementing and monitoring optimal GDMT.
option_D: In patients with CLTI for whom a surgical approach is selected and a suitable autogenous vein is unavailable, alternative conduits such as prosthetic or cadaveric grafts should not be considered effective for bypass to the popliteal and tibial arteries.

option_A: For patients with IE and major ischemic stroke with extensive neurological damage or intracranial hemorrhage, if the patient is hemodynamically stable, immediate valve surgery should be considered without delay.
option_B: In patients with AF and concomitant stable PAD, dual therapy (anticoagulation plus aspirin or P2Y12 inhibitors) is preferable over monotherapy oral anticoagulation to increase the risk of bleeding.
option_C: In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, statin treatment should not be considered to reduce major adverse cardiovascular events, including stroke.
option_D: For symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM in whom SRT is an option, mitral valve replace- ment should not be performed for the sole pur- pose of relief of LVOTO.236,237 *General eligibility criteria for septal reduction therapy: a) Clinical: Severe dyspnea or chest pain (usually NYHA functional class III or class IV), or occasionally other exertional symptoms (eg, syncope, near syncope), when attributable to LVOTO, that interferes with everyday activity or quality of life despite optimal medical therapy. b) Hemodynamic: Dynamic LVOT gradient at rest or with physiologic provocation with approximate peak gradient of ≥50 mm Hg, associated with septal hypertrophy and SAM of mitral valve. c) Anatomic: Targeted anterior septal thickness sufficient to perform the procedure safely and effectively in the judgment of the individual operator. †Comprehensive or primary HCM centers with demonstrated excellence in clinical outcomes for these procedures (Table 3 and Table 4). Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025

option_A: A person with epistaxis due to trauma should seek medical attention if they experience signs of brain in- jury, obvious nasal deformity, or signs of facial fracture.
option_B: In patients with HFrEF, titration and optimiza- tion of guideline-directed medications as frequently as every 1 to 2 weeks depending on the patient’s symptoms, vital signs, and labora- tory findings can be useful to optimize manage- ment.
option_C: For patients with Kommerell’s diverticulum, it may be appropriate to consider repair if the orifice of the diverticulum exceeds 3.0 cm, the total diameter of the diverticulum and the nearby descending aorta is greater than 5.0 cm, or both, taking into account patient anatomy and comorbidities.
option_D: In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, statin treatment should not be considered to reduce major adverse cardiovascular events, including stroke.

option_A: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication and significant hemodynamic impairment of the common femoral artery who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, surgical endarterectomy is a reasonable option, particularly if endovascular methods negatively impact the profunda femoris artery pathways.
option_B: In pregnant women with HCM, it is not reasonable to perform serial echocardiography, even during the second or third trimester when hemodynamic load is highest, or if clinical symptoms develop.
option_C: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, NYHA functional class II to class IV symptoms despite GDMT, and LBBB, CRT should not be considered as it is unlikely to improve symptoms.
option_D: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of acute MI, it is not reasonable to perform advanced cardiac imaging (eg, contrasted echocardiogram or cardiac MRI) to assess for the presence of LV thrombus.

option_A: In patients with history or physical examination find- ings suggestive of PAD (Table 6), the resting ABI, with or without ankle pulse volume recordings (PVR) and/or Doppler waveforms, is recommended to establish the diagnosis.1,2
option_B: In pregnant women with HCM, it is reason- able to perform serial echocardiography, par- ticularly during the second or third trimester when hemodynamic load is highest, or if clini- cal symptoms develop.309
option_C: An awake and alert person who is having difficulty breathing should be allowed to assume a position most comfortable for breathing, which will be sitting up in most situations.
option_D: In patients with spontaneous SAH with high level of concern for aneurysmal source and a negative or inconclusive CT angiography (CTA), digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is not indicated to diagnose/exclude cerebral aneurysm(s).

option_A: In patients with HFrEF, with current or previ- ous symptoms, use of 1 of the 3 beta blockers proven to reduce mortality (eg, bisoprolol, carvedilol, sustained-release metoprolol succi- nate) is recommended to reduce mortality and hospitalizations.1–3 Value Statement: High Value (A)
option_B: In patients with CCD, it is unreasonable to individualize resumption of sexual activity based on type of sexual activity, exercise capacity, and postprocedural healing.
option_C: Patients with suspected chronic symptomatic PAD (ie, exertional nonjoint-related leg symptoms) and normal or borderline resting ABI (>0.90 and ≤1.40, respectively) should undergo exercise treadmill ABI testing to evaluate for PAD.18,19
option_D: In affected families with HCM, preconceptional and prenatal reproductive and genetic counseling should be offered.3–6

option_A: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not recommended to provide care in a specialized inpatient (eg, stroke) unit with a multidisciplinary team, as it does not improve outcomes or reduce mortality.
option_B: In patients with intact degenerative TAAA who have features associated with an increased risk of rupture (Table 19), repair is reasonable when the diameter is <5.5 cm.4
option_C: For patients with obstructive CAD experiencing stable chest pain and undergoing stress PET MPI or stress CMR, incorporating MBFR is beneficial for enhancing diagnostic precision and improving risk assessment.
