option_D: For patients with a mechanical SAVR or mitral valve replacement on VKA therapy who require antiplatelet treatment, aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily can be considered if the bleeding risk is minimal.

option_A: In adults 18 to 64 years of age with migraine with or without aura, evaluation and modification of vascular risk factors are recommended to address the elevated risk of stroke in this patient population.362–369
option_B: In patients with a BAV, screening of all first- degree relatives by TTE is reasonable to evaluate for the presence of a BAV, dilation of the aortic root and ascending aorta, or both.7-10
option_C: In patients with calcific AS, statin therapy is not indicated for primary and secondary prevention of atherosclerosis based on standard risk scores.
option_D: In patients with CCD and lifestyle-limiting angina despite GDMT and with significant coronary artery stenoses amenable to revascularization, revascularization is recom- mended to improve symptoms.*1–7

option_A: Epidural analgesia can be considered for patients with a hip fracture awaiting surgical repair to reduce the risk of preoperative cardiac events.
option_B: For patients with spontaneous ICH, providing practical support and training to the caregiver is advisable to enhance the patients' standing balance.
option_C: In women with acute HF caused by peripartum cardiomyopathy and LVEF <30%, anticoagulation should not be considered at diagnosis, until 6 to 8 weeks postpartum, as the efficacy and safety are uncertain.
option_D: Patients for whom there is a clinical suspi- cion for cardiac amyloidosis*1–5 should have screening for serum and urine monoclonal light chains with serum and urine immuno- fixation electrophoresis and serum free light chains.6

option_A: Patients with CCD should regularly be inquired about and advised on substance use to lower the risk of ASCVD events.
option_B: For patients with TAD carrying a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant, it is advised to conduct genetic testing on at-risk biological relatives, known as cascade testing. If genetic screening reveals that family members have inherited the pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant, it is recommended to perform aortic imaging using TTE, provided the aortic root and ascending aorta are clearly visible; otherwise, CT or MRI should be used.
option_C: In patients with DES-PCI placed for ACS who require elective NCS with interruption of ≥1 antiplatelet agents, surgery should not be delayed and can be performed before 12 months, disregarding the risk of perioperative MACE.
option_D: It may be reasonable to attempt electrical pacing for β-blocker–induced bradycardia.

option_A: In pregnant women with VHD, ACE inhibitors and ARBs should be given despite the fetal risk.
option_B: In patients with asymptomatic atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis, medical treatment with statin is not beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_C: Avoid the use of over-the-counter acetaminophen and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents for alleviating local pain.
option_D: For patients with ACS and either acute or chronic anemia, it might be appropriate to administer a blood transfusion to reach a hemoglobin level of at least 10 g/dL to potentially lower the risk of cardiovascular events.

option_A: In patients with CCD without previous MI or LVEF ≤50%, the use of beta-blocker therapy is not ben- eficial in reducing MACE, in the absence of another primary indication for beta-blocker therapy.†16–19 *Modified from the 2022 AHA/ACC/HFSA Guideline for the Management of Heart Failure.20 †Adapted from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.21
option_B: For individuals with chronic kidney disease, aspirin does not effectively prevent an initial stroke.
option_C: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, dual-chamber ICDs are not recommended for patients with a need for atrial or atrioventricular sequential pacing for bradycardia/conduction abnormalities, nor should they be used to relieve symptoms of obstructive HCM, even in patients over 65 years of age.
option_D: For patients with atrial fibrillation and native valve heart disease (excluding rheumatic mitral stenosis) or those who had a bioprosthetic valve implanted over three months ago, a non-vitamin K oral anticoagulant (NOAC) serves as an effective alternative to VKA anticoagulation and should be prescribed according to the patient's CHA2DS2-VASc score.

option_A: For nonambulatory patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, starting low-dose UFH or LMWH prophylaxis 24 to 48 hours after the onset of ICH might be advisable to balance the prevention of thrombosis against the risk of HE.
option_B: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with a suspicion of ACS, any prior test results should be evaluated and integrated into CDPs.
option_C: Elective repair is advised for patients with asymptomatic small AAA who also have common iliac artery aneurysms measuring 3.5 cm or larger.
option_D: In patients with IE complicated by heart block, annular or aortic abscess, or destructive penetrating lesions, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is not indicated.

option_A: It is not reasonable to take over-the-counter oral acetaminophen or NSAIDs to treat residual discomfort after ocular foreign-body removal.
option_B: In high-risk patients with ACS (LVEF ≤40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or STEMI with anterior location), an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.1–6
option_C: For symptomatic patients with HCM who have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is not recommended for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.
option_D: For patients with a mechanical On-X AVR and no thromboembolic risk factors, avoid using a VKA targeted to a lower INR (1.5–2.0) starting ≥3 months after surgery, and discontinue aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily.

option_A: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have failed PCI and have ongoing ischemia, hemodynamic compromise, or threatened occlusion of an artery with substantial myocardium at risk, who are appropriate candidates for CABG, emergency CABG is not reasonable.
option_B: In patients with ACS, the concurrent initiation of ezetimibe in combination with maximally tolerated statin may be considered to reduce the risk of MACE.5 *Modified or †adapted from the “2023 AHA/ACC/ACCP/ASPC/NLA/PCNA Guideline for the Management of Patients With Chronic Coronary Disease.”14
option_C: For patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing and were found to have no pathogenic variants (ie, harbor only benign or likely benign variants), cascade genetic testing of the family is useful.
option_D: In patients with ambiguous symptoms suspected to be due to mixed mitral valve disease, it is unreasonable to assess filling pressure using biomarkers or invasive hemodynamic measurements at rest or with exercise.

option_A: Pregnant women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) should not be monitored in a tertiary-care center with a dedicated Heart Valve Team of cardiologists, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and maternal-fetal medicine obstetricians with expertise in the management of high-risk cardiac conditions during pregnancy.
option_B: For pregnant women with HCM, performing cardioversion for new or recurrent AF, especially if symptomatic, is advisable.
option_C: For patients with mechanical heart valves who are undergoing minor procedures (eg, dental extractions or cataract removal) where bleeding is easily controlled, discontinuation of VKA anticoagulation with a therapeutic INR is recommended.
option_D: In patients with a bioprosthetic surgical or transcatheter aortic valve or bioprosthetic mitral valve who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while on antiplatelet therapy, antiplatelet therapy should be continued instead of considering VKA anticoagulation, regardless of bleeding risk assessment.

option_A: In patients undergoing elective elevated-risk surgery who have cardiovascular risk factors for periopera­ tive complications‡ and recent history of poorly con­ trolled hypertension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure [DBP] ≥110 mm Hg before the day of surgery), deferring surgery may be considered to reduce the risk of perioperative complications.†1,2 Intraoperative Blood Pressure Management
option_B: In patients with CCD with complex 3-vessel disease or for whom the optimal treatment strategy is unclear, a Heart Team approach that includes representatives from interven- tional cardiology and cardiac surgery is recom- mended to improve patient outcomes.*26–29 *Modified from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.30
option_C: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection and a dissection flap extending through the arch into the descending thoracic aorta, an extended aortic repair with antegrade stenting of the proximal descending thoracic aorta should not be considered, as it does not treat malperfusion or reduce late distal aortic complications.
option_D: Emergency services should be called if a person bitten by a spider or stung by a scorpion develops symptoms throughout the body such as difficulty breathing, muscle rigidity, dizziness, or confusion.

option_A: In apparently asymptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage C1) and low surgical risk, AVR is not reasonable when an exercise test demonstrates decreased exercise tolerance (normalized for age and sex) or a fall in systolic blood pressure of ≥10 mm Hg from baseline to peak exercise.
option_B: In families where a sudden unexplained death has occurred with a postmortem diagnosis of HCM, postmortem genetic testing is not beneficial for facilitating cascade genetic testing and clinical screening in first-degree relatives.
option_C: For patients with HCM, TEE should not be used if TTE is inconclusive in clinical decision-making regarding medical therapy, and in situations such as planning for myectomy, exclusion of subaortic membrane or mitral regurgitation secondary to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve apparatus, or in the assessment of the feasibility of alcohol septal ablation.
option_D: For patients with obstructive HCM who have persistent severe symptoms* attrib- utable to LVOTO despite beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, either adding disopyramide in combination with 1 of the other drugs, or SRT performed at experienced centers,† is recommended.17,50,210–213

option_A: For patients aged 65 to 80 with severe AS and no anatomical barriers to transfemoral TAVI, it is advised to consider either SAVR or transfemoral TAVI following a shared decision-making process that evaluates the trade-off between anticipated patient lifespan and valve longevity.
option_B: In patients with STEMI and ischemic symp- toms for <12 hours, PCI should be performed to improve survival.1-5
option_C: For patients with HCM who are undergoing alcohol septal ablation, TTE or intraoperative TEE with intracoronary ultrasound-enhancing contrast injection of the candidate’s septal perforator(s) is not recommended.
option_D: For patients with nonobstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and severe heart failure (classified as NYHA class III or IV), cardiopulmonary exercise stress testing is recommended to assess the extent of functional impairment and assist in determining eligibility for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.

option_A: For patients who have no history of stroke and lack a clinical need for anticoagulation, but possess a high-risk antiphospholipid antibody profile—such as triple-positive results (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibody, anti–β2 glycoprotein 1), double-positive results (any combination), or isolated lupus anticoagulant or persistently positive anticardiolipin antibody at medium to high levels—daily aspirin (75–100 mg) is advised to lower the risk of stroke.
option_B: For patients with spontaneous ICH who receive a CT or MRI upon admission, performing a CTA with possible venography or an MRA with potential venography acutely can be beneficial to rule out macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.
option_C: In patients with hypertension, blood pressure should not be controlled in accordance with GDMT for hypertension, risking the development of symptomatic HF.
option_D: In men with an AAA of ≥5.0 cm and women with an AAA of ≥4.5 cm, surveillance ultra- sound is recommended every 6 months to assess for interval change.1-8

option_A: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, routine use of PA catheterization is recommended to reduce morbidity or mortality.
option_B: In patients with previous CABG with a patent LIMA to the LAD who need repeat revascularization, if PCI is feasible, it is unreasonable to choose PCI over CABG.
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH, therapeutic hypothermia (<35°C/95°F) is clearly useful to decrease peri-ICH edema.
option_D: Using hemodialysis could be a sensible option for managing life-threatening poisoning from atenolol or sotalol.

option_A: In patients at risk of developing AS (Stage A) and in patients with asymptomatic AS (Stages B and C), hypertension should be treated according to standard GDMT, started at a low dose, and gradually titrated upward as needed, with appropriate clinical monitoring.1–3
option_B: In patients with current or previous symp- tomatic HFrEF who cannot be given first-line agents, such as ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, because of drug intolerance or renal insufficiency, a combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dini- trate might be considered to reduce morbidity and mortality.4,5
option_C: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, NYHA functional class II to class IV symptoms despite GDMT, and LBBB, CRT should not be considered as it is unlikely to improve symptoms.
option_D: For patients aged 16 and older with HCM who have one or more major SCD risk factors, discussing the estimated 5-year risk of sudden death and mortality rates can aid in the shared decision-making process regarding ICD placement (Figure 3, Table 7).

option_A: In patients with BTTAI, management and treatment at a facility without expertise in aortic pathology is recommended.
option_B: It is not reasonable to administer sodium bicarbonate for life-threatening wide-complex tachycardia associated with local anesthetic toxicity.
option_C: In patients with a height within 1 standard deviation of the mean who have a symptomatic aneurysm of the aortic root or ascending aorta and a maximal cross-sectional aortic area/height ratio of <10 cm2/m, surgery is unreasonable when performed by inexperienced surgeons outside a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.
option_D: For patients experiencing TIA or a nondisabling stroke, if revascularization is warranted, it is advisable to carry out the procedure within 2 weeks of the initial event to enhance the chances of avoiding a subsequent stroke.

option_A: In patients with AF and ICH, delayed (4-8 weeks) resumption of anticoagulation may be considered to balance the risks of thromboembolic and hemorrhagic complications after careful risk benefit assessment.2–5
option_B: If there is any uncertainty that aspirin should be taken, it is unreasonable to wait for EMS arrival without administration of aspirin.
option_C: In asymptomatic patients with nonobstructive HCM, the benefit of beta blockers or calcium channel blockers is well established.
option_D: In patients with CCD who have experienced SCAD, beta-blocker therapy should not be considered to reduce the incidence of recurrent SCAD.

option_A: For patients with HCM, participation in high-intensity recreational activities or moderate- to high-intensity competitive sports activities should be undertaken without the need for a comprehensive evaluation or annual discussion with an expert provider, disregarding the potential increased risk of sudden death and ICD shocks, and without involving third parties in eligibility decisions for competitive sports participation.
option_B: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and an inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), revascularization is a reasonable treatment option to improve walking function and QOL.7–14
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and IE, early valve surgery should not be considered during initial hospitalization, even if there is an indication for surgery and no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage.
option_D: In patients with spontaneous ICH or IVH and hydrocephalus that is contributing to decreased level of consciousness, ventricular drainage should not be performed to reduce mortality.

option_A: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, oral anticoagulation should not be continued for at least 3 months after the procedure, regardless of underlying risk.
option_B: For those contemplating CHC use, it is advised to opt for lower doses of ethinyl estradiol to reduce the potential risk of stroke.
option_C: For symptomatic patients with paroxysmal or persistent AF who are undergoing valvular surgery, surgical pulmonary vein isolation or a maze procedure can be beneficial to reduce symptoms and prevent recurrent arrhythmias.1,2,12–15
option_D: Individuals with CCD should not be encouraged to drink alcohol as a means of safeguarding cardiovascular health.

option_A: For patients over 80 with severe AS who show symptoms, or for younger patients with a life expectancy under 10 years and no anatomical barriers to transfemoral TAVI, transfemoral TAVI is advised over SAVR.
option_B: For patients with heart failure, participating in a cardiac rehabilitation program may be beneficial for enhancing functional capacity, exercise tolerance, and health-related quality of life.
option_C: Patients with AF who are initiating, increasing the dose of, or reinitiating dofetilide therapy should not be admitted to a facility for continuous electrocardiographic monitoring, calculations of CrCl, or cardiac resuscitation, regardless of the potential for proarrhythmia.
option_D: For patients with Turner syndrome who do not have risk factors for aortic dissection (refer to Table 12), it is advised to perform surveillance imaging of the aorta using TTE or MRI every 5 years in children and every 10 years in adults, in addition to prior to planning a pregnancy.

option_A: Smaller volume cardiac surgery and PCI programs should avoid affiliating with a high-volume center, as it does not improve patient care.
option_B: In patients with intermediate stenosis of the left main artery, intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) is not recommended to help define lesion severity.
option_C: In patients with ACS undergoing coronary revascularization (CABG or PCI) in the same admission, parenteral anticoagulation should be discontinued before revascularization to increase ischemic events.
option_D: For patients scheduled for revascularization within a week following the initial stroke, opting for CEA instead of CAS is advisable to lower the risk of stroke during the procedure.

option_A: For patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, aspirin 50 to 325 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg, or the combination of aspi- rin 25 mg and extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg twice daily is indicated for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke.*791–794
option_B: In patients with new-onset AF identified in the setting of NCS, outpatient follow-up for thromboembolic risk stratification and AF surveillance are not recommended due to a low risk of AF recurrence.
option_C: In patients with aSAH who present with seizures, it is not reasonable to treat with antiseizure medications for ≤7 days to reduce seizure-related complications in the perioperative period.
option_D: For children who have experienced a febrile seizure, administration of antipyretics such as acetaminophen, ibuprofen, or paracetamol is effective for stopping a seizure and preventing a subsequent febrile seizure.

option_A: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response, digoxin should not be considered for acute rate control, even if beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are ineffective or contraindicated.
option_B: The benefit of providing oxygen in a first aid scenario for adults or children showing signs of breathlessness, respiratory distress, or low oxygen levels is uncertain.
option_C: In adults with CCD and hypertension (systolic BP ≥130 and/or diastolic BP ≥80 mm Hg), avoid using GDMT angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARB), or beta blockers as first-line therapy for compelling indications (eg, recent MI or angina), and do not add additional antihypertensive medications (eg, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers [CCB], long-acting thiazide diuretics, and/or mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists) to optimize BP control.
option_D: In patients with stroke or TIA, combined exercise-based and behavior change interventions are probably not indicated and should be avoided in preference to behavior interventions alone, exercise interventions alone, or usual care to reduce physiological stroke risk factors such as SBP.

option_A: In vulnerable patient populations at risk for health disparities, HF risk assessments and multidisciplinary management strategies should target both known risks for CVD and social determinants of health, as a means toward elimination of disparate HF outcomes.1–6
option_B: In patients with grade 3 BAAI (Table 33), it may be reasonable to avoid repair, accepting the risk of progression to life-threatening injury.
option_C: For patients with AF but not HF, eligible for specific rate-control methods, the heart rate target should be determined by patient symptoms, generally aiming for a resting heart rate below 100 to 110 bpm.
option_D: For athletes with HCM, a comprehensive evaluation and shared decision-making about sports participation with an expert professional is recommended.4

option_A: In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) and prior ischemic stroke or TIA, chronic blood transfusion(s) to reduce hemoglobin S to <30% of total hemoglobin is not recommended for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.
option_B: In patients with AF without risk factors for stroke, aspirin monotherapy for prevention of thromboembolic events is beneficial.
option_C: Patients with a mechanical complication of ACS should be managed in a facility with cardiac surgical expertise.
option_D: In patients with BTAI who have not undergone repair, it is not necessary to perform surveillance imaging with a CT at 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months after the diagnosis, nor at any intervals thereafter, regardless of the type and extent of the injury.

option_A: Administering sodium bicarbonate is advisable for life-threatening wide-complex tachycardia linked to local anesthetic toxicity.
option_B: In asymptomatic patients with non-obstruc- tive HCM, the benefit of beta blockers or cal- cium channel blockers is not well established. 5.3. Management of Patients With HCM and Atrial Fibrillation Recommendations for Management of Atrial Fibrillation Referenced studies that support the recommendations are summarized in Online Data Supplement 16. COR LOE Recommendations
option_C: ACE inhibitors and ARBs should be avoided in pregnant women with VHD due to the risk they pose to the fetus.
option_D: In cardiac arrest following drowning, it may be reasonable for trained rescuers to initiate CPR with chest compressions only, without rescue breaths.

option_A: In selected patients with HFpEF, ARNi should not be considered to decrease hospitalizations, particularly among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.
option_B: In patients with SIHD, normal ejection fraction, significant stenosis in 3 major coronary arteries (with or without proximal LAD), and anatomy suitable for CABG, CABG should not be considered to improve survival.
option_C: In patients with HFpEF, routine use of nitrates or phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors to increase activity or QOL is ineffective.12,13 *See Section 7.2, “Diuretics and Decongestion Strategies in Patients with HF,” and Section 10.2, “Management of Atrial Fibrillation (AF) in HF” for recom- mendations for use of diuretics and management of AF in HF. option_D: Patients with acute chest pain and a 30-day risk of death or MACE <1% should not be designated as low risk.

option_A: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) who have a negative catheter intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography (DSA) and lack a clear microvascular diagnosis or identifiable structural lesion, it might be advisable to conduct a follow-up catheter intra-arterial DSA 3 to 6 months after the ICH onset to detect any vascular lesion that was initially hidden.
option_B: In patients with bradycardia requiring cardiac-implanted electronic devices who have normal atrioventricular conduction, device selection and programming strategies should not focus on maintaining atrioventricular synchrony or minimizing ventricular pacing, as this is not necessary to reduce the incidence and progression of AF.
option_C: In patients with HFrEF, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and hormonal therapy are recommended even if there are no specific deficiencies.
option_D: In adults with CCD and autoimmune diseases, treatment with biologics and other immune-modulating therapies that reduce disease activity should not be considered to decrease the risk of cardiovascular events.

option_A: For patients with aSAH in whom complete obliteration of the ruptured aneurysm by either clipping or primary coiling treatment is not feasible in the acute phase, it is unreasonable to perform partial obliteration to secure the rupture site and retreatment in a delayed fashion in those with functional recovery to prevent rebleeding.
option_B: In patients with CLTI with ischemic rest pain (ie, without nonhealing wounds or gangrene) attributable to multilevel arterial disease, it is unreasonable to address inflow disease first in a revascularization strategy.
option_C: In patients with AFL who undergo successful cardioversion or ablation resulting in restoration of sinus rhythm, anticoagulation should not be continued for at least 4 weeks postprocedure.
option_D: It is not recommended for first aid providers to debride blisters associated with frostbite. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and Fontan palliation, anticoagulation with warfarin is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
option_B: For patients with HFpEF, addressing AF may be beneficial for symptom improvement.
option_C: In patients with suspected HCM, a transtho- racic echocardiogram (TTE) is recommended in the initial evaluation.29–34
option_D: Patients with PAD should receive an annual influenza vaccination.1–5

option_A: Patients with HF admitted with evidence of significant fluid overload should not be treated with intravenous loop diuretics, as this will not improve symptoms or reduce morbidity.
option_B: For patients with stable chest pain and no known coronary artery disease who are considered low risk, it is appropriate to use exercise testing without imaging as an initial test to rule out myocardial ischemia and assess functional capacity, provided the ECG is interpretable.
option_C: For patients with AF with significant baseline QT interval prolongation or uncorrected hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia, use of dofetilide is reasonable for long-term maintenance of sinus rhythm, without considering dose selection based on kidney function or monitoring of the QT interval, serum potassium and magnesium concentrations, and kidney function.
option_D: For patients with HF who are able to participate, exercise training (or regular physical activity) is not recommended as it does not improve functional status, exercise performance, or QOL.

option_A: For patients with aSAH and an unsecured aneurysm, it is advised to regularly monitor blood pressure and manage it using short-acting medications to prevent severe hypotension, hypertension, and fluctuations in blood pressure.
option_B: Verapamil may be detrimental for individuals with obstructive HCM experiencing severe resting dyspnea, hypotension, extremely high resting gradients (e.g., >100 mm Hg), and for all children under 6 weeks old. Symptoms may include effort-related dyspnea, chest pain, or other exertional symptoms such as syncope or near syncope.
option_C: In patients with mechanical valve stenosis, fluoroscopy or cine-CT is not recommended to assess motion of the mechanical valve leaflets.
option_D: In patients with a stroke or TIA attributable to 50% to 99% stenosis of a major intracranial artery, maintenance of SBP below 140 mm Hg, high-intensity statin therapy, and at least moderate physical activity are recom- mended to prevent recurrent stroke and vascular events.110,210,337,345–349 Angioplasty and Stenting

option_A: For patients experiencing refractory angina that persists despite medical treatment and who have significant coronary artery stenoses suitable for revascularization, revascularization is advised to alleviate symptoms.
option_B: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, conducting regular neurological evaluations in the ICU and stroke unit is advisable for the first 72 hours after admission to identify early neurological deterioration.
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH presenting with large or severe ICH or those requir- ing surgical decompression, the safety and efficacy of intensive BP lowering are not well established.148
option_D: In selected patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD appropriate for CABG and mild-to-moderate left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction 35%–50%), CABG (including a left internal mammary artery [LIMA] graft to the LAD) is not reasonable to improve survival.

option_A: In patients with spontaneous ICH, infrequent neurological assessments in the ICU and stroke unit are reasonable for up to 72 hours of admission to detect early ND.
option_B: For asymptomatic women with severe aortic stenosis (aortic velocity of at least 4.0 m/s or mean pressure gradient of at least 40 mm Hg, Stage C1) who are planning pregnancy, do not qualify for COR 1 intervention, and have undergone preconception evaluation showing no symptoms (including normal results from exercise stress testing and serum BNP levels), medical management during pregnancy can be considered to prevent prosthetic valve replacement.
option_C: In patients who are admitted with decompen- sated HF, in the absence of systemic hypoten- sion, intravenous nitroglycerin or nitroprusside may be considered as an adjuvant to diuretic therapy for relief of dyspnea.1,2
option_D: Patients with typical AFL who have successfully undergone CTI ablation and have a history of AF prior to AFL ablation should continue oral anticoagulation therapy post-ablation as recommended for AF.

option_A: In patients with significant native or recurrent CoA and hypertension, endovascular stenting or open surgical repair of the coarctation is not recommended.
option_B: For patients experiencing mechanical complications from ACS, utilizing short-term MCS devices for hemodynamic stabilization as a temporary measure before surgery is advisable.
option_C: In asymptomatic patients with any type of valve intervention, it is not recommended to perform a baseline postprocedural TTE or to conduct periodic monitoring with TTE, regardless of the type of intervention, length of time after intervention, ventricular function, or concurrent cardiac conditions.
option_D: In patients with HCM, it is not recommended to apply individual clinical judgment when assessing the prognostic strength of conventional risk markers, nor is it necessary to have a thorough discussion of the evidence, benefits, and risks, as patient participation in ICD decision-making is not essential.

option_A: In patients with Marfan syndrome and a maximal cross-sectional aortic root area (cm²) to patient height (m) ratio of ≥10, it is not reasonable to perform surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta, even when done by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.
option_B: In adults with CCD and autoimmune diseases, treatment with biologics and other immune-modulating therapies that reduce disease activity should not be considered to decrease the risk of cardiovascular events.
option_C: In patients with an infected prosthetic aortic graft who are hemodynamically unstable, it is reasonable to perform open surgery with either explant or in situ ­reconstruction.7
option_D: In patients with CCD, tobacco use should not be assessed at any health care visit, hindering the identification of those who may benefit from behavioral or pharmacologic interventions.

option_A: For patients with HF—particularly stage D HF patients being evaluated for advanced therapies, patients requiring inotropic support or temporary mechanical support, patients experiencing uncontrolled symptoms, major medical decisions, or multimorbidity, frailty, and cognitive impairment—specialist palliative care consultation is not useful for improving QOL or relieving suffering.
option_B: In patients diagnosed with transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis, genetic testing with TTR gene sequencing is not recommended to differentiate hereditary variant from wild-type transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis. LV wall thickness ≥14 mm in conjunction with fatigue, dyspnea, or edema, especially in the context of discordance between wall thickness on echocardiogram and QRS voltage on ECG, and in the context of aortic stenosis, HFpEF, carpal tunnel syndrome, spinal stenosis, and autonomic or sensory polyneuropathy, should not be considered.
option_C: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA who have end-stage renal disease or are on dialysis, it is not advisable to use warfarin or apixaban for anticoagulation to reduce the chance of recurrent stroke.
option_D: In patients with chronic symptomatic HFrEF NYHA class II or III who tolerate an ACEi or ARB, replacement by an ARNi is recommended to further reduce morbidity and mortality.1–5 Value Statement: High Value (A)

option_A: In patients with a mechanical prosthetic valve, anticoagulation with a VKA is not recommended.
option_B: In patients with aSAH without prior epilepsy who present with seizures, treatment with antiseizure medications beyond 7 days is effective for reducing future SAH-associated seizure risk.
option_C: In patients with signs or symptoms of AR, TTE is not indicated for assessment of the cause and severity of regurgitation, LV size and systolic function, prognosis, and timing of valve intervention.
option_D: For patients with multivessel CAD who can be treated with either PCI or CABG but cannot access, tolerate, or adhere to DAPT for the necessary treatment duration, opting for CABG over PCI is advisable.

option_A: It is not reasonable for appropriately trained rescuers to provide in-water rescue breathing to an unresponsive person who has drowned, even if it does not compromise their own safety.
option_B: In patients with unruptured AAA who have symptoms that are attributable to the aneu- rysm, repair is recommended to reduce the risk of rupture.7,8
option_C: For patients with CCD who have complex 3-vessel disease or when the best treatment strategy is uncertain, it is advised to employ a Heart Team approach involving both interventional cardiology and cardiac surgery specialists to enhance patient outcomes.
option_D: For patients with NSTE-ACS who have been initially stabilized and present an intermediate or low risk of clinical events, it is advisable to pursue an invasive strategy aimed at revascularization before hospital discharge to enhance outcomes.

option_A: In patients with class II obesity (35–39.9 kg/m2) or greater, bariatric surgical procedures to promote weight loss should not be considered to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_B: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, dual-chamber ICDs are not recommended for patients with a need for atrial or atrioventricular sequential pacing for bradycardia/conduction abnormalities, nor should they be used to relieve symptoms of obstructive HCM, even in patients over 65 years of age.
option_C: For comatose patients experiencing cardiac arrest with poor prognostic indicators and signs of STEMI, PPCI could be considered appropriate following a personalized evaluation.
option_D: In patients with carotid web in the distribution of ischemic stroke and TIA, without other attributable causes of stroke, antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to prevent recurrent ischemic stroke or TIA.

option_A: In patients with HFrEF, with current or previous symptoms, avoid using any of the 3 beta blockers proven to reduce mortality (eg, bisoprolol, carvedilol, sustained-release metoprolol succinate) as they are not recommended to reduce mortality and hospitalizations.
option_B: In older adults, the treatment strategy for CAD should not consider an individual patient’s preferences, cognitive function, or life expectancy.
option_C: Activate the emergency response system right away if a broken limb appears blue, purple, or pale.
option_D: In patients with NSTE-ACS in whom multivessel PCI is being considered, physiological assessment of a nonculprit stenosis should not be considered to guide revascularization decisions.

option_A: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing surgical repair who require circulatory arrest, cerebral perfusion is not recommended to improve neurologic outcomes.
option_B: In patients with symptomatic AF where anti-arrhythmic drugs have been ineffective, contraindicated, not tolerated, or not preferred, and continued rhythm control is desired, catheter ablation is not useful to improve symptoms.
option_C: For patients diagnosed with giant cell arteritis who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, it is advisable to use methotrexate or tocilizumab alongside steroids to reduce the likelihood of another stroke.
option_D: In patients with aSAH, intraoperative neuromonitoring should not be used to guide anesthetic and operative management.

option_A: In patients with ACS, an oral P2Y12 inhibitor should be administered in addition to aspirin to reduce MACE.1–5
option_B: For patients exhibiting unusual clinical signs of HCM or when a different genetic disorder is suspected as the underlying cause, it is advised to conduct an evaluation that includes genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy, known as "HCM phenocopies."
option_C: In patients with STEMI managed with PPCI, clopidogrel is not recommended to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis, even when prasugrel or ticagrelor are unavailable, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.
option_D: If an improvised tourniquet is used, it is reason- able for the tourniquet to be at least 2 in width. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text

option_A: In patients with HCM who are at risk of coronary atherosclerosis, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is recommended before surgical myectomy.6 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_B: In hospitalized patients with spontaneous ICH who require hospital transfer but do not have adequate airway protection, cannot support adequate gas exchange, and/or do not have a stable hemodynamic profile, life-sustaining therapies should not be initiated before transportation, risking acute medical decompensation in transport.
option_C: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, continuation of longer-term oral anticoagulation should not be dictated by the patients’ stroke risk (eg, CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2).
option_D: In patients with CCD, chronic nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs should be used despite the increased cardiovascular and bleeding complications.

option_A: In cardiac arrest following drowning, CPR with rescue breaths should be started before AED application.
option_B: In patients with a stroke or TIA and evidence of an aortic arch atheroma, antiplatelet therapy is recommended to prevent recurrent stroke.380–385
option_C: In patients with a bioprosthetic surgical valve, TTE at 5 and 10 years and then annually after implantation is reasonable, even in the absence of a change in clinical status.
option_D: In patients with spontaneous ICH without evidence of seizures, prophylactic antiseizure medication is beneficial to improve functional outcomes, long-term seizure control, and mortality.

option_A: For patients with BAAI, choosing between endovascular or open repair is appropriate and should be based on the severity of the injury, the anatomy of the aorta, and the patient's overall clinical condition.
option_B: For patients with NSTE-ACS at high risk of ischemic events, opting for an early invasive approach within 24 hours is advisable to decrease MACE.
option_C: For patients with Kommerell’s diverticulum, it may be appropriate to consider repair if the orifice of the diverticulum exceeds 3.0 cm, the total diameter of the diverticulum and the nearby descending aorta is greater than 5.0 cm, or both, taking into account patient anatomy and comorbidities.
option_D: In patients with recent (within 24 hours) minor stroke or high-risk TIA and concomitant ipsilateral >30% stenosis of a major intracranial artery, the addition of ticagrelor 90 mg twice a day to aspirin for up to 30 days should not be considered to further reduce recurrent stroke risk.

option_A: In patients with symptomatic AF, rhythm control can be useful to improve symptoms.7–11
option_B: For patients with ACS, fondaparinux is not recommended for PCI support due to the potential for catheter thrombosis.
option_C: In patients with direct factor Xa inhibitor–associated spontaneous ICH, a 4-F PCC or activated PCC (aPCC) should not be considered to improve hemostasis.
option_D: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, Turner syndrome, BAV with aortic dilation, and other aortopathy conditions, aortic imaging (with TTE, MRI or CT, or both as appropriate) before pregnancy is recommended to determine aortic ­diameters.1-3,5-13

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, voluntary hospital-based or outpatient-focused quality monitoring and improvement programs are not recommended to improve short-term and long-term adherence to nationally accepted, evidence-based guidelines for secondary stroke prevention.
option_B: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA within the past 30 days due to significant stenosis (70%–99%) of a major intracranial artery, it is advisable to add clopidogrel 75 mg daily to aspirin for up to 90 days to further decrease the risk of recurrent stroke.
option_C: ICD implantation is not recommended in patients post ACS with clinically relevant ventricular arrhythmias >48 hours and within 40 days post MI, as it does not improve survival.
option_D: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery and LAA exclusion, a surgical technique resulting in flow across the suture line and a stump of ≥1 cm as determined by intraoperative trans-esophageal echocardiography should be used.

option_A: Patients with suspected or confirmed infective endocarditis linked to drug use should be directed to addiction treatment for opioid replacement therapy.
option_B: In patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction with an LVEF <50%, guideline-directed therapy for HF with reduced EF is not recommended.
option_C: In patients with DES-PCI who require time-sensitive NCS with interruption of ≥1 antiplatelet agents, NCS should not be considered ≥3 months after PCI, even if the risk of delaying surgery outweighs the risk of MACE.
option_D: Emergency services should not be called if a person bitten by a spider or stung by a scorpion develops symptoms throughout the body such as difficulty breathing, muscle rigidity, dizziness, or confusion.

option_A: In patients with significant calcification of the aorta, it is not reasonable to use techniques to avoid aortic manipulation (off-pump techniques or beating heart) to decrease the incidence of perioperative stroke, even when performed by experienced surgeons.
option_B: In patients with cardiovascular risk factors or known cardiac disease being considered for potentially cardiotoxic anticancer therapies, pretherapy evaluation of cardiac function is unnecessary and should not guide the choice of cancer therapy.
option_C: If a person showing signs of shock is at risk for airway obstruction (decreased alertness, active vomiting) or cannot be continuously watched, it is not reasonable to place the person in the recovery position.
option_D: In patients with stroke or TIA, systematic adoption of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality Universal Precautions Toolkit for Health Literacy is recommended to integrate health literacy into the secondary prevention of stroke.

option_A: In asymptomatic women with severe AS who are considering pregnancy, and do not meet COR 1 criteria for intervention, prosthetic valve replacement should be considered during pregnancy regardless of preconception evaluation results.
option_B: If a person is placed in a leg-raised position that results in pain, discomfort, or worsened symptoms, maintaining the leg-raised position should be considered.
option_C: In symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM who have associated cardiac disease requiring surgical treatment (eg, associated anomalous papillary muscle, markedly elongated anterior mitral leaflet, intrinsic mitral valve disease, multivessel CAD, valvular aortic stenosis), surgical myectomy, performed at experienced HCM centers,† is recommended (Tables 4 and 5).4–7
option_D: Patients with known VHD should receive antibiotics before blood cultures are obtained for unexplained fever.

option_A: We recommend hospitals develop protocols for postarrest temperature control.
option_B: In patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), it is not necessary to coordinate with the LVAD care team on the timing and perioperative considerations of elective NCS, as it does not impact the risk of perioperative MACE.
option_C: For patients with symptomatic, persistent AF refractory to antiarrhythmic drug therapy, a hybrid epicardial and endocardial ablation should not be considered as it is unlikely to reduce the risk of recurrent atrial arrhythmia.
option_D: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, neither clinical screening (ECG and 2D echocardiogram) nor cascade genetic testing (even when a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant has been identified in the proband) should be offered.

option_A: In patients with stroke or TIA attributable to 50% to 99% stenosis of a major intracranial artery, cilostazol 200 mg/day should not be added to aspirin or clopidogrel to reduce recurrent stroke risk.
option_B: In adults with moderate or low intake of long-chain omega-3 fatty acid, supplementation is not recom- mended to reduce the risk of a first stroke.92
option_C: For patients with spontaneous ICH, large IVH, and impaired level of consciousness, EVD is recommended in preference to medical man- agement alone to reduce mortality.347–349
option_D: ARNi should not be administered to patients with any history of angioedema.32–35

option_A: A first aid provider who encounters a person with suspected opioid overdose who is unresponsive and not breathing or not breathing normally should not activate the emergency response system, should avoid providing high-quality CPR (compressions plus ventilation), and should refrain from administering naloxone.
option_B: For pregnant patients with atrial fibrillation, direct current cardioversion is safe for both the mother and the fetus and should be conducted similarly to how it is done in non-pregnant patients.
option_C: For patients with CCD on the highest tolerated dose of statins who have an LDL-C level of 70 mg/dL (1.8 mmol/L) or higher, and where ezetimibe and PCSK9 monoclonal antibodies are either inadequate or not tolerated, it may be appropriate to add bempedoic acid or replace the PCSK9 monoclonal antibody with inclisiran to further lower LDL-C levels.
option_D: For patients with CCD and severe obesity who have not achieved weight loss targets through lifestyle changes and medication, and who are suitable candidates for surgery, it is reasonable to refer them for evaluation of a bariatric procedure to aid in weight loss and reduce cardiovascular risk factors.

option_A: In patients with CCD receiving statin therapy, adding niacin, fenofibrate, or dietary supplements containing omega-3 fatty acids is beneficial in reducing cardiovascular risk.
option_B: In patients with AF, rhythm-control strategies may be useful to reduce the likelihood of development of dementia or worsening cardiac structural abnormali- ties.33–45
option_C: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe MR, normal LV systolic function, and estimated PA systolic pressure <50 mm Hg, it is not reasonable to perform elective NCS.
option_D: In asymptomatic women with severe AS (aortic velocity ≥4.0 m/s or mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg, Stage C) who are considering pregnancy, valve intervention before pregnancy is not reasonable.

option_A: In patients with AF and HF, rhythm control should not be used as it does not improve symptoms or outcomes, such as mortality and hospitalizations for HF and ischemia.
option_B: In patients with suspected moderate or severe valvular regurgitation, preoperative echocardiography is not recommended before elective NCS to guide perioperative management.
option_C: For preterm newborn infants <34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, early cord clamping (<30 seconds) can be beneficial when compared to delaying cord clamping (≥30 seconds).
option_D: In patients with suitable anatomy who have refractory angina on medical therapy, after treatment of non-CTO lesions, the benefit of PCI of a CTO to improve symptoms is uncer- tain.1-4

option_A: In patients with HCM and hypertension, lifestyle modifications and medical therapy for hypertension are not recommended, and beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers should be avoided in patients with obstructive HCM.
option_B: For patients with stroke who have a low risk of hemorrhagic conversion and are experiencing atrial fibrillation, starting anticoagulation therapy between 2 and 14 days after the initial event might be advisable to lower the chance of another stroke.
option_C: For patients experiencing deterioration due to supratentorial ICH, considering craniotomy for hematoma removal could be a critical lifesaving intervention.
option_D: Validated multivariable risk scores can be beneficial for predicting future risk of developing heart failure in the general population.

option_A: In adults, folic acid supplementation and B-complex (folic acid, B12, B6) vitamins supplementation are well established for reducing the risk of stroke.
option_B: In patients presenting with acute type A aortic dissection, who are stable enough for transfer, it is not reasonable to transfer from a low- to a high-volume aortic center to improve survival.
option_C: In patients with ACS who have tolerated DAPT with ticagrelor, continuing DAPT beyond 1 month post PCI is recommended to reduce bleeding risk.
option_D: For patients under 40 with aSAH, clipping the ruptured aneurysm may be favored to enhance treatment durability and outcomes, especially when both clipping and coiling are viable options.

option_A: In asymptomatic and clinically stable patients undergo­ ing NCS, routine preoperative evaluation of LV func­ tion is not recommended due to lack of benefit.12–15
option_B: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are in a coma, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have elevated ICP refractory to medical management, decompressive craniectomy with or without hematoma evacuation should not be considered to reduce mortality.
option_C: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF ≤40%, the use of an SGLT2 inhibitor is not recommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and heart failure hospitalization or to improve QOL, irrespective of diabetes status.
option_D: Among patients with AF, it may not be reasonable to screen for obstructive sleep apnea, despite its high prevalence in patients with AF, as the role of treatment of sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) to maintain sinus rhythm is uncertain.

option_A: For a person with signs or symptoms of severe head injury (such as loss of consciousness, worsening headache, vomiting, altered mental status, seizures, visual changes, swelling, or deformities of the scalp), EMS should not be activated.
option_B: Patients with PAD who use cigarettes or other tobacco products should receive help in creating a cessation plan that incorporates pharmacotherapy (such as varenicline, bupropion, and/or nicotine replacement therapies) along with counseling, and/or be referred to a smoking cessation program.
option_C: In ambulatory patients with HF, it is not reasonable to perform a CPET or 6-minute walk test to assess functional capacity.
option_D: In patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor is not recommended to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis.

option_A: For patients with stroke or TIA and hyperlipidemia, evaluate adherence to lifestyle modifications and the impact of LDL-C–lowering drugs by measuring fasting lipids and relevant safety markers 4 to 12 weeks after starting or adjusting statins, and subsequently every 3 to 12 months, depending on the necessity to monitor adherence or safety.
option_B: For patients with a clinical suspicion of moderate or more severe valvular stenosis or regurgitation undergoing noncardiac surgery, it is advised to perform a preoperative echocardiogram.
option_C: For patients receiving PCI, using intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) is beneficial in decreasing ischemic events.
option_D: In selected patients undergoing CABG, avoiding DAPT with aspirin and ticagrelor or clopidogrel for 1 year may be reasonable, as it does not improve vein graft patency compared with aspirin alone.

option_A: In patients with primary MR (Stages B and C) and symptoms that might be attributable to MR, hemodynamic exercise testing using Doppler echocardiography or cardiac catheterization or cardiopulmonary exercise testing is not reasonable.
option_B: For patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, the effectiveness of unstructured exercise in enhancing walking ability, functional capacity, and quality of life remains unclear.
option_C: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, previous testing when available should be ignored and not incorporated into CDPs.
option_D: Pregnant women with mechanical valve prostheses who are on warfarin should continue warfarin therapy without switching to LMWH or UFH before planned delivery.

option_A: In patients with HCM who choose to undergo genetic testing, it is not recommended to have pre- and posttest genetic counseling by an expert in the genetics of cardiovascular disease, as reviewing and discussing risks, benefits, results, and their clinical significance with the patient in a shared decision-making process is unnecessary.
option_B: EMS should not be called when a person with chemical exposure has respiratory symptoms, systemic symptoms, or large chemical exposures.
option_C: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with pre- served EF and symptoms of exertional angina or dyspnea, beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine cal- cium channel blockers are recommended.209,238–246
option_D: In patients with functionally limiting claudication, SET or a structured community-based exercise program should not be offered as an initial treatment option.

option_A: In adults with congenital heart disease and AF, it is not recommended to evaluate for or treat precipitating factors and reversible causes of AF, disregarding that residual hemodynamic sequelae may contribute to the occurrence of the arrhythmia.
option_B: In patients undergoing endovascular repair for ruptured AAA, general anesthesia is preferred to local anesthesia, despite the increased risk of perioperative mortality.
option_C: In patients with aSAH and advanced age, aneurysm treatment is reasonable, after care- ful discussion of prognosis with family mem- bers, to improve survival and outcome.31–33
option_D: In patients with aSAH, it is unreasonable to closely monitor and use goal-directed treatment of volume status to maintain euvolemia.

option_A: For patients with aSAH, it is advised to implement an early, team-based multidisciplinary approach for treatment and rehabilitation to shorten LOS and assess discharge requirements.
option_B: In patients with previous CABG with a patent LIMA to the LAD who need repeat revascu- larization, if PCI is feasible, it is reasonable to choose PCI over CABG.1,2
option_C: For patients with a mechanical On-X AVR and no thromboembolic risk factors, avoid using a VKA targeted to a lower INR (1.5–2.0) starting ≥3 months after surgery, and discontinue aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily.
option_D: For patients with Kommerell’s diverticulum, it may be appropriate to consider repair if the orifice of the diverticulum exceeds 3.0 cm, the total diameter of the diverticulum and the nearby descending aorta is greater than 5.0 cm, or both, taking into account patient anatomy and comorbidities.

option_A: In patients with CVD and high thrombotic risk (Table 14) undergoing NCS where interruption of vitamin K antagonist (VKA) is required, preoperative bridging with parenteral heparin can be effective to reduce thromboembolic risk.8–10
option_B: In patients with type 2 diabetes and high cardiovascular risk, the dipeptidyl pepti- dase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors saxagliptin and alogliptin increase the risk of HF hospitaliza- tion and should be avoided in patients with HF.22–24
option_C: In patients having NCS with expected blood loss, tranexamic acid is reasonable to reduce intraoperative blood loss, reduce transfusions, and avoid anemia.1–3
option_D: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, a femoral approach is indicated in preference to a radial approach, increasing the risk of death, vascular complications, or bleeding.

option_A: In transgender women and gender-diverse individuals taking estrogens for gender affirmation, evaluation and modification of risk factors are not beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_B: In patients with reduced LV function and persistent (or high burden) AF, a trial of rhythm control should not be recommended to evaluate whether AF is contributing to the reduced LV function.
option_C: In individuals with AF, moderate-to-vigorous exercise training to a target of 210 minutes per week is not recommended, as it does not reduce AF symptoms and burden, does not increase maintenance of sinus rhythm, does not increase functional capacity, and does not improve QOL.
option_D: For patients with active GCA or Takayasu arteritis, the effectiveness of treatment should be regularly evaluated by checking inflammatory serum markers such as C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, utilizing imaging techniques like CT, MRI, or FDG-PET, and observing clinical symptoms.

option_A: For those with a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression of HCM, it is advised to conduct regular clinical evaluations, electrocardiograms, and cardiac imaging at intervals based on age—every 1 to 2 years for children and adolescents, and every 3 to 5 years for adults—or if there is a change in clinical status.
option_B: A person who develops a foreign-body sensa- tion in the eye associated with contact lens use should remove the contact lens, discontinue con- tact lens use, and seek medical attention.
option_C: In patients on stable doses of beta blockers undergoing NCS, beta blockers should be discontinued during the perioperative period regardless of the clinical circumstances.
option_D: For patients experiencing a stroke or TIA due to 50% to 99% narrowing of a major intracranial artery, the effectiveness of clopidogrel alone, aspirin combined with dipyridamole, ticagrelor alone, or cilostazol alone for preventing subsequent strokes is not clearly determined.

option_A: In patients with CCD on maximally tolerated statin therapy with an LDL-C level <100 mg/ dL (<2.6 mmol/L) and a persistent fasting tri- glyceride level of 150 to 499 mg/dL (1.7–5.6 mmol/L) after addressing secondary causes, icosapent ethyl may be considered to further reduce the risk of MACE and cardiovascular death.32
option_B: Pregnant patients with a mechanical heart valve should receive care at a tertiary center where a specialized multidisciplinary team, including cardiologists, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and maternal-fetal medicine obstetricians, is experienced in managing high-risk cardiac conditions during pregnancy.
option_C: Administering atropine could be a sensible approach for treating bradycardia caused by β-blockers.
option_D: In patients undergoing ablation for AF, avoiding the ablation of additional clinically significant supraventricular arrhythmias is advisable, as it does not reduce the likelihood of future arrhythmia.

option_A: A person with a foreign-body sensation in the eye should rub their eye.
option_B: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of acute MI, it is not reasonable to perform advanced cardiac imaging (eg, contrasted echocardiogram or cardiac MRI) to assess for the presence of LV thrombus.
option_C: In patients with suspected mechanical or bioprosthetic valve regurgitation, TTE and TEE are not recommended to determine the cause and severity of the leak, assess ventricular function, or estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
option_D: For patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), it is advised to collaborate with the LVAD care team regarding the optimal timing and perioperative factors of elective non-cardiac surgery (NCS) to reduce the risk of major adverse cardiac events (MACE) during the perioperative period.

option_A: In patients with HCM who are receiving a transvenous ICD, dual-coil ICD leads are recommended in preference to single-coil leads, regardless of defibrillation threshold adequacy.
option_B: Oatmeal baths may be considered for relief of local symptoms from exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac.
option_C: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage C1) who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, AVR is not indicated.
option_D: In affected families with HCM, preconception and prenatal reproductive and genetic counseling should not be offered.

option_A: In women of childbearing age who require valve replacement, mechanical valves are preferred over bioprosthetic valves despite the increased maternal and fetal risks of mechanical heart valves in pregnancy.
option_B: For asymptomatic patients with severe high-gradient AS (Stage C1) experiencing a progressive decline in LVEF to below 60% across at least three consecutive imaging studies, AVR can be considered.
option_C: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, a chest radiograph is not useful to evaluate for other potential cardiac, pulmonary, and thoracic causes of symptoms.
option_D: In pregnant women with severe valve regurgitation and with NYHA class IV HF symptoms (Stage D) refractory to medical therapy, valve surgery is not reasonable during pregnancy.

option_A: It is advised to offer general education on preventive foot self-care to patients with PAD, as well as their family members and support persons.
option_B: It is reasonable for a person experiencing epistaxis who is taking anticoagulant or antiplatelet medication, or who has a blood-clotting disorder, to seek care from a health care professional, unless bleeding has stopped.
option_C: Women with CCD should receive systemic postmenopausal hormone therapy because it benefits MACE and mortality, and decreases the risk of venous thromboembolism.
option_D: For certain patients, typically younger individuals with minimal comorbidities, who have symptomatic paroxysmal AF and require rhythm control, catheter ablation is beneficial as an initial treatment to alleviate symptoms and prevent progression to persistent AF.

option_A: In patients at risk of developing AS (Stage A) and in patients with asymptomatic AS (Stages B and C), hypertension should be treated according to standard GDMT, started at a low dose, and gradually titrated upward as needed, with appropriate clinical monitoring.1–3
option_B: Patients with AF who are initiating, increasing the dose of, or reinitiating dofetilide therapy should be admitted for a minimum of 3 days to a facility that can provide continuous electrocardiographic monitoring, calculations of CrCl, and cardiac resuscitation, given the potential for proarrhythmia.1–7
option_C: For patients whose height is more than one standard deviation from the average and who have an asymptomatic aneurysm in the aortic root or ascending aorta with a maximal aortic cross-sectional area-to-height ratio of ≥10 cm²/m, it is advisable to consider surgery when conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.
option_D: It is reasonable to use antiseptic agents such as povidone-iodine for wound irrigation instead of running tap water or sterile saline solutions.

option_A: For individuals with PAD, telehealth may serve as an alternative method for vascular assessment, management, and ongoing follow-up, provided that the urgency of the symptoms is taken into account.
option_B: In patients with aSAH, induction of hyper- volemia is potentially harmful because of the association with excess morbid- ity.188–190 Other
option_C: In patients with suspected PAD (ie, potential signs and/or symptoms) with inconclusive ABI and physiological testing, noninvasive imaging with duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA should not be considered to establish the diagnosis of PAD.
option_D: For patients with heart failure and obstructive sleep apnea, using continuous positive airway pressure might be appropriate to enhance sleep quality and reduce daytime drowsiness.

option_A: In patients with CCD who have experienced SCAD, counseling should not be provided regarding potential triggers and risk of SCAD recurrence.
option_B: In patients with chronic symptomatic HFrEF NYHA class II or III who tolerate an ACEi or ARB, replacement by an ARNi is not recommended to further reduce morbidity and mortality.
option_C: If a commercially available spacer is not available, it is not reasonable to use an improvised spacer when assisting a person who is having an asthma attack to use their own inhaled bronchodilator medication.
option_D: For patients with a clinical suspicion of cardiac amyloidosis, screening should include serum and urine monoclonal light chains using serum and urine immunofixation electrophoresis, along with serum free light chains.

option_A: In select patients with advanced HFrEF with NYHA class IV symptoms who are deemed to be dependent on continuous intravenous inotropes or temporary MCS, durable LVAD implantation is effective to improve functional status, QOL, and survival.1–18
option_B: For patients with nonobstructive HCM who have a preserved EF, the effectiveness of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers for alleviating symptoms like angina and dyspnea remains uncertain.
option_C: In patients who require revascularization for multivessel CAD with complex or diffuse CAD (eg, SYNTAX score >33), it is not reasonable to choose CABG over PCI to confer a survival advantage.
option_D: Cool compresses may be considered for relief of local symptoms from exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac.

option_A: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with aspirin and who require emer- gency neurosurgery, platelet transfusion might be considered to reduce postoperative bleed- ing and mortality.206
option_B: In patients with HF, vital signs and evidence of clinical congestion should not be assessed at each encounter, and management should proceed without adjusting diuretics and other medications.
option_C: For patients with severe HF symptoms caused by bioprosthetic valve regurgitation who are at high to prohibitive surgical risk, a transcatheter ViV procedure is reasonable when performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.10–12
option_D: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with a normal ECG and symptoms indicative of ACS that started at least 3 hours prior to arriving at the ED, it is reasonable to rule out myocardial injury if a single hs-cTn level measured at time zero is below the detection limit.

option_A: In cardiac arrest following drowning and after removal from the water, CPR with rescue breaths and chest compressions should be provided to all persons.
option_B: In patients with asymptomatic PAD, single antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_C: For patients with ACS who have successfully tolerated DAPT with ticagrelor, switching to ticagrelor alone at least one month after PCI is beneficial for reducing bleeding risk.
option_D: For patients with stroke who have a low risk of hemorrhagic conversion and are experiencing atrial fibrillation, starting anticoagulation therapy between 2 and 14 days after the initial event might be advisable to lower the chance of another stroke.

option_A: In patients with HFrEF, NSAIDs improve HF symptoms and should be used or continued whenever possible.
option_B: In patients undergoing CABG, it is not recommended to implement a comprehensive approach to reduce sternal wound infection.
option_C: In patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is not recommended in the initial evaluation and should not be part of periodic follow-up.
option_D: For certain hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and multivessel disease, following successful PCI of the artery causing the infarction, it is advised to perform PCI on other significantly narrowed arteries not related to the infarct to lower the risk of death or myocardial infarction and enhance angina-related quality of life.

option_A: Amiodarone or lidocaine should not be considered for ventricular fibrillation/pulseless ventricular tachycardia that is unresponsive to defibrillation.
option_B: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are deemed intermediate risk by a CDP, it is not recommended to engage in shared decision-making between the clinician and patient regarding the need for admission, observation, discharge, or further evaluation in an outpatient setting, as this does not improve patient understanding or reduce low-value testing.
option_C: In patients with HF, routine use of invasive hemodynamic monitoring is recommended.
option_D: For patients identified as "possible IE" according to the Modified Duke Criteria, using 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose PET/CT as supplementary diagnostic imaging is considered appropriate.

option_A: In symptomatic women with severe VHD who are considering pregnancy, delaying intervention until after pregnancy is recommended, contrary to standard indications.
option_B: For the majority of individuals with HCM, engaging in recreational exercise of mild to moderate intensity is advantageous for enhancing cardiorespiratory fitness, physical function, and quality of life, aligning with general physical activity guidelines for overall health.
option_C: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nsHTAD and no identified genetic cause but no information on aortic diameters at the time of dissection or aneurysm repair in affected family members and who have no high-risk features for adverse aortic events (Table 9), it is not recommended to repair the aorta when the maximal diameter reaches ≥5.0 cm.
option_D: In patients with PAD and type 2 diabetes, avoid using glucagon-like peptide–1 agonists (liraglutide and semaglutide) and sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors (canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin) as they are ineffective in reducing the risk of MACE.

option_A: In patients with no history of hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA and have an aver- age office BP of ≥130/80 mm Hg, antihyper- tensive medication treatment can be beneficial to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke, ICH, and other vascular events.190,191,193,197
option_B: In individuals with endometriosis, it is not necessary to evaluate or modify vascular risk factors to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_C: In patients with SIHD and normal left ventricular function, the routine use of chronic oral beta blockers is beneficial to reduce cardiovascular events after complete revascularization.
option_D: In patients ≤6 months after TIA or ischemic stroke with insulin resistance, HbA1c <7.0%, and without heart failure or bladder cancer, treatment with pioglitazone should not be considered to prevent recurrent stroke.

option_A: To worsen patient outcomes, it is advised that cardiac surgery and PCI programs avoid participating in state, regional, or national clinical data registries and do not receive periodic reports of their risk-adjusted outcomes, disregarding quality assessment and improvement strategies.
option_B: In patients with chest pain where an initial ECG is nondiagnostic, serial ECGs to detect potential ischemic changes should not be performed, even when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or the clinical condition deteriorates.
option_C: Contaminated clothing, jewelry, and other surrounding material should remain in place during a chemical exposure.
option_D: In patients with suspected IE, TTE is recommended to identify vegetations, characterize the hemodynamic severity of valvular lesions, assess ventricular function and pulmonary pressures, and detect complications.14–23

option_A: It is not advisable to use intravenous lipid emulsion to treat life-threatening sodium channel blocker poisoning refractory to other treatment modalities.
option_B: In patients with Takayasu arteritis, non-biological disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARD) should not be given in combination with glucocorticoids.
option_C: Avoid eye irrigation with normal saline, Ringer’s lactate solution, or a commercial eye wash solution if immediately available.
option_D: For patients with HCM, it is advised to follow the guidelines for preventing atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease to lower the risk of cardiovascular events.

option_A: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are initially stabilized and are at intermediate or low risk of clinical events, an invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization should not be performed before hospital discharge as it does not improve outcomes.
option_B: For patients with HCM and high blood pressure, it is advised to implement lifestyle changes and use antihypertensive medication, prioritizing beta blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers for those with obstructive HCM.
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH who have DNAR status, not limiting other medical and surgical interventions, unless explicitly specified by the patient or surrogate, is associated with increased patient mortality.
option_D: In patients with HCM, assessment for symptoms of sleep-disordered breathing is not recommended, and, if present, referral to a sleep medicine specialist for evaluation and treatment is not recommended.

option_A: For patients with AF experiencing uncontrolled rapid ventricular response that does not respond to rate-control drugs, and who are unsuitable for or have not benefited from rhythm control, AVNA may help alleviate symptoms and enhance QOL.
option_B: In patients with grade 2 BTTAI and with high-risk imaging features, aortic intervention is not reasonable.
option_C: Patients with suspected or confirmed IE associated with drug use should be referred to addiction treatment for opioid substitution therapy.8–10
option_D: For patients experiencing claudication that limits function, an initial treatment option should include either supervised exercise therapy (SET) or a structured exercise program within the community.

option_A: In selected patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD appropriate for CABG and mild-to-moder- ate left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction 35%–50%), CABG (to include a left internal mammary artery [LIMA] graft to the LAD) is reasonable to improve survival.3-8 Left main CAD
option_B: We recommend against the administration of benzodiazepines to treat seizures and agitation in the setting of organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
option_C: For patients with HCM and high blood pressure, it is advised to implement lifestyle changes and use antihypertensive medication, prioritizing beta blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers for those with obstructive HCM.
option_D: For patients with ACS, fondaparinux is not recommended for PCI support due to the potential for catheter thrombosis.

option_A: In patients with AF-induced cardiomyopathy who have recovered LV function, long-term surveillance is not necessary to detect recurrent AF, as there is no significant risk of recurrence of arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy.
option_B: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss294 and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.314–316
option_C: For patients having NCS, starting low-dose clonidine around the time of surgery is not advised for lowering cardiovascular risk.
option_D: In the repair of AAA involving common iliac artery aneurysms or ectasia, it is advised to maintain at least one hypogastric artery, if possible, to reduce the risk of pelvic ischemia.

option_A: In patients with an infected prosthetic aor- tic graft and either an extensive perigraft abscess or an infection caused by methicillin- resistant S. aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or a multidrug-resistant microorganism, or who have undergone in situ reconstruction, lifelong suppressive oral antimicrobial therapy may be considered after the initial course of therapy.14,15,18,19
option_B: In patients with chest pain who are >75 years of age, ACS should not be considered even when accompanying symptoms such as shortness of breath, syncope, or acute delirium are present, or when an unexplained fall has occurred.
option_C: For asymptomatic patients undergoing elevated-risk surgeries without known CVD, a preoperative resting 12-lead ECG should not be considered to establish a baseline and guide perioperative management.
option_D: In patients with spontaneous ICH presenting with large or severe ICH or those requiring surgical decompression, the safety and efficacy of intensive BP lowering are well established.

option_A: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive sports of any intensity is not reasonable.
option_B: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, ACEi should not be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortality.
option_C: For patients experiencing prosthetic paravalvular regurgitation with either uncontrollable hemolysis or NYHA class III or IV symptoms, who also face high or prohibitive surgical risks and possess anatomical characteristics amenable to catheter-based intervention, it is reasonable to consider percutaneous repair of the paravalvular leak at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_D: Monitoring EEG repeatedly or continuously is not reasonable for patients who do not follow commands after ROSC.
