option_A: For patients who have LVEF ≤30%, ischemic cause of HF, sinus rhythm, LBBB with a QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class I symptoms on GDMT, CRT should not be considered as it will not reduce hospitalizations, improve symptoms, or enhance QOL.
option_B: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are deemed intermediate risk by a CDP, it is not recommended to engage in shared decision-making between the clinician and patient regarding the need for admission, observation, discharge, or further evaluation in an outpatient setting, as this does not improve patient understanding or reduce low-value testing.
option_C: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA, with moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, who are able to maintain a therapeutic INR level with warfarin, use of dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, or edoxaban is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.
option_D: Pregnant women with a mechanical prosthetic valve who have prosthetic valve obstruction or experience an embolic event should undergo a TEE.7–9

option_A: For symptomatic patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain with CCTA-defined ≥50% stenosis in the left main coronary artery, obstructive CAD with FFR with CT ≤0.80, or severe stenosis (≥70%) in all 3 main vessels, ICA is not effective for guiding therapeutic decision-making.
option_B: For patients with HCM who are not otherwise identified as high risk for SCD, or in whom a deci- sion to proceed with ICD remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal or family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory electrocar- diographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial replacement fibrosis with late gadolinium enhancement (LGE).1–15
option_C: In patients undergoing coronary angiography or revascularization, adequate information about benefits, risks, therapeutic conse- quences, and potential alternatives in the performance of percutaneous and surgi- cal myocardial revascularization should be given, when feasible, with sufficient time for informed decision-making to improve clinical outcomes.3-5
option_D: For patients with obesity and atrial fibrillation, applying manual pressure or increasing the electrical energy may enhance the success rate of electrical cardioversion.

option_A: In patients with TIA or nondisabling stroke, engagement in targeted secondary prevention programs (eg, cardiac rehabilitation programs or exercise and lifestyle counseling programs) is not beneficial for reducing risk factors and recurrent ischemic events.
option_B: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain after an inconclusive or abnormal exercise ECG or stress imaging study, CCTA is not reasonable.
option_C: For patients with aSAH, having nurses with specialized stroke skills and certification can effectively improve outcomes, ensure timely care, and maintain adherence to stroke protocols.
option_D: In patients with AF and HF, digoxin should not be used for rate control, either in combination with other rate-controlling agents or as monotherapy if other agents are not tolerated.

option_A: Patients with ALI should not be evaluated on an emergency basis by a clinician with sufficient experience to assess limb viability and implement appropriate therapy.
option_B: For symptomatic patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain with CCTA-defined ≥50% stenosis in the left main coronary artery, obstructive CAD with FFR with CT ≤0.80, or severe stenosis (≥70%) in all 3 main vessels, ICA is not effective for guiding therapeutic decision-making.
option_C: In patients with GCA or Takayasu arteritis who are in remission, elective endovascular or open surgical intervention is not reasonable to treat aortic and branch vessel complications.
option_D: In patients with severe† PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, invasive hemodynamic monitoring is reasonable to guide intraoperative and postoperative care.3–5 Table 9.  Preoperative and Intraoperative Management Considerations in Patients With Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Management Considerations Continue beta blockers and/or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers without interruption in the perioperative period Avoid hypovolemia and reduced preload (can worsen LVOT obstruction) Avoid hypotension and reduced afterload (can worsen LVOT obstruction) Avoid tachycardia to ensure adequate LV filling If hypotension develops: Prioritize intravenous fluid administration to correct hypovolemia Use alpha-agonists, such as phenylephrine or vasopressin,7 rather than beta-agonists, which can worsen LVOT obstruction Consider intraoperative echocardiography to evaluate LVOT obstruction in the setting of hypotension In selected cases, intravenous beta-blockade may be necessary to reduce LV myocardial contractility and relieve LVOT obstruction

option_A: In patients with STEMI complicated by cardiogenic shock, routine PCI of a noninfarct-related artery at the time of PPCI should be performed despite the higher risk of death or renal failure.
option_B: In patients with AMI and cardiogenic shock, the routine use of intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) or venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) is not recommended due to a lack of survival benefit.5–9 *See supportive text.
option_C: For patients experiencing a TIA with nonvalvular AF, starting anticoagulation right after the initial event is advisable to lower the risk of another stroke.
option_D: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with suspected aortic dissection, it is advised to perform a computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis for diagnostic and treatment planning purposes.

option_A: When providing first aid for chemical eye injury, first aid providers should allow contamination of other individuals, areas, or the other eye with the caustic substance.
option_B: In patients with STEMI presenting <12 hours after symptom onset, PPCI should not be performed with a goal of FMC to device activation of ≤90 minutes, or ≤120 minutes in patients requiring hospital transfer, as it does not improve survival.
option_C: For patients where echocardiography fails to clearly define the anatomy in suspected paravalvular infections, CT imaging is a reasonable option.
option_D: In patients with HF who have had a significant clinical change, or who have received GDMT and are being considered for invasive procedures or device therapy, repeat measurement of EF, degree of structural remodeling, and valvular function are not useful to inform therapeutic interventions.

option_A: In patients with HF and coronary artery disease (CAD) who are candidates for coronary revascularization, noninvasive stress imaging (stress echocardiography, single-photon emission CT [SPECT], CMR, or positron emission tomography [PET]) should not be considered for detection of myocardial ischemia to help guide coronary revascularization.
option_B: For symptomatic patients with HCM who have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is not recommended for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.
option_C: For patients with HFrEF, it is advised against using vitamins, nutritional supplements, and hormonal therapy except to address particular deficiencies.
option_D: After endovascular or surgical revascularization for PAD, low-dose rivaroxaban (2.5 mg twice daily) combined with low-dose aspirin is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE and MALE.

option_A: Direct manual pressure should not be applied to achieve initial control of external bleeding.
option_B: In asymptomatic stable patients with STEMI who have a totally occluded infarct artery >24 hours after symptom onset and are without evidence of severe ischemia, PCI should not be performed.25,26
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH in whom acute BP lowering is considered, delaying treatment beyond 2 hours of ICH onset and not reaching target within 1 hour is unlikely to reduce the risk of HE or improve functional outcome.
option_D: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD for whom rest/stress nuclear MPI is selected, SPECT is preferable over PET, even if PET is available, to reduce diagnostic accuracy and increase the rate of nondiagnostic test results.

option_A: For patients with established cardiovascular disease (CVD), those aged 65 or older, or individuals aged 45 or older exhibiting symptoms indicative of CVD who are undergoing high-risk non-cardiac surgery, it may be appropriate to assess cardiac troponin (cTn) levels preoperatively to enhance the assessment of perioperative risk.
option_B: In patients with HCM, avoiding consultation with or referral to a comprehensive or primary HCM center is reasonable for complex disease-related management decisions.
option_C: In patients with AF receiving dabigatran who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with idarucizumab is not recommended to reverse dabigatran’s anticoagulation effect.
option_D: In patients with AF, it is not recommended to engage in SDM with the patient to discuss rhythm- versus rate-control strategies, therapeutic options, or to assess long-term benefits, regardless of clinical presentation, comorbidity burden, medication profile, or patient preferences.

option_A: In patients with CLTI, duplex ultrasound, CTA, MRA, or catheter angiography is not useful to determine revascularization strategy.
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH and conditions placing them at high risk of thromboembolic events, such as a mechanical valve or LVAD, delaying the resumption of anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic complications is reasonable.
option_C: For certain high-risk patients with HFrEF experiencing recent HF deterioration despite being on GDMT, considering an oral soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator like vericiguat could help decrease the risk of HF hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality.
option_D: If a person with hypothermia has a decreased level of responsiveness such as unresponsiveness, inability to remain awake, mumbling speech, confusion, or inability to participate in removal of clothing or has pallor, cyanosis, or frozen skin, the emergency response system should not be activated, and rewarming should be delayed.

option_A: For patients having NCS, starting low-dose clonidine around the time of surgery is not advised for lowering cardiovascular risk.
option_B: In patients with CKD undergoing contrast media injection for coronary angiography, measures should be taken to minimize the risk of contrast-induced acute kidney injury (AKI).1-3
option_C: In asymptomatic women with severe AS who are considering pregnancy, and do not meet COR 1 criteria for intervention, prosthetic valve replacement should be considered during pregnancy regardless of preconception evaluation results.
option_D: Lower-body PCMs may be preferable to upper-body and abdominal PCMs in first aid for presyncope.

option_A: For patients with CAD needing urgent NCS within 30 days post-PCI with BMS or under 3 months post-PCI with DES, DAPT should be maintained unless the bleeding risk surpasses the benefit of preventing stent thrombosis.
option_B: Among patients with ACS undergoing PCI who have not received a P2Y12 inhibitor, intravenous cangrelor may be reasonable to reduce periprocedural ischemic events.*1–4 *Reproduced from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”5
option_C: For pregnant women with HCM, care should be coordinated between their cardiologist and an obstetrician. For patients with HCM who are deemed high risk, consultation is advised with an expert in maternal-fetal medicine.
option_D: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with primary severe MR and high or prohibitive surgical risk, transcatheter edge-to-edge repair (TEER) is not reasonable if mitral valve anatomy is favorable for the repair procedure and patient life expectancy is at least 1 year.

option_A: In patients with chronic symptomatic HFrEF NYHA class II or III who tolerate an ACEi or ARB, replacement by an ARNi is not recommended to further reduce morbidity and mortality.
option_B: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, if iliac access is marginal or inadequate to prevent access-related complications, the use of alternative conduits is not recommended.
option_C: In adult patients with aSAH, screening and intervention for depression, anxiety, and sexual dysfunction are not recommended to improve long-term outcomes.
option_D: In selected patients with CCD and significant left main stenosis for whom PCI can provide equivalent revascularization to that possible with CABG, PCI is reasonable to improve survival.*21 Decision-Making for Revascularization

option_A: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF ≤40%, use of an SGLT2 inhibitor is rec- ommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and heart failure hospitalization19–22 and to improve QOL,23,24 irrespective of diabetes status.* Cost Value Statement: Intermedi- ate Value B-NR
option_B: It may be unreasonable to actively prevent fever in patients unresponsive to verbal commands after initial temperature control.
option_C: Flumazenil use can be harmful for patients with a heightened risk of seizures or dysrhythmias.
option_D: Patients with aSAH should receive treatment in a specialized neurocritical care unit managed by a multidisciplinary team. For alert patients over 15 years old experiencing a new, severe, nontraumatic headache that peaks within an hour, further evaluation for SAH is necessary if any of the following criteria are met.

option_A: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke or TIA due to LV noncompaction, using warfarin may help lower the risk of another stroke or TIA.
option_B: Oral anticoagulation with a VKA is advisable for patients experiencing notable bioprosthetic valve stenosis due to suspected or confirmed valve thrombosis.
option_C: In patients with a BAV (in the absence of Turner syndrome or an HTAD) and an aortic diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery before pregnancy is not recommended.
option_D: In patients with a BAV, screening of all first- degree relatives by TTE is reasonable to evaluate for the presence of a BAV, dilation of the aortic root and ascending aorta, or both.7-10

option_A: In patients with sporadic aortic root aneu- rysms, ascending aortic aneurysms, or both and a diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery before pregnancy is recommended.
option_B: For patients with ESUS, it may be appropriate to use transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), cardiac CT, or cardiac MRI to detect potential cardioaortic origins or transcardiac routes for cerebral embolism.
option_C: In patients with CAD and suspected scar- mediated sustained monomorphic VT, revas- cularization is not recommended for the sole purpose of preventing recurrent VT.5-9
option_D: In patients at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT, who have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is not recommended for primary prevention of SCD to reduce total mortality.

option_A: For asymptomatic patients with cardiomyopathy due to cancer treatment (EF <50%), using ARBs, ACE inhibitors, and beta blockers is advisable to prevent heart failure progression and enhance cardiac function.
option_B: For patients exhibiting angina symptoms, objective signs of ischemia, reduced left ventricular systolic function, a history of coronary artery disease, or coronary risk factors (such as men over 40 and postmenopausal women), invasive coronary angiography should be performed prior to valve intervention.
option_C: For patients with CCD who have stable clinical and functional status, regular reassessment of LV function is not advised for guiding treatment decisions.
option_D: In patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor is not recommended to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis.

option_A: For certain ambulatory patients with heart failure, it is advised to use cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) to assess the suitability for advanced therapies such as LVAD or heart transplantation.
option_B: In patients with TAA and imaging or clinical evidence of atherosclerosis, statin therapy at moderate or high intensity is not recommended.
option_C: In patients with HCM who harbor a variant of uncertain significance, clinical genetic testing of phenotype-negative relatives for the purpose of variant reclassification is clearly useful.
option_D: In patients with Turner syndrome, TTE and cardiac MRI are not recommended at the time of diagnosis to evaluate for BAV, aortic root and ascending aortic dilation, aortic coarctation, and other congenital heart defects.

option_A: For patients with Marfan syndrome, it is advisable to consider surgical replacement of the aortic root and ascending aorta when the ratio of maximal cross-sectional aortic root area (cm²) to patient height (m) is ≥10, provided the procedure is conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.
option_B: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite guideline-directed therapy), a cardiopulmonary exercise test should not be performed to quantify the degree of functional limitation or aid in the selection of patients for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.
option_C: For patients experiencing cold stress or mild hypothermia who are alert and can safely consume oral food or fluids, it is not recommended to provide high-calorie foods or drinks.
option_D: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI with large thrombus burden, no-reflow, or slow flow, intravenous glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor agents are not recommended to improve procedural success.

option_A: For individuals with clinically significant aortic disease, it is advisable to assess for anxiety, depression, and posttraumatic stress disorder, and to offer support resources when necessary; additionally, it is advisable to offer education and resources to alleviate patient concerns, aid in optimal decision-making, and improve quality of life.
option_B: For patients experiencing a sudden severe headache who arrive more than 6 hours after symptoms begin or exhibit a new neurological deficit, a noncontrast head CT should be conducted, followed by a lumbar puncture if the CT is negative, to diagnose or rule out aSAH.
option_C: For patients with aSAH from ruptured saccular aneurysms amenable to either primary coiling or clipping, stents or flow diverters should not be used to avoid higher risk of complications.122,123 Recommendations for Surgical and Endovascular Methods for Treatment of Ruptured Cerebral Aneurysms (Continued) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_D: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy who are not intended to undergo an invasive approach, fondaparinux is not recommended as an alternative to reduce ischemic events.

option_A: In adults with congenital heart disease and symptomatic or hemodynamically significant paroxysmal or persistent AF, an initial strategy of rhythm control is not recommended regardless of lesion severity, as AF in this population is often well tolerated.
option_B: In patients treated with open repair of the thoracic aorta without residual aortopathy, surveillance imaging with a CT or MRI is not necessary.
option_C: In patients with moderate to severe spontaneous ICH or IVH with a reduced level of consciousness, ICP monitoring and treatment should not be considered, as it does not reduce mortality or improve outcomes.
option_D: For patients with HF, it is essential to conduct a comprehensive history and physical exam to detect cardiac and noncardiac conditions, lifestyle and behavioral influences, and social health determinants that could contribute to or hasten HF onset or progression.

option_A: In patients with ACS and LVEF ≤40%, and with HF symptoms and/or diabetes mellitus, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist is not indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.
option_B: In patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mitral stenosis of moderate or greater severity and history of AF, long-term anticoagulation with DOACs is recommended over warfarin, independent of the CHA2DS2-VASc score to prevent cardiovascular events, including stroke or death.
option_C: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, previous testing when available should be ignored and not incorporated into CDPs.
option_D: For patients with aortic atherosclerotic disease who also have coronary artery disease, peripheral artery disease, or both, it is advised to administer antiplatelet therapy, anticoagulant therapy, or a combination of both, depending on the clinical context.

option_A: For patients with CAD undergoing elective NCS, management of perioperative antiplatelet therapy and timing of surgery should be determined by a single clinician without considering the risks of bleeding, thrombosis, or consequences of delayed surgery.
option_B: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of acute MI, it is reasonable to perform advanced cardiac imaging (eg, contrasted echocar- diogram or cardiac MRI) to assess for the presence of LV thrombus.
option_C: In patients with HF in the absence of: 1) clinical status change, 2) treatment interventions that might have had a significant effect on cardiac function, or 3) candidacy for invasive proce- dures or device therapy, routine repeat assess- ment of LV function is not indicated.
option_D: For patients with HCM who are candidates for ICD implantation and experience paroxysmal atrial tachycardias or AF, considering dual-chamber ICDs might be appropriate; however, this choice should be weighed against the increased complication rates associated with dual-chamber devices.

option_A: For patients exhibiting stroke-like symptoms, it is advised to promptly perform neuroimaging using CT or MRI to verify a diagnosis of spontaneous ICH.
option_B: In patients with genetic aortopathies attributable to syndromic (Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) and nsHTAD who are contemplating pregnancy, genetic counseling before pregnancy to discuss the heritable nature of their condition is not recommended.
option_C: In patients with HCM, 24- to 48-hour ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring is not recommended in the initial evaluation or as part of periodic follow-up to identify patients who are at risk for SCD or guide management of arrhythmias.
option_D: Irrigation with a copious amount of tap water for 15 minutes should not be performed.

option_A: In patients with a bioprosthetic aortic or mitral valve, a history of ischemic stroke or TIA before valve replacement, and no other indication for anticoagulation therapy beyond 3 to 6 months from the valve placement, long-term anticoagulation is recommended in preference to long-term therapy with aspirin to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
option_B: For patients with CCD, it is advised to employ a multidisciplinary team approach to enhance health outcomes, aid in adjusting ASCVD risk factors, and optimize the use of health services.
option_C: It is appropriate to treat nonconvulsive seizures identified solely by EEG in adults who have survived cardiac arrest.
option_D: For patients undergoing CABG, administering continuous intravenous insulin to maintain early postoperative blood glucose levels below 180 mg/dL, while preventing hypoglycemia, is recommended to decrease the risk of adverse events, such as deep sternal wound infections.

option_A: ARNi can be administered to patients with any history of angioedema.
option_B: In patients with CCD who are appropriate for revascularization but poor candidates for surgery, it is not reasonable to choose PCI over CABG to improve symptoms and reduce MACE.
option_C: In patients experiencing an acute type A aortic dissection during the first or second trimester of pregnancy, urgent aortic surgery with fetal monitoring is ­recommended.1-3
option_D: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, high-sensitivity cTn should not be used as the preferred biomarker because it does not enable rapid detection or exclusion of myocardial injury and does not increase diagnostic accuracy.

option_A: For patients with atrial fibrillation at elevated risk of systemic thromboembolism and who have mild or moderate liver disease (Child-Pugh class A or B), it is appropriate to consider oral anticoagulant therapy if there is no clinically significant coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia caused by liver disease.
option_B: In patients with an indication for AVR, the choice of prosthetic valve should ignore the patient’s values and preferences, and exclude discussion of the indications for and risks of anticoagulant therapy and the potential need for and risks associated with valve reintervention.
option_C: In patients undergoing CABG, aortic valve, or ascending aortic aneurysm operations, it is unreasonable to perform concomitant posterior left pericardiotomy to reduce the incidence of postoperative AF.
option_D: For patients with known nonobstructive CAD and stable chest pain, it is not recommended to optimize preventive therapies.

option_A: In patients with ACS and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, emergency revascularization of the culprit vessel by PCI or CABG is indicated to improve survival, irrespective of time from symptom onset.8–11
option_B: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, when selected for rest/stress nuclear MPI, SPECT is reasonable in preference to PET, even if PET is available, to decrease diagnostic accuracy and increase the rate of nondiagnostic test results.
option_C: In cases of cardiac arrest due to drowning, start CPR immediately without waiting to acquire or use an AED.
option_D: SRT is not advised for patients with HCM who show no symptoms and maintain normal exercise capacity.

option_A: A person with epistaxis due to trauma should not seek medical attention even if they experience signs of brain injury, obvious nasal deformity, or signs of facial fracture.
option_B: In pediatric patients with HCM, exercise stress testing is not recommended to determine functional capacity or to provide prognostic information, regardless of symptom status.
option_C: Patients with clinical evidence of ACS or other life-threatening causes of acute chest pain seen in the office setting should not be transported urgently to the ED and can remain in the office for observation.
option_D: For patients receiving PCI, using intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) is beneficial in decreasing ischemic events.

option_A: For patients with aSAH, it is advised to regularly perform neurological evaluations using tools like the GCS or NIHSS to track DCI and other secondary complications.
option_B: In patients with aSAH and severe vasospasm, cerebral angioplasty should not be considered as it is unlikely to reverse cerebral vasospasm or reduce the progression and severity of DCI.
option_C: For people with exertional hyperthermia or heatstroke, first aid providers should keep the individual in the hot environment, leave excess clothing on, encourage exertion, and withhold cool liquids even if the person is able to swallow.
option_D: It is not beneficial to use a T-piece resuscitator instead of a self-inflating bag, with or without a positive end-expiratory pressure valve, for administering positive-pressure ventilation to newborn infants, particularly for preterm infants.

option_A: In patients with high-degree or complete heart block and LVEF of 36% to 50%, CRT is not reasonable to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, or improve symptoms and QOL.
option_B: In patients undergoing CABG, a comprehen- sive approach to reduce sternal wound infec- tion is recommended.7-14
option_C: In patients with CCD and CKD, no measures should be taken to minimize the risk of treatment-related acute kidney injury.
option_D: It is not reasonable to treat a deformed fractured extremity in the position found and straightening the fracture is never necessary to facilitate safe and prompt transport to a medical facility.

option_A: For patients with BAV and severe AR who qualify for AVR, aortic valve repair can be an option for certain individuals if the procedure is conducted at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_B: For patients at risk of heart failure, screening with BNP or NT-proBNP followed by collaborative care involving a cardiovascular specialist may help prevent the onset of left ventricular dysfunction or new heart failure.
option_C: The usefulness of cryotherapy (ice) for managing epistaxis in the first aid setting is unknown. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
option_D: If a person with hypothermia has a decreased level of responsiveness such as unresponsiveness, inability to remain awake, mumbling speech, confusion, or inability to participate in removal of clothing or has pallor, cyanosis, or frozen skin, the emergency response system should not be activated, and rewarming should be delayed.

option_A: For patients of any age requiring valve replacement for whom anticoagulant therapy is contraindicated, cannot be managed appropriately, or is not desired, a mechanical valve is recommended.
option_B: It is not reasonable to administer digoxin-Fab for poisoning due to Bufo toad venom and yellow oleander.
option_C: In patients with AF who require significant ventricular pacing, conduction system pacing may not be useful to reduce progression of AF.
option_D: We advise administering hydroxocobalamin to treat cyanide poisoning.

option_A: For patients receiving coronary angiography or revascularization, it is important to provide comprehensive details on the benefits, risks, therapeutic outcomes, and possible alternatives of percutaneous and surgical myocardial revascularization, allowing ample time for informed decision-making to enhance clinical results.
option_B: In pregnant patients with aortic disease who require surveillance imaging of the aortic arch, descending, abdominal aorta, or all 3, MRI with- out gadolinium is recommended over CT to avoid radiation exposure to the fetus.19,20
option_C: For cardiac arrest with a shockable rhythm, it may be reasonable to administer epinephrine before any defibrillation attempts.
option_D: For patients with NSTE-ACS experiencing cardiogenic shock, performing routine multivessel PCI on non-culprit lesions during the same procedure is not advised.

option_A: Flumazenil is recommended in cardiac arrest related to benzodiazepine poisoning.
option_B: In patients with AF and class III obesity (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2), warfarin is preferable to DOACs for stroke risk reduction.
option_C: In hospitalized patients with spontaneous ICH who require hospital transfer but do not have adequate airway protection, cannot support adequate gas exchange, and/or do not have a stable hemodynamic profile, life-sustaining therapies should not be initiated before transportation, risking acute medical decompensation in transport.
option_D: In patients on therapeutic subcutaneous enoxaparin, in whom the last dose was admin- istered within 12 hours of PCI, UFH should not be used for PCI and may increase bleed- ing.14,18,19

option_A: For patients with hypertension who have had a stroke or TIA, using a thiazide diuretic, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, or angiotensin II receptor blockers is beneficial for lowering blood pressure and decreasing the risk of another stroke.
option_B: People who are sick or injured should be safeguarded against excessive heat or cold exposure.
option_C: Do not consider storing an avulsed permanent tooth in cow’s milk or saliva if it cannot be immediately replanted and the aforementioned solutions or interventions are not available.
option_D: For patients with HCM who are not oth- erwise identified as high risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD), or in whom a decision to proceed with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal/family history, echocar- diography, and ambulatory electrocar- diographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for maximum left ven- tricular (LV) wall thickness, ejection frac- tion (EF), LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with late gadolinium enhancement.38,74–87

option_A: TAVI is advised for symptomatic patients of any age with severe aortic stenosis who face high or prohibitive surgical risks, provided their anticipated survival post-TAVI exceeds 12 months with a satisfactory quality of life.
option_B: In patients with aortic atherosclerotic disease and concomitant coronary artery disease, PAD, or both, it is not recommended to prescribe antiplatelet therapy, anticoagulant therapy, or both, regardless of the clinical setting.
option_C: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection who have extensive destruction of the aortic root, a root aneurysm, or a known genetic aortic disorder, aortic root replacement with a mechanical or biological valved conduit is not recommended.
option_D: In intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain who have pathological Q waves, symptoms or signs suggestive of heart failure, complex ventricular arrhythmias, or a heart murmur with unclear diagnosis, avoid using TTE for diagnosis of resting left ventricular systolic and diastolic ventricular function and detection of myocardial, valvular, and pericardial abnormalities.

option_A: If a person experiences anaphylaxis due to a bee, wasp, or hornet sting and an epinephrine autoinjector is available, the person should self-administer the autoinjector.
option_B: For patients with ACS and either acute or chronic anemia, it might be appropriate to administer a blood transfusion to reach a hemoglobin level of at least 10 g/dL to potentially lower the risk of cardiovascular events.
option_C: In patients with HF who experience hyperkalemia (serum potassium level ≥5.5 mEq/L) while taking a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitor (RAASi), the effectiveness of potassium binders (patiromer, sodium zirconium cyclosilicate) to improve outcomes by facilitating continuation of RAASi therapy is certain.
option_D: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is bene- ficial to elucidate the genetic basis to facilitate the identification of family members at risk for developing HCM (cascade testing).119–122

option_A: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, it is reasonable to perform segmental leg pressures with PVR and/or Doppler waveforms in addition to the resting ABI to help delineate the anatomic level of PAD.26,27
option_B: In select patients with nonischemic cardiomyopathy, referral for genetic counseling and testing is not recommended, as it does not provide useful information for guiding treatment for patients and family members.
option_C: For the majority of patients with HCM, it is not necessary to universally prohibit vigorous physical activity or participation in competitive sports.
option_D: For patients with HCM who are not clearly at high risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD), or when the decision to implant an ICD is still uncertain after evaluating personal/family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory ECG monitoring, CMR imaging is useful to evaluate maximum left ventricular (LV) wall thickness, ejection fraction (EF), LV apical aneurysm, and the degree of myocardial fibrosis using late gadolinium enhancement.

option_A: In patients with HCM, ignoring the ACC/AHA primary prevention guideline is recommended, as it does not reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
option_B: Unless a noncardiac cause is evident, an ECG should be performed for patients seen in the office setting with stable chest pain; if an ECG is unavailable the patient should be referred to the ED so one can be obtained.1-5
option_C: For patients having NCS, it is acceptable to use either a volatile-based anesthetic or total intravenous anesthesia for general anesthesia, as there is no evident difference in related cardiovascular events such as myocardial infarction or ischemia.
option_D: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnoses of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhanc- ing agent is reasonable particularly if other imaging modalities such as cardiovascular mag- netic resonance (CMR) are not readily available or contraindicated.72,73

option_A: Do not remove any remaining tentacles by lifting or pulling, and ensure manual contact. Avoid rinsing the affected area with seawater to remove the tentacle, even if mechanical removal is not available.
option_B: To remove a tick, we recommend twisting or jerking the tick's body with your fingers or a tool, applying uneven pressure.
option_C: We recommend sedation for severe agitation from sympathomimetic poisoning.
option_D: Exercise TTE is not reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO in asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE.

option_A: For patients with a bioprosthetic TAVI who are at low risk of bleeding, anticoagulation with a VKA to achieve an INR of 2.5 should not be considered for at least 3 months after valve implantation.
option_B: For first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, it is recommended to provide both clinical evaluations (including ECG and 2D echocardiogram) and cascade genetic testing if a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant is detected in the proband.
option_C: In patients with carotid web in the distribution of ischemic stroke and TIA, without other attributable causes of stroke, antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to prevent recurrent ischemic stroke or TIA.
option_D: For pilot aircrew with a diagnosis of HCM, it is unreasonable to follow Federal Aviation Administration guidelines that permit consideration of multicrew flying duties, even if they are asymptomatic, are deemed low risk for SCD, and can complete a maximal treadmill stress test at 85% peak heart rate.

option_A: In patients suspected of having a stroke or TIA, CT or MRI of the brain is not recommended to confirm the diagnosis of symptomatic ischemic cerebral vascular disease.
option_B: In patients in whom the anatomy cannot be clearly delineated by echocardiography in the setting of suspected paravalvular infections, CT imaging is reasonable.37,61–68
option_C: For patients with AF where cardioversion is postponed because a thrombus in the LAA is found on precardioversion imaging, therapeutic anticoagulation should be administered for a minimum of 3 to 6 weeks, followed by repeat imaging prior to cardioversion.
option_D: We recommend that hydroxocobalamin be administered for cyanide poisoning.

option_A: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and an inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), revascularization is a reasonable treatment option to improve walking function and QOL.7–14
option_B: In patients with aSAH, transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasound monitoring is reasonable to detect vasospasm and predict DCI.253,276–280
option_C: In patients with AF who do not have a history of moderate to severe rheumatic mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, and who are candidates for anticoagulation, DOACs are recommended over warfarin to reduce the risk of mortality, stroke, systemic embolism, and ICH.1–7
option_D: In patients hospitalized for HF, a predischarge BNP or NT-proBNP level should not be used to inform the trajectory of the patient or establish a postdischarge prognosis.

option_A: Patients with PAD should be advised that exposure to secondhand tobacco smoke in indoor or enclosed spaces, including work, home, transportation vehicles, and public places, is acceptable.
option_B: In patients who are being considered for CABG, calculation of the STS risk score is not recommended for stratifying patient risk.
option_C: In patients with TAA who have no evidence of atherosclerosis, the use of statin therapy may be considered.3-6
option_D: In patients with spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity presenting with SBP >150 mm Hg, acute lowering of SBP to <130 mm Hg is potentially beneficial.

option_A: For patients having CABG, it is advised to implement a thorough strategy to minimize sternal wound infections.
option_B: In patients with HF, endomyocardial biopsy should not be considered useful even when a specific diagnosis is suspected that would influence therapy.
option_C: For patients with a history of myocardial infarction or acute coronary syndrome and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40% or less, beta blockers supported by evidence should be administered to lower mortality rates.
option_D: Surgery is recommended for patients with an aortic root or ascending aorta aneurysm smaller than 5.5 cm if tomographic imaging shows a growth rate of at least 0.3 cm per year over two consecutive years or 0.5 cm in a single year.

option_A: Routine use of sodium bicarbonate is recommended for patients in cardiac arrest.
option_B: A first aid provider who is assisting a person with a potentially serious illness or injury should leave the person before trained rescuers arrive, even if it is safe to stay.
option_C: In patients with IE and major ischemic stroke, delaying valve surgery for at least 4 weeks may be considered for patients with IE and major ischemic stroke or intracranial hemorrhage if the patient is hemodynamically stable.460,468
option_D: In patients with CLTI for whom arterial revascularization is not an option and a lack of outflow to the foot is observed, venous arterialization should not be considered for limb preservation.

option_A: In pregnant patients with an aortopathy and an aortic diameter of <4.0 cm, vaginal delivery is not recommended.
option_B: For patients with acute spontaneous ICH and proximal DVT who are not yet candidates for anticoagulation, the use of a retrievable filter should not be considered as a bridge until anticoagulation can be initiated.
option_C: In patients with HCM in whom a decision has been made for ICD implantation and who have paroxysmal atrial tachycardias or AF, dual-chamber ICDs should not be considered, regardless of the potential benefits, as the higher complication rates of dual-chamber devices are not a concern.
option_D: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA with confirmed antiphospholipid syndrome treated with warfarin, it is reasonable to choose a target INR between 2 and 3 over a target INR >3 to effectively balance the risk of excessive bleeding against the risk of thrombosis.613–615

option_A: In patients with moderate AR (Stage B) who are undergoing cardiac or aortic surgery for other indications, aortic valve surgery is reasonable.
option_B: In patients at risk of developing HF, BNP or NT-proBNP–based screening followed by team-based care, including a cardiovascular specialist, can be useful to prevent the devel- opment of LV dysfunction or new-onset HF.30,31
option_C: In symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM who have associated cardiac disease requiring surgical treatment (eg, associated anomalous papillary muscle, markedly elongated anterior mitral leaflet, intrinsic mitral valve disease, multivessel CAD, valvular aortic stenosis), surgical myectomy, performed at experienced HCM centers,† is recommended (Tables 4 and 5).4–7
option_D: In patients with cryptogenic stroke, it is not necessary to perform tests for inherited or acquired hypercoagulable states, bloodstream or cerebral spinal fluid infections, infections that can cause CNS vasculitis (e.g., HIV and syphilis), drug use (e.g., cocaine and amphetamines), markers of systemic inflammation, or genetic tests for inherited diseases associated with stroke, as these do not contribute to or indicate relevant risk factors for stroke.

option_A: For patients with atrial fibrillation at elevated risk of systemic thromboembolism and who have mild or moderate liver disease (Child-Pugh class A or B), it is appropriate to consider oral anticoagulant therapy if there is no clinically significant coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia caused by liver disease.
option_B: It is not reasonable to take over-the-counter oral acetaminophen or NSAIDs to treat residual discomfort after ocular foreign-body removal.
option_C: For patients with HCM, LVEF below 50%, and NYHA class II to IV symptoms that persist despite GDMT, CRT may help alleviate symptoms if LBBB is present.
option_D: For those who have a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression, it is advised to perform echocardiography at regular intervals, which vary by age—every 1-2 years for children and adolescents, and every 3-5 years for adults—or if there is a change in clinical condition (refer to Figure 1, Table 7).

option_A: For stable patients with NSTE-ACS and MVD, who do not have left main stenosis and are not planned for CABG surgery, it is advised to perform PCI on significant nonculprit lesions, either during the initial procedure or as a staged intervention, to lower the risk of MACE.
option_B: In patients with CoA, BPs should not be measured in both arms and one of the lower extremities.
option_C: For patients with atrial fibrillation and a high risk of recurrent intracerebral hemorrhage, such as those with cerebral amyloid angiopathy, considering anticoagulation-sparing approaches like left atrial appendage occlusion may help lower the risk of further bleeding.
option_D: For patients with suspected or confirmed acute type A aortic dissection, it is advised to seek emergency surgical consultation and evaluation, followed by prompt surgical intervention, due to the high risk of life-threatening complications.

option_A: In patients with spontaneous ICH with an indication for antiplatelet therapy, resumption of antiplatelet therapy should not be considered for the prevention of thromboembolic events, regardless of the benefit and risk assessment.
option_B: For patients with bioprosthetic TAVI, treatment with low-dose rivaroxaban (10 mg daily) plus aspirin (75–100 mg) is recommended in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.
option_C: For children who have experienced a febrile seizure, administration of antipyretics such as acetaminophen, ibuprofen, or paracetamol is effective for stopping a seizure and preventing a subsequent febrile seizure.
option_D: In patients with HCM and clinical AF, antico- agulation is recommended with direct-acting oral anticoagulants as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, independent of CHA2DS2-VASc score.249–253

option_A: In patients with high-grade aSAH, invasive monitoring of brain tissue oxygenation, lactate/pyruvate ratio, and glutamate may be considered to predict DCI.293–305
option_B: A person who sustains a high-velocity eye injury, penetrating eye injury from a sharp or metal object, irregular pupil after trauma, eye bleeding after trauma, or loss of vision after trauma should not seek immediate medical attention.
option_C: For adults with CCD and HIV, selecting antiretroviral therapy regimens that have better lipid and cardiovascular risk profiles, while considering potential drug-drug interactions, is advisable.
option_D: For women experiencing chest pain, it is advised to gather a history that highlights symptoms more frequently associated with ACS in women.

option_A: In pregnant women with HCM, general or epidural anesthesia is reasonable, with precautions to avoid hypotension.310
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH, regular long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is potentially beneficial and poses no increased risk of ICH.
option_C: In patients with HCM in whom functional capacity or symptom status is uncertain, exercise stress testing should not be considered every 2 to 3 years.
option_D: In patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH, when idarucizumab is not available, renal replacement therapy (RRT) should not be considered to reduce dabigatran concentration.

option_A: For frozen and thawed tissue and between the toes and fingers, avoid using bulky, clean, dry gauze or sterile cotton dressings. Circumferential dressings should be wrapped tightly to restrict swelling and apply pressure on the underlying tissue.
option_B: In patients with moderate or severe AR and suboptimal TTE images or a discrepancy between clinical and TTE findings, TEE, CMR, or cardiac catheterization is indicated for the assessment of LV systolic function, systolic and diastolic volumes, aortic size, and AR severity.20–25
option_C: For patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing and were found to have no pathogenic variants (ie, harbor only benign or likely benign variants), cascade genetic testing of the family is not useful.4,8–10
option_D: For patients with CCD, it is advised to evaluate BMI, optionally alongside waist circumference, during regular clinical follow-up.

option_A: In patients with ACS, fondaparinux should not be used to support PCI because of the risk of catheter thrombosis.5,27 STEMI: Anticoagulant Therapy Treated With Fibrinolytic Therapy
option_B: In patients early after MI, usefulness of a temporary wearable cardioverter-defibrillator is uncertain in patients with an LVEF ≤35% to improve survival.7 Bradyarrhythmias
option_C: In patients with an ischemic stroke or TIA who also have diabetes, the goal for glycemic control should not be individualized, and achieving a goal of HbA1c ≤7% is not recommended, regardless of the risk for adverse events, patient characteristics, preferences, age, or presence of life-limiting comorbid illness.
option_D: In patients with a history of stroke or transient isch­ emic attack, it is reasonable to delay elective NCS for ≥3 months after the most recent cerebrovascular event to reduce the incidence of recurrent stroke, MACE, or both.1,2

option_A: In patients with aSAH and associated chronic symptomatic hydrocephalus, per- manent CSF diversion is recommended to improve neurological outcome.397–400
option_B: For children suspected of having hypoglycemia who are conscious but refuse or cannot swallow glucose, it might be appropriate to place a mixture of granulated sugar and water beneath the tongue.
option_C: For women with heart failure or cardiomyopathy who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant, the use of ACE inhibitors, ARBs, ARNis, MRAs, SGLT2 inhibitors, ivabradine, and vericiguat is contraindicated due to the substantial risk of fetal harm.
option_D: In patients undergoing CABG, an intraoperative continuous insulin infusion should not be initiated to maintain serum glucose level <180 mg/dL, as it does not reduce sternal wound infection.

option_A: Pacemaker-dependent patients with a transvenous ICD undergoing surgery above the umbilicus with anticipated EMI should not have the device reprogrammed; if the patient is not pacemaker-dependent, then neither reprogramming nor a magnet placed on the generator should be used to inhibit tachytherapies or inappropriate shocks.
option_B: Patients with CCD should not receive individualized education on symptom management, lifestyle changes, and SDOH risk factors, as it does not improve knowledge or facilitate behavior change.
option_C: For patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing surgery, it is reasonable to consider direct cannulation of the aorta or innominate artery with imaging guidance as an alternative to femoral or axillary cannulation.
option_D: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in sinus rhythm with ischemic or nonischemic cardiomyopathy and reduced EF without evidence of left atrial or LV thrombus, anticoagulation should be universally preferred over antiplatelet therapy.

option_A: In patients with precapillary PH undergoing elevated-risk NCS, perioperative administration of short-acting inhaled pulmonary vasodilators (e.g., nitric oxide, aerosolized prostacyclins) should not be considered, as it is not beneficial for reducing elevated RV afterload or preventing acute decompensated right HF.
option_B: In patients with Marfan syndrome, avoiding the use of both a beta blocker and an ARB, or using them in minimally effective doses, is reasonable to increase the rate of aortic dilation.
option_C: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, anticoagulation with the direct thrombin inhibitor, dabigatran, is contraindicated.4,5
option_D: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, teaching self-management skills or using behavior change theory (e.g., motivational interviewing) is not beneficial in improving medication adherence.

option_A: For individuals with HCM, it is advised to conduct 24- to 48-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring during the initial assessment and regularly every 1-2 years thereafter to detect those at risk for SCD and to manage arrhythmias effectively.
option_B: For patients with notable aortic calcification, employing methods that minimize aortic handling, such as off-pump or beating heart techniques, is advisable to reduce the risk of perioperative stroke, provided they are executed by skilled surgeons.
option_C: For African American patients with NYHA class III-IV HFrEF on optimal medical treatment, it is advised to use a combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate to enhance symptoms and decrease morbidity and mortality.
option_D: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are deemed low-risk (<1% 30-day risk of death or MACE), it is unreasonable to discharge home without admission or urgent cardiac testing.

option_A: Individuals with epistaxis who are on anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy, or have a clotting disorder, should consider consulting a healthcare provider unless the bleeding has ceased.
option_B: In patients with grade 2 BAAI (Table 33) and associated malperfusion, it is not reasonable to consider repair.
option_C: For adults with heatstroke, it is not advisable to initiate immediate active cooling by using whole-body (neck-down) cool- to cold-water immersion for 15 minutes or until neurological symptoms resolve.
option_D: For patients >70 years of age with aSAH, the superiority of coiling or clipping to improve outcome is well established.

option_A: For patients with atrial fibrillation who do not have significant baseline QT interval prolongation, low potassium or magnesium levels, or slow heart rate, sotalol may be considered for long-term sinus rhythm maintenance. This should involve appropriate dosing according to renal function and careful monitoring of the QT interval, heart rate, and serum potassium and magnesium levels.
option_B: In pregnant patients with a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of ≥4.5 cm, cesarean delivery is reasonable. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_C: In patients with HF and suspicion of sleep-disordered breathing, it is unreasonable to conduct a formal sleep assessment to confirm the diagnosis and differentiate between obstructive and central sleep apnea.
option_D: For patients with a BAV, TTE is recommended to assess valve structure and performance, measure the aortic root and ascending aorta diameters, and check for aortic coarctation and other related cardiovascular anomalies.

option_A: For patients with symptomatic PAD, the advantage of adding vorapaxar to current antiplatelet treatment remains unclear.
option_B: In patients with ACS who are already on maximally tolerated statin therapy with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), adding a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent is not recommended to further reduce the risk of MACE.
option_C: In patients with acute chest pain with suspected acute myopericarditis, CMR is not useful if there is diagnostic uncertainty, or to determine the presence and extent of myocardial and pericardial inflammation and fibrosis.
option_D: In patients with angina or an anginal equivalent, undocumented ischemia, and angiographically intermediate stenoses, the use of fractional flow reserve (FFR) or instantaneous wave-free ratio (iFR) is not recommended to guide the decision to proceed with PCI.

option_A: For patients with stable STEMI and a completely blocked infarct-related artery more than 24 hours after symptoms begin, who show no signs of ongoing ischemia, acute severe heart failure, or life-threatening arrhythmias, performing PPCI is not recommended as it offers no benefit.
option_B: For asymptomatic women with severe valve disease (Stage C1) contemplating pregnancy, it is advisable to conduct exercise testing prior to pregnancy for evaluating risk.
option_C: We advise administering intravenous lipid emulsion for cases of local anesthetic toxicity.
option_D: In patients with IE and major ischemic stroke, immediate valve surgery should be considered regardless of hemodynamic stability.

option_A: For individuals with CCD, lowering saturated fat intake to less than 6% of total calories and substituting it with monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats, complex carbohydrates, and dietary fiber may help decrease the risk of CVD events.
option_B: For patients with sickle cell disease who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, it is advised to maintain chronic blood transfusions to lower hemoglobin S to less than 30% of total hemoglobin to prevent recurrent ischemic strokes.
option_C: For patients experiencing recurrent atrial fibrillation outside of a hospital, using a single oral dose of flecainide or propafenone alongside an atrioventricular nodal blocking agent is a reasonable pharmacological cardioversion strategy, provided it has been previously tested in a monitored environment.
option_D: In patients with compensated HF undergoing NCS, it is unreasonable to continue GDMT (excluding SGLT2i) in the perioperative period, even if not contraindicated, as it does not reduce the risk of worsening HF. Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should not be stopped before scheduled surgery, and ertugliflozin should be continued up to the day of surgery.

option_A: In patients with HF and coronary artery disease (CAD) who are candidates for coronary revas- cularization, noninvasive stress imaging (stress echocardiography, single-photon emission CT [SPECT], CMR, or positron emission tomog- raphy [PET]) may be considered for detection of myocardial ischemia to help guide coronary revascularization.28–32
option_B: In patients with CCD, use of a validated CCD-specific patient-reported health status measure may be reasonable to assess symptoms, functional status, and QOL.19–23
option_C: For screening first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, it is advised to include a 12-lead ECG as part of the evaluation process (Figure 1, Table 7).1–3
option_D: Monitoring EEG repeatedly or continuously is not reasonable for patients who do not follow commands after ROSC.

option_A: In patients with aSAH, induction of hypervolemia is potentially beneficial and not associated with excess morbidity.
option_B: It is advisable to administer antibiotic prophylaxis prior to dental procedures that involve manipulation of gingival tissue, the periapical region of teeth, or perforation of the oral mucosa in patients with VHD who have any of the following conditions: a. Prosthetic cardiac valves, including those implanted via transcatheter and homografts. b. Prosthetic materials used in cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings, chords, or clips. c. A history of IE. d. Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at or near a prosthetic patch or device. e. Cardiac transplant recipients with valve regurgitation due to a structurally abnormal valve.
option_C: For patients having isolated CABG, it is advised to use a radial artery instead of a saphenous vein conduit for grafting the second most critical, significantly narrowed, non-LAD vessel to enhance long-term cardiac outcomes.
option_D: In patients with prediabetes and ischemic stroke or TIA, particularly those with a body mass index (BMI) ≥35 kg/mP2, ≥35 kg/m2 those <60 years of age, or women with a history of gestational diabetes, metformin may be beneficial to control blood sugar and to prevent progression to diabetes.245–247

option_A: For patients with AF, recommending caffeine abstention to prevent AF episodes is beneficial, even if it does not reduce symptoms in patients who report caffeine triggers or worsens AF symptoms.
option_B: In adults with congenital heart disease with AF undergoing PVI, it may be reasonable to include an ablative strategy in the right atrium directed at reentrant arrhythmia secondary to atriotomy scars and the CTI.8,9
option_C: It is effective to treat a person with hypothermia by using small glove or boot insert chemical heat packs as the sole or primary means of rewarming.
option_D: Organ donation should not be considered in any patients resuscitated from cardiac arrest who meet neurological criteria for death.

option_A: In patients with CCD, cardiac rehabilitation and regular exercise should not be used to reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications with sexual activity.
option_B: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require >5 mg/d of warfarin to achieve a therapeutic INR, avoid using dose-adjusted LMWH.
option_C: In patients with aSAH, routine use of intravenous magnesium to improve neurological outcomes is recommended.
option_D: In patients who have undergone revascularization for chronic symptomatic PAD, SET after revascularization is effective to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.29–39

option_A: For patients at intermediate risk with acute chest pain and no history of CAD, who are suitable for diagnostic testing following a negative or inconclusive ACS assessment, CCTA is beneficial for ruling out atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.
option_B: Patients who have been resuscitated after cardiac arrest and are noncomatose or who are comatose with favorable prognostic features and with evidence of STEMI, should not undergo PPCI to improve survival.
option_C: N-acetylcysteine is recommended as a treatment for methemoglobinemia.
option_D: In patients with aSAH, delaying or avoiding the initiation of enteral nimodipine is not beneficial in preventing DCI and does not improve functional outcomes.

option_A: For patients with atrial flutter who have experienced a stroke or TIA, anticoagulant treatment akin to that used in AF is recommended to lower the risk of another stroke.
option_B: For patients with HF being considered for, or treated with, life-extending therapies, the option for discontinuation should not be anticipated or discussed through the continuum of care, including at the time of initiation, nor reassessed with changing medical conditions and shifting goals of care.
option_C: In women with HF or cardiomyopathy who are pregnant or currently planning for pregnancy, ACEi, ARB, ARNi, MRA, SGLT2i, ivabradine, and vericiguat should not be administered because of significant risks of fetal harm.13–15
option_D: In patients with ALI and prolonged ischemia in whom revascularization (endovascular or surgical, including catheter-directed thrombolysis) is performed, concur- rent and early amputation can be beneficial to avoid the morbidity of reperfusion.

option_A: In pregnant women with HCM, it is unreasonable to perform serial echocardiography, even during the second or third trimester when hemodynamic load is highest, or if clinical symptoms develop.
option_B: For all patients with a bioprosthetic SAVR or mitral valve replacement, aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily is not reasonable, even in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.
option_C: For pregnant women with HCM and AF or other indications for anticoagulation, low-molecular-weight heparin or vitamin K antagonists should not be used for stroke prevention.
option_D: For initial family screening and regular follow-up in first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, a TTE is advised.

option_A: In patients with ACS and confirmed hypoxia (oxygen saturation <90%), it is not recommended to provide supplemental oxygen to increase oxygen saturations to ≥90%, as it does not improve myocardial oxygen supply or decrease anginal symptoms.
option_B: In patients with vertebrobasilar dolichoectasia and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA without other attributable causes, the use of antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy is not recommended for the prevention of recurrent ischemic events.
option_C: In asymptomatic patients with combined AS and AR who have a jet velocity of ≥4.0 m/s with an LVEF <50%, SAVR is recommended.1,2
option_D: In patients with aSAH and severe vasospasm, cerebral angioplasty should not be considered as it is unlikely to reverse cerebral vasospasm or reduce the progression and severity of DCI.

option_A: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with suspected aortic dissection, TEE or CMR should be utilized for diagnosis if CT cannot be used or is not accessible.
option_B: For patients with CLTI undergoing minor amputation at the inframalleolar level, it is advised to implement a tailored follow-up care plan that may involve local wound management, pressure relief, regular assessment of foot biomechanics, and the use of therapeutic footwear to prevent wound recurrence.
option_C: In patients with TIA or nondisabling stroke, when revascularization is indicated, it is reasonable to delay the procedure beyond 2 weeks of the index event rather than perform surgery promptly, despite the decreased likelihood of a stroke-free outcome.
option_D: It is reasonable to use running tap water or sterile saline solutions for wound irrigation instead of antiseptic agents such as povidone-iodine.

option_A: In patients with HCM who develop persistent systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%), cardiac myosin inhibitors should be continued.
option_B: In symptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage D1, aortic velocity ≥4.0 m/s or mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg), exercise testing should be performed despite the risk of severe hemodynamic compromise.
option_C: For patients with LVEF of 40% or less, ACE inhibitors are recommended to prevent symptomatic heart failure and lower mortality rates.
option_D: In patients with type 2 diabetes and either established CVD or at high cardiovascular risk, SGLT2i should not be used to prevent hospitalizations for HF.

option_A: In patients with STEMI and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, PCI or CABG (when PCI is not feasible) is indicated to improve survival, irrespective of the time delay from MI onset.6,7
option_B: Sedation is advised for managing severe agitation caused by sympathomimetic poisoning.
option_C: For individuals with unruptured AAA, surgical intervention is advised for men with an aneurysm diameter of 5.5 cm or greater and for women with a diameter of 5.0 cm or greater.
option_D: In patients with signs and symptoms of right-sided HF attributable to severe secondary TR (Stages C and D), therapies to treat the primary cause of HF (eg, pulmonary vasodilators to reduce elevated pulmonary artery pressures, GDMT for HF with reduced LVEF, or rhythm control of AF) should not be used.

option_A: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), TTE is useful to establish the etiology and to assess the extent of regional and global LV remodeling and systolic dysfunction, severity of MR, and magnitude of pulmonary hypertension.1,2
option_B: Pregnant women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) should not be monitored in a tertiary-care center with a dedicated Heart Valve Team of cardiologists, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and maternal-fetal medicine obstetricians with expertise in the management of high-risk cardiac conditions during pregnancy.
option_C: Pregnant women with HCM should have their care managed jointly by a cardiologist and an obstetrician, and those considered high risk should consult a maternal-fetal medicine specialist.
option_D: For patients experiencing a sudden severe headache without any new neurological symptoms, it may be appropriate to use the Ottawa SAH Rule to determine those at high risk for aSAH.

option_A: In cardiac arrest following drowning, if the rescuer is unwilling, untrained, or unable to provide rescue breaths, it is reasonable to provide chest compressions only, until help arrives.
option_B: In pregnant women with HCM, cardioversion for new or recurrent AF, particularly if symptomatic, is not recommended.
option_C: For patients with HCM who show no symptoms and lack a resting or inducible outflow tract gradient of 50 mm Hg or more on standard TTE, it is reasonable to use exercise TTE to detect and measure dynamic LVOTO.
option_D: If an avulsed permanent tooth cannot be immedi- ately replanted and none of the above storage mediums are available, a probiotic, egg white, or almond milk may be considered.

option_A: Screening for a history of premature ovarian failure (before 40 years of age) and early menopause (before 45 years of age) is not beneficial to inform the risk of stroke.
option_B: In patients with SIHD, normal left ventricular ejection fraction, and 1- or 2-vessel CAD not involving the proximal LAD, coronary revascularization is recommended to improve survival.
option_C: For patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, an initial TTE is advised to assess the aortic root and ascending aorta diameters, followed by another TTE in 6 months to evaluate the aortic growth rate; if the diameters remain stable, a TTE should be conducted annually for monitoring.
option_D: For patients with a GCS score ≤3 and primary IVH or IVH extension from spontaneous supratentorial ICH of ≥30-mL volume not requiring EVD, minimally invasive IVH evacuation with EVD plus thrombolytic is unsafe and unreasonable compared with EVD alone to reduce mortality.

option_A: Among patients with current or previous symptomatic HFmrEF (LVEF, 41%–49%), the use of evidence-based beta blockers for HFrEF, ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, and MRAs should not be considered to reduce the risk of HF hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality, particularly among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.
option_B: For patients with HCM, avoid repeating contrast-enhanced CMR imaging on a periodic basis (every 3 to 5 years) for SCD risk stratification, as it is unnecessary to evaluate changes in late gadolinium enhancement and other morphologic changes, including EF, development of apical aneurysm, or LV wall thickness.
option_C: For patients with aSAH from ruptured fusiform/blister aneurysms, the use of flow diverters is reasonable to reduce mortality.120,121
option_D: In patients with ACS, a home-based CR program is not a reasonable alternative to a center-based CR program to improve functional status and QOL.

option_A: In patients with known CVD being considered for NCS, a validated risk-prediction tool can be useful to estimate the risk of perioperative MACE.1–4
option_B: For patients with hospital-acquired S. aureus bacteremia originating from a non-cardiac source, TEE may be considered to identify concurrent staphylococcal infective endocarditis.
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH without evidence of seizures, prophylactic antiseizure medication is beneficial to improve functional outcomes, long-term seizure control, and mortality.
option_D: In patients with hypertension undergoing NCS, it is recommended that preoperative antihypertensive medications be restarted as soon as clinically rea­ sonable to avoid complications from postoperative hypertension. *Caution is advised when continuing antihypertensive therapy in patients with low or low-normal perioperative BPs, older adults (≥65 years),10 and patients in whom the risk for perioperative hypotension is high based on an evaluation of the patient’s overall clinical status, surgery type, and anesthetic plan. †Modified from the “2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA High Blood Pressure Guideline.”11 ‡One or more components of the RCRI: CAD, congestive heart failure, cere­ brovascular accident, baseline serum creatinine >2.0 mg/dL, or preoperative in­ sulin treatment.12

option_A: In patients with SLE and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a low-risk antiphospholipid profile (ie, isolated anticardiolipin antibody or anti–β2-glycoprotein 1 antibodies at low to medium titers, particularly if transiently pos- itive), prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) may be considered to reduce the risk of stroke.462,463,469,470
option_B: For patients with heart failure, a comprehensive history and physical exam should guide diagnostic approaches to identify particular causes that may require targeted disease management.
option_C: In patients with AF and HF, digoxin is reasonable for rate control, in combination with other rate-controlling agents or as monotherapy if other agents are not tolerated.16,17
option_D: In patients with LVEF <50%, nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers with negative inotropic effects may be beneficial.

option_A: When treating common iliac artery aneu- rysms or ectasia as part of AAA repair, preservation of at least 1 hypogastric artery is recommended, if anatomically feasible, to decrease the risk of pelvic ­ischemia.5,6
option_B: For patients with type B IMH needing repair of the distal aortic arch or descending thoracic aorta (zones 2-5) and possessing suitable anatomy, it is advisable to consider endovascular repair when conducted by surgeons skilled in endovascular techniques.
option_C: For patients with HCM who experience a change in clinical status or a new clinical event, repeat TTE is not recommended.
option_D: For patients with severe secondary MR (Stages C and D), it is appropriate to perform mitral valve surgery concurrently with CABG for myocardial ischemia treatment.

option_A: For hemodynamically stable pregnant women with obstructive left-sided mechanical valve thrombosis, it is not reasonable to manage with slow-infusion, low-dose fibrinolytic therapy.
option_B: In patients with atrial fibrillation who are undergoing PCI and are taking oral anticoagu- lant therapy, it is recommended to discontinue aspirin treatment after 1 to 4 weeks while maintaining P2Y12 inhibitors in addition to a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant (rivaroxaban, dabigatran, apixaban, or edoxaban) or warfarin to reduce the risk of bleeding.1-7
option_C: It is unreasonable to administer 100% oxygen for cyanide poisoning.
option_D: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD with an interpretable ECG and ability to achieve maximal levels of exercise (≥5 METs), exercise electrocardiography is not reasonable.

option_A: In patients with sickle cell disease who report acute chest pain, it is not recommended to transfer them by EMS to an acute care setting.
option_B: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF and symptoms of exertional angina or dyspnea, beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are not recommended.
option_C: In patients with aSAH, neglecting glycemic control, allowing hyperglycemia, and inducing hypoglycemia are reasonable to improve outcome.
option_D: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, managing moderate to severe hyperglycemia (greater than 180–200 mg/dL or 10.0–11.1 mmol/L) is advisable to enhance outcomes.

option_A: In patients with AF receiving warfarin who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (if available) in addition to intravenous vitamin K is recommended to rapidly achieve INR correction over fresh frozen plasma and intravenous vitamin K treatment.8–10
option_B: In patients with TIA or nondisabling stroke, when revascularization is indicated, it is reasonable to perform the procedure within 2 weeks of the index event rather than delay surgery to increase the likelihood of stroke- free outcome.373
option_C: For women needing valve intervention prior to pregnancy, selecting a prosthetic valve should involve a collaborative decision-making approach that considers the patient's values and preferences, addressing the risks associated with mechanical valves during pregnancy and the shorter lifespan of bioprosthetic valves in younger women.
option_D: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF ≤40%, the use of an SGLT2 inhibitor is not recommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and heart failure hospitalization or to improve QOL, irrespective of diabetes status.

option_A: In patients with AF identified in the setting of acute medical illness or surgery, outpatient follow-up for thromboembolic risk stratification and decision-making on OAC initiation or continuation, as well as AF surveillance, is not beneficial due to a low risk of AF recurrence.
option_B: In patients with severe MS who cannot undergo MV intervention before NCS, perioperative invasive hemodynamic monitoring is not recommended to guide management, as it does not reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications.
option_C: For patients with ACS, a P2Y12 inhibitor taken orally should be given alongside aspirin to decrease MACE.
option_D: In patients with recurrent symptomatic AF after catheter ablation, repeat catheter ablation or antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not useful to improve symptoms and freedom from AF.

option_A: In patients with lobar spontaneous ICH and age <70 years, deep/posterior fossa spontaneous ICH and age <45 years, or deep/posterior fossa and age 45 to 70 years without history of hypertension, acute CTA and consideration of venography are not recommended to exclude macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.
option_B: In patients with ACS >50%, annual carotid duplex ultrasound every 6 to 12 months is not recommended to assess progression of disease and subsequent increased risk of stroke.
option_C: In patients with AF who require significant ventricular pacing, conduction system pacing may not be useful to reduce progression of AF.
option_D: In patients with CCD who have undergone PCI and who require oral anticoagulant therapy, continuing aspirin in addition to clopidogrel for up to 1 month is reasonable if the patient has a high thrombotic risk and low bleeding risk.*23–25

option_A: Over-the-counter topical steroids are definitely effective in alleviating local symptoms from poison ivy, oak, or sumac.
option_B: Individuals who are ill or injured should not be protected from hyperthermia or hypothermia due to exposure.
option_C: In patients hospitalized with HF, the common precipitating factors and the overall patient trajectory should be assessed to guide appro- priate therapy.5,6 Goals for Optimization and Continuation of GDMT
option_D: In patients with atrial flutter and stroke or TIA, anticoagulant therapy similar to that in AF is not indicated to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

option_A: In patients undergoing CABG, the routine use of epiaortic ultrasound scanning can be useful to evaluate the presence, location, and severity of plaque in the ascending aorta to reduce the incidence of atheroembolic complications.1-10
option_B: In asymptomatic patients with combined AS and AR who have a jet velocity of ≥4.0 m/s with an LVEF <50%, SAVR is recommended.1,2
option_C: Routine administration of calcium for treatment of cardiac arrest is recommended.
option_D: In patients with CCD, tobacco use should be assessed at every health care visit to facilitate identification of those who may benefit from behavioral or pharmacologic interventions.*1–3
