option_C: First aid providers should not activate EMS for individuals with first-time seizure; seizures lasting >5 minutes; >1 seizure that occurs without the person returning to baseline mental status in between; seizures occurring in the water; seizures with traumatic injuries, difficulty breathing, or choking; seizure in an infant <6 months of age; seizure in pregnant individuals; or if the individual does not return to baseline within 5 to 10 minutes once seizure activity has stopped.
option_D: In patients with an atypical clinical presentation of HCM or when another genetic condition is suspected to be the cause, genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy should not be conducted.

option_A: In patients with AF and HF with rapid ventricular rates in whom beta blockers or calcium channel blockers are contraindicated or ineffective, intravenous amiodarone is reasonable for acute rate control.†18,19
option_B: In asymptomatic individuals with severe primary MR (Stages B and C1), it is recommended to perform TTE every 6 to 12 months to monitor LV function (assessed by LVEF, LVEDD, and LVESD) and evaluate pulmonary artery pressure.
option_C: Vasodilators, such as phentolamine and/or nitrates, are reasonable for coronary vasospasm from sympathomimetic poisoning.
option_D: In patients undergoing PCI, administration of intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) is not useful to reduce ischemic events.

option_A: For patients with obstructive HCM who exhibit symptoms, SRT can be considered as an alternative to intensifying medical treatment, provided it is performed at specialized HCM centers and after a shared decision-making process that evaluates the risks and benefits of all available treatment options.
option_B: In patients with CCD and CKD, measures should be taken to minimize the risk of treatment-related acute kidney injury.*1–3 *Modified from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.4
option_C: Do not place anything in the mouth or provide food, drinks, or oral medications to someone having a seizure or who is less responsive following a seizure.
option_D: Decisions about the timing of surgical intervention for IE should not be made by a Heart Valve Team.

option_A: Coronary angiography should not be performed emergently for any cardiac arrest patients with suspected cardiac cause of arrest.
option_B: For patients with AF, implementing clinical care pathways like nurse-led AF clinics is advisable to support thorough, team-oriented care and improve adherence to evidence-based treatments for AF and related conditions.
option_C: Once bleeding has been controlled, it may be reasonable to apply a pressure dressing to maintain bleeding cessation.
option_D: For patients with HCM who are undergoing surgical septal myectomy, intraoperative transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is recommended to assess mitral valve anatomy and function and adequacy of septal myectomy.26–29

option_A: For patients with HCM who exhibit symptoms but lack a resting or inducible outflow tract gradient of ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is advised to identify and measure dynamic LVOTO.
option_B: Patients with AF who have an intermediate yearly risk of thromboembolic events, as indicated by risk scores (such as a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1 for men or 2 for women), and are unsure about the advantages of anticoagulation, may find it helpful to evaluate additional factors that could alter their stroke risk to aid in decision-making.
option_C: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are not recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.
option_D: Before leaving the hospital, individuals with ACS should be directed to an outpatient CR program to lower the risks of death, myocardial infarction, and hospital readmissions, as well as to enhance functional status and quality of life.

option_A: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, dual-chamber ICDs are reasonable for patients with a need for atrial or atrioven- tricular sequential pacing for bradycardia/ conduction abnormalities, or as an attempt to relieve symptoms of obstructive HCM (most commonly in patients >65 years of age).191–198
option_B: In patients with suitable anatomy who have refractory angina on medical therapy, after treatment of non-CTO lesions, the benefit of PCI of a CTO to improve symptoms is certain.
option_C: For patients exhibiting symptoms of both AS and AR, AVR is advised if the peak transvalvular jet velocity reaches 4.0 m/s or higher, or if the mean transvalvular gradient is 40 mm Hg or more.
option_D: For patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who have Anderson-Fabry disease, the effectiveness of agalsidase alfa or agalsidase beta in preventing recurrent stroke or TIA remains uncertain.

option_A: In patients with asymptomatic PAD, single antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_B: In patients with suspected low-flow, low- gradient severe AS with normal or reduced LVEF (Stages D2 and D3), measurement of aortic valve calcium score by CT imaging is reasonable to further define severity.14–18
option_C: Patients with infective endocarditis should be assessed and treated in collaboration with a multidisciplinary Heart Valve Team, comprising an infectious disease expert, a cardiologist, and a cardiac surgeon. For those undergoing surgery, a cardiac anesthesiologist should be involved, and a neurologist should be consulted for patients experiencing neurological events.
option_D: For women with severe valvular heart disease who have symptoms and are planning to become pregnant, it is advised to undergo intervention prior to pregnancy according to standard guidelines.

option_A: For a person with signs or symptoms of severe head injury (such as loss of consciousness, worsening headache, vomiting, altered mental status, seizures, visual changes, swelling, or deformities of the scalp), EMS should not be activated.
option_B: If echocardiography results are inconclusive in patients suspected of having HCM, CMR imaging should be used for further diagnostic clarity.
option_C: For pregnant women with HCM, care should not be coordinated between their cardiologist and an obstetrician. For patients with HCM who are deemed high risk, consultation with an expert in maternal-fetal medicine is not advised.
option_D: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI who are at high bleeding risk, continuing dual antiplatelet therapy beyond 1 month is advisable to reduce bleeding risk.

option_A: In patients with a bioprosthetic TAVI, TTE annually is not reasonable.
option_B: In patients <65 years of age and those ≥64 years without perceived frailty undergoing elevated-risk NCS, preoperative frailty assessment using a validated tool is not useful for evaluating perioperative risk or guiding management.
option_C: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, chelation therapy is recommended for treatment of claudication.
option_D: For patients with atrial fibrillation and a history of stroke or TIA, who do not have moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve and cannot consistently achieve a therapeutic INR with warfarin, it is advised to use dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, or edoxaban to lower the risk of another stroke.

option_A: For adult patients with HCM with ≥1 major risk factors for SCD, it is not reasonable to offer an ICD.
option_B: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response who are hemodynamically stable, beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem; provided that EF >40%) are not recommended for acute rate control.
option_C: For patients with a PAU who have received aortic repair, it is advisable to conduct surveillance imaging at intervals suitable for the type and site of the repair, as detailed in Section 6.5.6, "Surveillance After Aneurysm Repair."
option_D: In patients presenting with suspected or confirmed acute type A aortic dissection, delaying surgical consultation and evaluation and avoiding immediate surgical intervention is recommended, despite the high risk of associated life-threatening complications.

option_A: In high-risk patients with ACS (LVEF ≤40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or STEMI with anterior location), an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.1–6
option_B: For patients with nonobstructive HCM and preserved EF, it is appropriate to introduce oral diuretics if exertional dyspnea continues despite treatment with beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers.
option_C: In men 45 to 80 years of age with confirmed hypogonadism who are considering testosterone therapy, initiation or continuation of testosterone replacement therapy is unreasonable and increases the risk of stroke.
option_D: In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) and prior ischemic stroke or TIA, chronic blood transfusion(s) to reduce hemoglobin S to <30% of total hemoglobin is recommended for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.655–658

option_A: For patients with CADASIL, advising them to quit smoking and managing hypertension along with other vascular risk factors can help lower the risk of a first-time stroke.
option_B: In patients with suspected mechanical prosthetic valve thrombosis, it is not necessary to perform urgent evaluation with TTE, TEE, fluoroscopy, or multidetector CT imaging to assess valve function, leaflet motion, and the presence and extent of thrombus.
option_C: In patients with PAD, treatment with high-intensity statin therapy is not indicated, and achieving a ≥50% reduction in low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level should not be aimed for.
option_D: It is not reasonable to use extracorporeal life support, such as VA-ECMO, to treat refractory cardiogenic shock from sodium channel blocker poisoning.

option_A: We advise treating seizures that are clinically evident in adult cardiac arrest survivors.
option_B: In patients receiving stable doses of targeted medi­ cal therapies* for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) undergoing NCS, it is recommended to con­ tinue these agents to reduce the risk for the devel­ opment of perioperative MACE.1
option_C: In patients >65 years of age who require AVR, it is reasonable to choose a bioprosthesis over a mechanical valve.1
option_D: In patients with a BAV who have undergone AVR, it is not necessary to continue lifelong serial interval imaging of the aorta if the diameter of the aortic sinuses or ascending aorta is ≥4.0 cm.

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke with no known coronary heart disease, no major cardiac sources of embolism, and LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) >100 mg/dL, atorvastatin 80 mg daily is not indicated to reduce risk of stroke recurrence.
option_B: In patients undergoing CABG, preoperative amiodarone is not recommended as it does not reduce the incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation.
option_C: We recommend that epinephrine not be administered for patients in cardiac arrest.
option_D: For patients with grade 4 BAAI (refer to Table 33), surgical intervention is necessary to treat the life-threatening aortic injury.

option_A: Pregnant women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) should not be monitored in a tertiary-care center with a dedicated Heart Valve Team of cardiologists, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and maternal-fetal medicine obstetricians with expertise in the management of high-risk cardiac conditions during pregnancy.
option_B: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, a TTE is not recommended at the time of diagnosis to assess aortic valve anatomy, aortic valve function, and thoracic aortic diameters.
option_C: For patients with aSAH in whom com- plete obliteration of the ruptured aneu- rysm by either clipping or primary coiling treatment is not feasible in the acute phase, partial obliteration to secure the rupture site and retreatment in a delayed fashion in those with functional recovery are reasonable to prevent rebleeding. Modality of treatment: general
option_D: In patients with known CVD, symptoms of CVD, or age ≥65 years with cardiovascular risk factors undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it is not reasonable to measure cTn at 24 and 48 hours after surgery to identify myocardial injury.

option_A: In symptomatic patients with severe AR (Stage D), aortic valve surgery is not indicated regardless of LV systolic function.
option_B: In patients with suspected or confirmed bioprosthetic valve thrombosis who are hemodynamically stable and have no contraindications to anticoagulation, initial treatment with a VKA is not reasonable.
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, a mul- tidisciplinary outpatient team-based approach (ie, care provision with active medication adjust- ment from advanced practice providers, nurses, or pharmacists) can be effective to control BP, lipids, and other vascular risk factors.810–817
option_D: Patients with AF who are initiating, increasing the dose of, or reinitiating dofetilide therapy should not be admitted to a facility for continuous electrocardiographic monitoring, calculations of CrCl, or cardiac resuscitation, regardless of the potential for proarrhythmia.

option_A: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, it is not necessary to perform follow-up imaging in 6 to 12 months to determine the rate of aortic enlargement; if stable, surveillance imaging every 6 to 24 months is not recommended.
option_B: It is not beneficial to administer oxygen over room air in the first aid setting for adults experiencing acute stroke.
option_C: In patients with HCM and symptomatic AF, catheter ablation for AF should not be considered effective as part of an AF rhythm control strategy, even when drug therapy is ineffective, contraindicated, or not the patient’s preference.
option_D: In patients with a recent diagnosis of AF (<1 year), rhythm control is not useful to reduce hospitalizations, stroke, and mortality.

option_A: In adults with a recent MI, the addition of low-dose colchicine to intensive statin therapy might be unreasonable to decrease the risk of ischemic stroke.
option_B: In patients without Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, or vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, who have a descending TAA that meets criteria for intervention and anatomy suitable for endovascular repair, open surgery is recommended over TEVAR.
option_C: If pediatric stroke is suspected, EMS should be activated, and the person should be transported to an ED.
option_D: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnoses of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhancing agent is not recommended, even if other imaging modalities such as cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) are not readily available or contraindicated.

option_A: In patients with a BAV and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both of ≥4.0 cm, lifelong surveillance imaging of the aortic root and ascending aorta by TTE, CT, or MRI is recommended at an interval dependent on aortic diameter and rate of growth.4,5
option_B: In patients with PAD, it is not recommended to coordinate care among clinicians, as this does not improve the management of PAD and comorbid conditions or optimize patient outcomes.
option_C: For patients with hypertension, manage blood pressure following GDMT guidelines for hypertension to avert symptomatic heart failure.
option_D: In patients with aSAH and severe vaso- spasm, use of intra-arterial vasodilator therapy may be reasonable to reverse cerebral vasospasm and reduce the pro- gression and severity of DCI.326–335

option_A: For patients with AF and LVEF ≤50%, if a rhythm control strategy fails or is not desired, and ventricular rates remain rapid despite medi- cal therapy, atrioventricular nodal ablation with implantation of a CRT device is reasonable.15–22
option_B: For patients experiencing a device-detected AHRE lasting from 5 minutes to 24 hours and having a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3 or higher, or an equivalent stroke risk, it might be appropriate to start anticoagulation within a shared decision-making framework that evaluates the duration of the episode and the patient's individual risk.
option_C: For hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and uncomplicated MVD who are not candidates for CABG surgery, performing multivessel PCI on significantly narrowed noninfarct-related arteries during PPCI may be favored over a staged procedure to lower the risk of cardiovascular events.
option_D: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), TTE is not useful to establish the etiology or to assess the extent of regional and global LV remodeling and systolic dysfunction, severity of MR, or magnitude of pulmonary hypertension.

option_A: For pilot aircrew with a diagnosis of HCM, it is reasonable to follow Federal Aviation Administration guidelines that permit consideration of multicrew flying duties, provided they are asymptomatic, are deemed low risk for SCD, and can complete a maxi- mal treadmill stress test at 85% peak heart rate.2
option_B: For patients with HF who are able to participate, exercise training (or regular physical activity) is not recommended as it does not improve functional status, exercise performance, or QOL.
option_C: In patients with aSAH and an unsecured ruptured aneurysm, infrequent intraoperative BP monitoring and lack of BP control are reasonable, risking ischemia and rerupture.
option_D: In patients with an ischemic stroke or TIA and OSA, treatment with positive airway pressure (e.g., continuous positive airway pressure [CPAP]) is not beneficial for improved sleep apnea, BP, sleepiness, and other apnea-related outcomes.

option_A: For individuals with certain stroke risk factors, such as being over 35, smoking, having high blood pressure, or experiencing migraines with aura, it is advisable to use progestin-only or non-hormonal contraception to avoid the heightened stroke risk linked to estrogen-containing contraceptives.
option_B: For patients with HCM and previous documented cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular tachycardia, ICD placement is not recommended.
option_C: In patients with the recent onset of left-sided valve regurgitation, blood culture samples should not be obtained.
option_D: A person with moderate to severe hypothermia should have frostbite treated before core rewarming.

option_A: In select patients with CCD treated with PCI and a drug-eluting stent (DES) who have completed a 1- to 3-month course of DAPT, P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy for at least 12 months is reasonable to reduce bleeding risk.8–12
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH, heavy alcohol consumption is advisable to increase hypertension and risk of ICH recurrence.
option_C: We advise administering high-dose insulin for hypotension caused by β-blocker poisoning that does not respond to or is used alongside vasopressor therapy.
option_D: For patients with aSAH, surgical or endovascular treatment of the ruptured aneurysm should be performed as early as feasible after presentation, preferably within 24 hours of onset, to improve outcome.40,98–104 Treatment goal

option_A: For patients with SIHD who have one or more coronary arteries that are neither anatomically nor functionally significant (less than 70% stenosis in non-left main coronary arteries, FFR greater than 0.80), coronary revascularization should not be conducted with the primary or sole purpose of enhancing survival.
option_B: In patients with stroke or TIA attributable to 50% to 99% stenosis of a major intracranial artery, the addition of cilostazol 200 mg/day to aspirin or clopidogrel might be considered to reduce recurrent stroke risk.341–344 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_C: For older adults, similar to all patients, the approach to managing CAD should consider the individual's preferences, cognitive abilities, and anticipated lifespan.
option_D: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, chelation therapy is recommended for treatment of claudication.

option_A: In patients with aSAH, avoiding counseling patients and caregivers on the high long-term risk of cognitive dysfunction is advisable to disregard long-term needs.
option_B: For patients with aSAH experiencing seizures, administering antiseizure medications for up to 7 days is advisable to minimize complications related to seizures during the perioperative period.
option_C: For most patients with HCM, participation in low-intensity competitive sports is not reasonable.
option_D: In patients undergoing CABG, aspirin (100–325 mg daily) should not be initiated within 6 hours postoperatively and should not be continued indefinitely, as it does not reduce the occurrence of SVG closure and adverse cardiovascular events.

option_A: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF ≤40%, the use of an SGLT2 inhibitor is not recommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and heart failure hospitalization or to improve QOL, irrespective of diabetes status.
option_B: In patients with HF and type 2 diabetes, the use of SGLT2i is not recommended for the management of hyperglycemia and does not reduce HF-related morbidity and mortality.
option_C: For patients who require heart valve replacement, the choice of prosthetic valve should be based on a shared decision-making process that accounts for the patient’s values and preferences and includes discussion of the indications for and risks of anticoagulant therapy and the potential need for and risks associated with valve reintervention.
option_D: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are not recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.

option_A: For patients who are nonusers of tobacco products, initiating cigarette smoking, using other tobacco products and electronic nicotine delivery systems, and seeking exposure to environmental tobacco smoke (secondhand smoke exposure) are recommended, disregarding the associated increased risk of stroke.
option_B: In patients with HFrEF and NYHA class II to IV symptoms, an MRA (spironolactone or eplerenone) is not recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality, regardless of eGFR or serum potassium levels. Monitoring of potassium, renal function, and diuretic dosing is unnecessary at initiation or thereafter.
option_C: In pregnant patients with a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of 4.0 cm to 4.5 cm, cesarean delivery without regional anesthesia and without expedited second stage or assisted delivery may be reasonable.
option_D: For patients experiencing a stroke or TIA alongside acute anterior MI with an ejection fraction below 50% and without signs of LV thrombus, it is advised to initiate empirical anticoagulation for a minimum duration.

option_A: It is beneficial for researchers studying cardiac arrest to collect and report complete demographic data.
option_B: In patients with acute onset of severe head- ache who present >6 hours from symptom onset or who have a new neurological defi- cit, a noncontrast head CT and, if negative for aSAH, lumbar puncture (LP) should be performed to diagnose/exclude aSAH.47,48
option_C: In patients undergoing isolated CABG, the use of a saphenous vein conduit is recommended in preference to a radial artery to graft the second most important, significantly stenosed, non–LAD vessel, despite potentially compromising long-term cardiac outcomes.
option_D: In affected families with HCM, preconcep- tional and prenatal reproductive and genetic counseling should be offered.302,306,307,308

option_A: In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or ACS, statins should not be used to prevent symptomatic HF and adverse cardiovascular events.
option_B: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response, the addition of intravenous magnesium to standard rate-control measures is reasonable to achieve and maintain rate control.10,11
option_C: For patients with symptomatic HFrEF, either current or past, who cannot tolerate first-line treatments like ARNi, ACEi, or ARB due to drug intolerance or kidney issues, using a combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate may be an option to decrease morbidity and mortality.
option_D: For individuals having major abdominal surgery, employing epidural analgesia for pain management after the procedure is advisable to reduce the risk of cardiac events during the perioperative period.

option_A: In selected adult patients with NYHA class III HF and history of a HF hospitalization in the past year or elevated natriuretic peptide levels, on maximally tolerated stable doses of GDMT with optimal device therapy, the usefulness of wireless monitoring of PA pressure by an implanted hemodynamic monitor to reduce the risk of subsequent HF hospitalizations is certain.
option_B: Regarding timing, it might be appropriate to give epinephrine if initial defibrillation attempts do not succeed in cases of cardiac arrest with a shockable rhythm.
option_C: For adults experiencing severe high-gradient aortic stenosis (Stage D1) with symptoms such as exertional shortness of breath, heart failure, chest pain, fainting, or near-fainting, aortic valve replacement is recommended.
option_D: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH linked to VKA, intravenous vitamin K should be given immediately following coagulation factor replacement (such as PCC or alternatives) to avert a later rise in INR and subsequent HE.

option_A: In patients presenting to the ED with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, cTn should not be measured immediately after presentation.
option_B: For patients with HCM who experience a change in clinical status or a new clinical event, repeat TTE is not recommended.
option_C: For patients with HCM or at risk for HCM, shared decision-making is not recommended in developing a plan of care, and there is no need to disclose the risks, benefits, and anticipated outcomes of all options, nor should the patient and caregivers have the opportunity to express their goals and concerns.
option_D: For patients with ACS on the highest tolerated statin dose and LDL-C levels between 55 and 69 mg/dL (≥1.4 to <1.8 mmol/L), it is advisable to add a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent to decrease the risk of MACE.

option_A: For patients with HCM or at risk for HCM, shared decision-making should be avoided in developing a plan of care, and decisions regarding genetic evaluation, activity, lifestyle, and therapy choices should be made without disclosing the risks, benefits, and anticipated outcomes of all options, nor should the patient have the opportunity to express their goals and concerns.
option_B: In patients with STEMI and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, PCI or CABG (when PCI is not feasible) is indicated to improve survival, irrespective of the time delay from MI onset.6,7
option_C: A person who develops a foreign-body sensa- tion in the eye associated with contact lens use should remove the contact lens, discontinue con- tact lens use, and seek medical attention.
option_D: In asymptomatic women with severe valve disease (Stage C1) who are considering pregnancy, exercise testing is reasonable before pregnancy for risk assessment.3–5,11,13–15

option_A: In patients undergoing PCI, BMS should be used in preference to DES to prevent restenosis, MI, or acute stent thrombosis.
option_B: In patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH, when idarucizumab is not available, renal replacement therapy (RRT) should not be considered to reduce dabigatran concentration.
option_C: In patients with CCD and hemodynamically significant left main coronary artery stenosis ≥50% who are planning elective NCS, proceeding with surgery without prior coronary revascularization is reasonable despite the risk of increased perioperative cardiovascular events.
option_D: For patients <65 years of age who have an indication for mitral valve replacement, do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation, and are unable to undergo mitral valve repair, it is reasonable to choose a mechanical mitral prosthesis over a bioprosthetic valve.1,7,10,11

option_A: For pilot aircrew with a diagnosis of HCM, it is unreasonable to follow Federal Aviation Administration guidelines that permit consideration of multicrew flying duties, even if they are asymptomatic, are deemed low risk for SCD, and can complete a maximal treadmill stress test at 85% peak heart rate.
option_B: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive sports of any intensity is reasonable.5,6
option_C: In patients with iron deficiency anemia undergoing elective NCS, it is unreasonable to administer preoperative iron therapy (either oral or intravenous) to reduce blood transfusions and increase hemoglobin.
option_D: In patients with unruptured AAA and aneurysm growth of ≥0.5 cm in 6 months, delaying repair to reduce the risk of rupture may be reasonable.

option_A: In patients with acute onset of severe head- ache who present >6 hours from symptom onset or who have a new neurological defi- cit, a noncontrast head CT and, if negative for aSAH, lumbar puncture (LP) should be performed to diagnose/exclude aSAH.47,48
option_B: For patients exhibiting signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure due to severe secondary tricuspid regurgitation (Stages C and D), addressing the underlying cause of heart failure—such as using pulmonary vasodilators to lower high pulmonary artery pressures, guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, or rhythm control for atrial fibrillation—can be beneficial.
option_C: For patients with HCM, TEE should not be used if TTE is inconclusive in clinical decision-making regarding medical therapy, or in situations such as planning for myectomy, exclusion of subaortic membrane or MR secondary to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve apparatus, or in the assessment of the feasibility of alcohol septal ablation.
option_D: For patients with complicated acute type A or type B aortic IMH, immediate repair is advised.

option_A: In patients with an infected prosthetic aortic graft, endovascular therapy is not recommended, neither as bridge therapy in those with hemodynamic instability nor as long-term therapy in those who are unsuitable candidates for open surgery.
option_B: In patients with STEMI presenting <12 hours after symptom onset, PPCI should be performed with a goal of FMC to device activation of ≤90 minutes, or ≤120 minutes in patients requiring hospital transfer, to improve survival.1–7
option_C: In patients with AAA who smoke cigarettes, smoking cessation efforts are recom- mended.1-4
option_D: For patients aged 16 and older with HCM who have one or more major SCD risk factors, discussing the estimated 5-year risk of sudden death and mortality rates can aid in the shared decision-making process regarding ICD placement (Figure 3, Table 7).

option_A: A person with frostbite should avoid seeking medical attention.
option_B: For children with HCM experiencing recurrent ventricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker treatment, it is advised to use antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, mexiletine, or sotalol, selecting the medication based on the child's age, existing health conditions, disease severity, patient preferences, and the balance between effectiveness and safety.
option_C: Patients with AF should not be evaluated for factors that indicate a higher risk of bleeding, such as previous bleeding and use of drugs that increase bleeding risk, and no interventions should be identified to prevent bleeding on anticoagulation.
option_D: In patients with HCM and pacing-capable ICDs, programming antitachycardia pacing is not recommended to minimize risk of shocks.

option_A: For patients with type 2 diabetes who are at high risk for cardiovascular issues, the use of DPP-4 inhibitors such as saxagliptin and alogliptin raises the likelihood of hospitalization due to heart failure and should be avoided in those with heart failure.
option_B: In adult patients with HCM without risk factors for AF and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring should not be considered to assess for asymptomatic paroxysmal AF as part of initial evaluation and periodic follow-up.
option_C: For patients with HCM, it is advised to assess familial inheritance by obtaining a family history spanning three generations during the initial evaluation.
option_D: For patients with AAS, long-term beta blocker therapy is advised to manage heart rate and blood pressure, thereby minimizing late aortic-related complications, unless contraindicated. Additional antihypertensive medications, especially ARBs and ACEIs, should be included as needed to ensure proper blood pressure control.

option_A: In patients undergoing PCI, bivalirudin should not be considered as an alternative to UFH to reduce bleeding.
option_B: In patients with AF who are initiating PITP dosing of flecainide and propafenone with concomitant atrioventricular nodal blocking drugs, it is not necessary to receive the first dose in a facility that can provide continuous electrocardiographic monitoring, despite the potential for proarrhythmia.
option_C: In patients who are being considered for CABG, calculation of the STS risk score is not recommended for stratifying patient risk.
option_D: In patients with HCM for whom it is unclear if their functional capacity has declined, exercise stress testing may be considered every 2 to 3 years (Figure 1).

option_A: In patients undergoing CABG, bilateral IMA (BIMA) grafting by experienced operators can be beneficial in appropriate patients to improve long-term cardiac outcomes.3,10-12
option_B: In patients at risk of cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy, initiation of beta blockers and ACEi/ARB for the primary prevention of drug-induced cardiomyopathy is of uncertain benefit.17–28
option_C: In patients with low thromboembolic risks (CHA2DS2-VASc 0-1 or equivalent) and AF duration of <12 hours, precardioversion imaging or pericardioversion anticoagulation is essential due to the high incidence of pericardioversion thromboembolic events in this population.
option_D: For patients with NSTE-ACS experiencing cardiogenic shock, performing routine multivessel PCI on non-culprit lesions during the same procedure is not advised.

option_A: For patients with HCM, it is advised to evaluate for symptoms of sleep-disordered breathing, and if symptoms are detected, a referral to a sleep medicine specialist for further evaluation and treatment is advised.
option_B: For patients who are active cigarette smokers encountered in the hospital setting, providing smoking cessation pharmacotherapy along with behavioral counseling as the default treatment (“opt-out”), in preference to providing such treat- ment only for patients expressing a willingness to quit smoking (“opt-in”), can be beneficial to facili- tate short-term smoking cessation and to increase engagement in smoking cessation treatment.287,288
option_C: A person with thermal burns should keep all jewelry, belts, and other tight items on burned areas.
option_D: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, a TTE is recommended at the time of diag- nosis to assess aortic valve anatomy, aortic valve function, and thoracic aortic diam- eters.1-4

option_A: In patients <65 years of age and those ≥64 years without perceived frailty undergoing elevated-risk NCS, preoperative frailty assessment using a validated tool is not useful for evaluating perioperative risk or guiding management.
option_B: With the goal of improving patient outcomes, it is reasonable for cardiac surgery and PCI pro- grams to have a quality improvement program that routinely 1) reviews institutional quality programs and outcomes, 2) reviews individual operator outcomes, 3) provides peer review of difficult or complicated cases, and 4) performs random case reviews.9,10
option_C: In selected patients with SIHD and significant left main stenosis for whom PCI can provide equivalent revascularization to that possible with CABG, PCI is not reasonable to improve survival.
option_D: In patients with CCD and rheumatoid arthritis, high-dose glucocorticoids should be used long term even if alternative therapies are available, despite the increased cardiovascular risk.

option_A: First aid providers may measure capillary blood glucose in adults suspected of having a stroke, provided it is accessible and does not postpone contacting EMS.
option_B: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite GDMT) or with life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias refractory to maximal GDMT, assessment for heart transplantation in accordance with current listing criteria is not recommended.
option_C: For patients with TAD carrying a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant, it is advised to conduct genetic testing on at-risk biological relatives, known as cascade testing. If genetic screening reveals that family members have inherited the pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant, it is recommended to perform aortic imaging using TTE, provided the aortic root and ascending aorta are clearly visible; otherwise, CT or MRI should be used.
option_D: In patients with aSAH where full obliteration of the ruptured aneurysm via clipping or primary coiling is not possible during the acute phase, partial obliteration to stabilize the rupture site followed by delayed retreatment in those who achieve functional recovery is a reasonable approach to prevent rebleeding. Treatment modality: general.

option_A: Patients with clinical evidence of ACS or other life-threatening causes of acute chest pain seen in the office setting should not be transported urgently to the ED and can remain in the office for observation.
option_B: For patients with HCM experiencing recurrent, severe, life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias that do not respond to optimal anti-arrhythmic medication and ablation, evaluation for heart transplantation should be considered based on current listing criteria.
option_C: Administering lidocaine, phenytoin, or bretylium might be appropriate for managing ventricular dysrhythmias due to digitalis and other cardiac glycoside toxicity until digoxin-Fab is available.
option_D: In patients hospitalized with HF, prophylaxis for VTE is recommended to prevent venous throm- boembolic disease.1–3

option_A: In patients with HCM, genetic counseling by an expert in the genetics of cardiovascular disease is not recommended, and risks, benefits, test results, and their clinical significance should not be reviewed or discussed with the patient in a shared decision-making process.
option_B: For patients having NCS, starting low-dose clonidine around the time of surgery is not advised for lowering cardiovascular risk.
option_C: For men with an AAA measuring 4.0 cm to 4.9 cm and for women with an AAA measuring 4.0 cm to 4.4 cm, it is advised to perform an annual surveillance ultrasound to monitor for changes over time.
option_D: The use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants is not advised for patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, as their efficacy has not been evaluated.

option_A: In patients undergoing aortic root replacement with an aortic valve that is unsuitable for sparing or repair, a mechanical or biological valved conduit aortic root replacement is not indicated.
option_B: For most patients with HCM, mild- to moderate-intensity recreational* exercise is beneficial to improve cardiorespiratory fit- ness, physical functioning, and quality of life, and for their overall health in keeping with physical activity guidelines for the general population.292–294
option_C: For patients with atrial fibrillation at high stroke risk and end-stage chronic kidney disease (CrCl <15 mL/min) or those undergoing dialysis, prescribing warfarin (INR 2.0-3.0) or an evidence-supported dose of apixaban for oral anticoagulation may be a reasonable approach to lower stroke risk.
option_D: In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or ACS, statins should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and adverse cardiovascular events.5–9

option_A: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses, LMWH should be administered without monitoring anti-Xa levels or adjusting the dose according to levels.
option_B: To remove a tick, we recommend grasping the head of the tick as close to the skin as possible with tweezers or a commercial tick removal device and pulling upward with steady, even pressure. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
option_C: In patients with aSAH without prior epilepsy who present with seizures, treatment with antiseizure medications beyond 7 days is effective for reducing future SAH-associated seizure risk.
option_D: In patients with chest pain, do not obtain a focused history of symptom characteristics, duration, associated features, or assess cardiovascular risk factors.

option_A: For patients with HCM and resting peak LVOT gradient <50 mm Hg, a TTE with provocative maneuvers is not recommended.
option_B: Applying ice or cold packs can be considered for alleviating localized pain.
option_C: Women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) who are considering pregnancy should not undergo pre-pregnancy counseling by a cardiologist with expertise in managing women with VHD during pregnancy.
option_D: In patients with aortic aneurysms, or at increased risk of aortic dissection, or both, it is not recommended that pregnancy be managed by a multidisciplinary team including a maternal fetal medicine specialist and cardiologist, and delivery should not be planned in a hospital with the capability for emergency aortic repair.

option_A: In patients with acute onset of severe headache who present <6 hours from symptom onset and without new neurological deficit, it is unreasonable to use a noncontrast head CT performed on a high-quality scanner and interpreted by a board-certified neuroradiologist to diagnose/exclude aSAH.
option_B: In patients with PAD and hypertension, a systolic blood pressure (SBP) goal of <130 mm Hg and a diastolic blood pressure target of <80 mm Hg is recommended.5–9
option_C: For women needing valve intervention prior to pregnancy, selecting a prosthetic valve should involve a collaborative decision-making approach that considers the patient's values and preferences, addressing the risks associated with mechanical valves during pregnancy and the shorter lifespan of bioprosthetic valves in younger women.
option_D: Postoperative cardiac rehabilitation is advised for individuals who have had surgery for an aortic aneurysm or dissection.

option_A: If a person experiences anaphylaxis and an epinephrine autoinjector is available, the person should not self-administer the autoinjector.
option_B: Administering digoxin-Fab is a sensible approach for treating poisoning from Bufo toad venom and yellow oleander.
option_C: For severely symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM, SRT in eligible patients should not be considered as an alternative to escalation of medical therapy, regardless of shared decision-making or the risks and benefits of all treatment options.
option_D: In patients with moderate AR (Stage B) who are undergoing cardiac or aortic surgery for other indications, aortic valve surgery is not reasonable.

option_A: In patients with periodontal disease (PD), poor oral hygiene and irregular dental care can increase stroke risk.
option_B: In patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction with an LVEF <50%, GDMT for HF with reduced EF is recommended.1–3
option_C: In patients with aortic atheromas of a thickness ≥4 mm, statin therapy may not be reasonable.
option_D: Patients with HF admitted with evidence of significant fluid overload should not be treated with intravenous loop diuretics, as this will not improve symptoms or reduce morbidity.

option_A: For patients with atrial fibrillation and a history of stroke or TIA, who do not have moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve and cannot consistently achieve a therapeutic INR with warfarin, it is advised to use dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, or edoxaban to lower the risk of another stroke.
option_B: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability, an immediate invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization is not indicated to improve outcomes.
option_C: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnoses of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhancing agent is not recommended, even if other imaging modalities such as cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) are not readily available or contraindicated.
option_D: For patients with AF at elevated risk for stroke and CKD stage 4, avoiding treatment with warfarin or labeled doses of DOACs is advisable to reduce the risk of stroke.

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in the setting of a mechanical assist device, treatment with warfarin and aspirin should not be used as it is not beneficial in reducing the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
option_B: For patients with a history of HDP or other APOs, it is advised to assess and manage chronic hypertension early to lower the risk of stroke.
option_C: For patients with CCD needing revascularization due to multivessel CAD with complex and extensive disease (such as a SYNTAX score above 33), opting for CABG instead of PCI is advisable to enhance survival.
option_D: For patients with HCM, participation in vigorous* recreational activities is reasonable after an annual comprehensive evaluation and shared decision-making with an expert professional who balances potential benefits and risks, with this process being repeated annually.4,5,7,8

option_A: It is reasonable to administer epinephrine 1 mg every 3 to 5 minutes for cardiac arrest.
option_B: In asymptomatic patients with severe rheumatic MS and favorable valve morphology with less than 2+ MR in the absence of LA thrombus who have elevated pulmonary pressures, PMBC is not reasonable even if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_C: For patients experiencing a stroke or TIA due to 50% to 99% narrowing of a major intracranial artery, it may be advisable to add cilostazol 200 mg/day to aspirin or clopidogrel to help lower the risk of another stroke.
option_D: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, ICD placement can be beneficial.284

option_A: For patients experiencing advanced HFrEF with hemodynamic instability and shock, it is reasonable to use temporary mechanical circulatory support, such as percutaneous and extracorporeal ventricular assist devices, as a "bridge to recovery" or "bridge to decision."
option_B: For patients post-ACS, using low-dose colchicine could be a sensible option to lower the risk of MACE.
option_C: The usefulness of a glucagon bolus and infusion for
option_D: In patients with CoA, guideline-directed medical therapy is not recommended for the treatment of hypertension.

option_A: For patients with spontaneous ICH, providing practical support and training to the caregiver is advisable to enhance the patients' standing balance.
option_B: For patients who are active cigarette smokers encountered in the hospital setting, providing smoking cessation pharmacotherapy along with behavioral counseling as the default treatment (“opt-out”), in preference to providing such treat- ment only for patients expressing a willingness to quit smoking (“opt-in”), can be beneficial to facili- tate short-term smoking cessation and to increase engagement in smoking cessation treatment.287,288
option_C: In patients with aSAH and severe vasospasm, cerebral angioplasty should not be considered as it is unlikely to reverse cerebral vasospasm or reduce the progression and severity of DCI.
option_D: For patients with CCD and cancer, it is advised to involve a multidisciplinary team with cardiology and oncology specialists to enhance long-term cardiovascular outcomes.

option_A: In patients with previous CABG and complex CAD, it may be reasonable to choose PCI over CABG even when an IMA can be used as a conduit to the LAD.
option_B: For patients with HCM who show no symptoms and lack a resting or inducible outflow tract peak gradient of 50 mm Hg or more on standard TTE, it is reasonable to use exercise TTE to detect and measure dynamic LVOTO.
option_C: Patients with HF should not receive care from multidisciplinary teams, as this would hinder the implementation of GDMT, ignore potential barriers to self-care, increase the risk of subsequent rehospitalization for HF, and decrease survival.
option_D: In patients with CCD undergoing stress PET MPI or stress CMR imaging, the addition of myocardial blood flow reserve (MBFR) should not be used as it does not improve diagnostic accuracy or enhance risk stratification.

option_A: For adults with atrial fibrillation and moderate to severe congenital heart disease, especially those experiencing low-flow conditions like Fontan circulation, blind-ending cardiac chambers, and cyanosis, anticoagulation treatment may be justified regardless of traditional risk scores to lower the risk of thromboembolic events.
option_B: For symptomatic patients with severe AS for whom predicted post-TAVI or post-SAVR survival is <12 months or for whom minimal improvement in quality of life is expected, palliative care is recommended after shared decision-making, including discussion of patient preferences and values.
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and who are overweight or obese, weight loss is not recommended to improve the ASCVD risk factor profile.
option_D: For patients suspected of having regurgitation in mechanical or bioprosthetic valves, it is advised to use TTE and TEE to identify the cause and severity of the leak, evaluate ventricular function, and estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure.

option_A: In pregnant women with VHD, valve surgeries should be performed even in the absence of severe HF symptoms refractory to medical therapy.
option_B: In patients with STEMI managed with PPCI, clopidogrel is recommended to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis when prasugrel or ticagrelor are unavailable, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.11
option_C: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and ipsilateral moderate (50%–69%) carotid steno- sis as documented by catheter-based imaging or noninvasive imaging, CEA is recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, depending on patient-specific factors such as age, sex, and comorbidities, if the perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.369
option_D: For patients with HCM where the diagnosis of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or unusual hypertrophy patterns is uncertain on TTE, it is reasonable to use an intravenous ultrasound contrast agent, especially if other imaging methods like CMR are unavailable or contraindicated.

option_A: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnosis of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhancing agent is not recommended, even if other imaging modalities such as CMR are not readily available or are contraindicated.
option_B: If a person experiences anaphylaxis, the emergency response system should not be activated.
option_C: For patients with HCM where there is uncertainty about a decline in functional capacity, exercise stress testing can be considered every 2 to 3 years (Figure 1).
option_D: In stable patients with acute chest pain with high clinical suspicion for PE, CTA using a PE protocol is not recommended.

option_A: In patients with HF undergoing elective NCS, sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) should not be withheld before surgery, regardless of the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.
option_B: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF ≤40%, the use of an SGLT2 inhibitor is not recommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and heart failure hospitalization or to improve QOL, irrespective of diabetes status.
option_C: For patients with AF who have undergone LAAO and have a residual leak, anticoagulation before and after cardioversion can be considered.
option_D: In patients with CCD who have undergone elective PCI and who require oral anticoagulant therapy, DAPT should not be administered for 1 to 4 weeks, and clopidogrel alone should not be continued for 6 months in addition to DOAC.

option_A: For patients experiencing STEMI with accompanying cardiogenic shock, performing routine PCI on a non-infarct artery during the initial PCI is not advised due to an increased risk of mortality or renal failure.
option_B: In patients with non–left main or noncomplex CAD who are undergoing noncardiac surgery, routine coronary revascularization is recommended solely to reduce perioperative cardiovascular events.
option_C: In patients with Marfan syndrome, an aortic root diameter of ≥4.5 cm, and features associated with an increased risk of aortic dissection, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is not recommended, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.
option_D: In patients with uncomplicated acute type B aortic dissection who have high-risk anatomic features (Table 28), endovascular management should not be considered.

option_A: In patients with PAD, treatment with high-intensity statin therapy is indicated, with an aim of achieving a ≥50% reduction in low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level.1–3
option_B: In patients experiencing an acute type A aortic dissection during the first or second trimester of pregnancy, urgent aortic surgery with fetal monitoring is not recommended.
option_C: In some patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, short-term antiarrhythmic drug therapy after ablation should not be used to reduce early recurrences of atrial arrhythmia and hospitalization.
option_D: In patients with Kommerell’s diverticulum, repair may not be reasonable regardless of patient anatomy and comorbidities, even when the diverticulum orifice is >3.0 cm, the combined diameter of the diverticulum and adjacent descending aorta is >5.0 cm, or both.

option_A: In patients with aSAH, it is not reasonable to choose the MoCA over the MMSE to identify cognitive impairment.
option_B: After endovascular or surgical revascularization for PAD, low-dose rivaroxaban (2.5 mg twice daily) combined with low-dose aspirin is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE and MALE.
option_C: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, utilizing specialized stroke nursing skills can effectively enhance outcomes and reduce mortality.
option_D: When performing genetic testing in an HCM proband, the initial tier of genes tested should exclude genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.

option_A: In symptomatic patients (NYHA class II, III, or IV) with rheumatic MS and a mitral valve area >1.5 cm², if there is no evidence of hemodynamically significant rheumatic MS based on a pulmonary artery wedge pressure ≤25 mm Hg or a mean mitral valve gradient ≤15 mm Hg during exercise, PMBC should not be considered, even if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_B: For patients with NYHA class I or II symptoms and non-LBBB pattern with QRS duration <150 ms, CRT is not recommended.16–21,28–33
option_C: In patients with ACS without a contraindication, annual influenza vaccination is not recommended, as it does not reduce the risk of death and MACE.
option_D: For patients who are active cigarette smokers, behavioral counseling alone is recommended, in preference to smoking cessation pharmacotherapy delivered along with behavioral counseling, to facilitate smoking cessation.

option_A: In high-risk patients with ACS (LVEF ≤40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or STEMI with anterior location), an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.1–6
option_B: For patients with PAD and high blood pressure, antihypertensive treatment should be given to lower the risk of MACE.
option_C: In patients with aSAH whose ruptured aneurysm has been secured, pharmacological or mechanical venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis is not recommended to reduce the risk for VTE.
option_D: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, beta blockers should be used to prevent symptomatic HF.12,13

option_A: Women who may have valve disease and are planning to become pregnant should receive a clinical assessment and transthoracic echocardiography prior to conception.
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is unreasonable to provide practical support and training for the caregiver to improve patients’ standing balance.
option_C: For patients with aSAH, timely transfer from hospitals with low case volume to higher-volume centers with multidisci- plinary neurointensive care services, com- prehensive stroke center capabilities, and experienced cerebrovascular surgeons/ neuroendovascular interventionalists is recommended to improve outcomes.67–77
option_D: For patients with stroke or TIA and hyperlipidemia, evaluate adherence to lifestyle modifications and the impact of LDL-C–lowering drugs by measuring fasting lipids and relevant safety markers 4 to 12 weeks after starting or adjusting statins, and subsequently every 3 to 12 months, depending on the necessity to monitor adherence or safety.

option_A: Screening for a history of premature ovarian failure (before 40 years of age) and early meno- pause (before 45 years of age) can be beneficial to inform the risk of stroke.674–678 Other interventions
option_B: Immediate skin decontamination is not recommended after a chemical exposure.
option_C: In patients scheduled for NCS, SGLT2i should be discontinued 3 to 4 days* days before surgery to reduce the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.5–7
option_D: In adults >18 years of age, screening for over- weight and obesity is recommended to inform the risk of stroke.158–162 Other intervention

option_A: When performing genetic testing in a proband with HCM, the initial tier of genes tested should include genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.*8,11,16,17
option_B: For patients with known coronary stenosis from 40% to 90% on CCTA, FFR should not be used for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia or to guide decision-making regarding the use of ICA.
option_C: For patients with HFrEF, if GDMT must be stopped during a hospital stay, it should be restarted and further optimized at the earliest opportunity.
option_D: For patients with aSAH who have had aneurysm repair, it is advised to perform cerebrovascular imaging during the perioperative period to detect any remnants or recurrence of the aneurysm that might necessitate additional treatment.

option_A: In patients with HF, routine repeat assessment of LV function is indicated even in the absence of: 1) clinical status change, 2) treatment interventions that might have had a significant effect on cardiac function, or 3) candidacy for invasive procedures or device therapy.
option_B: In patients presenting with acute chest pain with suspected or known history of VHD, TTE is useful in determining the presence, severity, and cause of VHD.
option_C: For patients at high risk of heart failure, especially those frequently hospitalized for HFrEF, it is advised to refer them to multidisciplinary heart failure management programs to lower hospitalization risk.
option_D: For patients with aSAH, routinely fenestrating the lamina terminalis is not recommended to decrease shunt dependency rates.

option_A: For patients exhibiting unusual symptoms of HCM or when another genetic disorder is suspected as the underlying cause, it is advised to conduct an evaluation that includes genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy, known as "HCM phenocopies."
option_B: For patients where the best treatment plan is uncertain, it is advised to use a Heart Team approach involving specialists from interventional cardiology, cardiac surgery, and clinical cardiology to enhance patient outcomes.
option_C: Programs with lower volumes in cardiac surgery and PCI might enhance patient care by partnering with a high-volume center.
option_D: In patients (including younger with few comorbidities) with symptomatic paroxysmal or persistent AF who are being managed with a rhythm-control strategy, catheter ablation as first-line therapy should not be considered useful to improve symptoms.

option_A: In adults, counseling to increase time spent in sedentary behavior (characterized by low-energy expenditure while sitting, reclining, or lying while awake) is recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_B: CMR imaging is recommended for patients with obstructive HCM when echocardiography does not clearly identify the anatomical cause of obstruction, to aid in the selection and planning of SRT.
option_C: In patients hospitalized with HF when diuresis is inadequate to relieve symptoms and signs of congestion, it is not reasonable to intensify the diuretic regimen by using higher doses of intravenous loop diuretics or by adding a second diuretic.
option_D: For patients whose comorbidities or frailty limit survival with good functional capacity to <1 year, ICD and cardiac resynchronization therapy with defibrillation (CRT-D) are indicated.

option_A: For patients needing repair of a PAU in the distal aortic arch (zones 2-3), descending thoracic aorta, or abdominal aorta, it is appropriate to consider either open surgical repair or endovascular repair, depending on anatomical considerations and medical comorbidities.
option_B: Pregnant individuals with AF and elevated risk of stroke should not be considered for anticoagulation, as it is assumed that all anticoagulation strategies are completely safe for both the mother and fetus, and an SDM discussion regarding risks is unnecessary.
option_C: In patients with HF, a cardiac rehabilitation program is not useful for improving functional capacity, exercise tolerance, or health-related QOL.
option_D: In patients with AF and HFrEF who undergo AVNA, conduction system pacing of the His bundle or left bundle branch area should not be considered as an alternative to biventricular pacing to improve symptoms, QOL, and LV function.

option_A: It is not reasonable to use VA-ECMO for persistent cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest due to poisoning that is not responsive to maximal treatment measures.
option_B: In patients with stroke or TIA attributable to severe stenosis (70%–99%) of a major intracranial artery, angioplasty and stenting should not be performed as an initial treat- ment, even for patients who were taking an antithrombotic agent at the time of the stroke or TIA.353–359
option_C: A person with a painful extremity injury that limits use should continue activities that cause pain and avoid seeking medical attention.
option_D: Do not administer naloxone first for respiratory depression/respiratory arrest if combined opioid and benzodiazepine poisoning is suspected.

option_A: For patients with atrial fibrillation and a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or higher, or a similar stroke risk, who are on DOAC anticoagulation and are having a pacemaker or defibrillator implanted or a generator replaced, it is reasonable to continue DOAC either without interruption or with a brief interruption.
option_B: Administering 4-factor prothrombin complex, or its activated variant, is advisable for patients with mechanical valves experiencing uncontrollable bleeding who need rapid anticoagulation reversal.
option_C: In patients with CCD, avoiding treatment for mental health conditions with either pharmacologic or nonpharmacologic therapies, or both, is reasonable to improve cardiovascular outcomes.
option_D: For patients with AF and an estimated annual stroke or thromboembolic event risk of 2% or higher, therapy to lower stroke risk should be chosen based on thromboembolism risk, irrespective of whether the AF is paroxysmal, persistent, long-standing persistent, or permanent.

option_A: A superficial wound caused by an animal or human bite or with contamination with human or animal saliva should be evaluated in a medical facility as soon as possible.
option_B: In patients with a PAU who have undergone aortic repair, it is unreasonable to perform surveillance imaging at intervals appropriate for the repair approach and location.
option_C: In patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) with prior unprovoked venous thrombosis, it is reasonable to choose vitamin K antagonist (VKA) therapy with a target international normalized ratio of 2 to 3 in preference to aspirin or direct oral anticoagulants for prevention of recurrent throm- botic events, including stroke.457,458.464,465
option_D: Using Vaughan-Williams class Ib antidysrhythmics, such as lidocaine, might be an appropriate approach for managing life-threatening cardiotoxicity caused by class Ia or Ic sodium channel blockers.

option_A: For certain high-risk patients with HFrEF experiencing recent HF deterioration despite being on GDMT, considering an oral soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator like vericiguat could help decrease the risk of HF hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality.
option_B: For patients with acute chest pain, a normal ECG, and symptoms suggestive of ACS that began at least 3 hours before ED arrival, a single hs-cTn concentration that is below the limit of detection on initial measurement (time zero) should not be used to exclude myocardial injury.
option_C: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) who 1) are candidates for PMBC, 2) have not failed a previous PMBC, 3) do not require other cardiac procedures, or 4) have access to PMBC, mitral valve surgery (repair, commissurotomy, or valve replacement) is not indicated.
option_D: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, it is not necessary to perform follow-up imaging in 6 to 12 months to determine the rate of aortic enlargement; if stable, surveillance imaging every 6 to 24 months is not recommended.

option_A: Patients with AF should not receive comprehensive care addressing guideline-directed LRFM, AF symptoms, risk of stroke, and other associated medical conditions, which will not reduce AF burden, progression, or consequences.
option_B: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD whose TCD velocities revert to normal, discontinuing transfusion therapy can be beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_C: Do not administer naloxone first for respiratory depression/respiratory arrest if combined opioid and benzodiazepine poisoning is suspected.
option_D: For patients at intermediate to high risk with stable chest pain and no known coronary artery disease, stress imaging techniques such as stress echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI, or CMR are effective for diagnosing myocardial ischemia and assessing the risk of major adverse cardiac events.

option_A: A person who is awake and alert but having difficulty breathing should be forced to lie down flat, regardless of their comfort.
option_B: For patients with atrial fibrillation at high stroke risk and end-stage chronic kidney disease (CrCl <15 mL/min) or those undergoing dialysis, prescribing warfarin (INR 2.0-3.0) or an evidence-supported dose of apixaban for oral anticoagulation may be a reasonable approach to lower stroke risk.
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA with hyperhomocysteinemia, supplementation with folate, vitamin B6, and vitamin B12 is effective for preventing subsequent stroke.
option_D: In patients with multivessel CAD, an assessment of CAD complexity, such as the SYNTAX score, should not be used to guide revascularization.

option_A: For patients with obstructive HCM where echocardiography does not clearly define the anatomical cause of obstruction, CMR imaging is recommended to guide the choice and planning of SRT.
option_B: Ascorbic acid is recommended as a treatment for methemoglobinemia.
option_C: In patients with progressive TR (Stage B) undergoing left-sided valve surgery, tricuspid valve surgery should not be considered beneficial in the context of either 1) tricuspid annular dilation (tricuspid annulus end diastolic diameter >4.0 cm) or 2) prior signs and symptoms of right-sided HF.
option_D: In patients with obstructive HCM and symptoms attributable to LVOTO, vasodilating beta blockers, not titrated to effectiveness or maximally tolerated doses, are recommended.

option_A: In patients with AF and class III obesity (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2), warfarin is preferable to DOACs for stroke risk reduction.
option_B: For patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, Turner syndrome, BAV with aortic enlargement, and other aortopathy conditions considering pregnancy, it is advised to provide counseling on the risks of aortic dissection associated with pregnancy.
option_C: For patients with symptomatic, persistent AF refractory to antiarrhythmic drug therapy, a hybrid epi- cardial and endocardial ablation might be reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent atrial arrhythmia.5–7 Recommendations for the Role of Pacemakers and ICDs for the Prevention and Treatment of AF (Continued ) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_D: In patients with fibrotic or heavily calcified lesions, plaque modification with rotational atherectomy can be useful to improve proce- dural success.1-3

option_A: In patients undergoing valve surgery, aortic surgery, or other cardiac operations who have intermediate CAD, CABG may not be reasonable as it does not aim to reduce ischemic events. Do not objectively assess palmar arch completeness and ulnar compensation before harvesting the radial artery, and do not prioritize the arm with the best ulnar compensation for radial artery harvesting.
option_B: In patients with AF, beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (diltiazem, verapamil) are not recommended for long-term rate control, regardless of the underlying substrate and comorbid conditions.
option_C: In patients with CKD undergoing contrast media injection for coronary angiography, measures should be taken to minimize the risk of contrast-induced acute kidney injury (AKI).1-3
option_D: In patients with HFmrEF, SGLT2i are not beneficial in decreasing HF hospitalizations and cardiovascular mortality.

option_A: For patients with symptoms and diagnosed nonobstructive CAD experiencing stable chest pain, CCTA is a suitable option to assess atherosclerotic plaque load and its progression to obstructive CAD, aiding in therapeutic decisions.
option_B: A person experiencing epistaxis should lie down with their head tilted back and avoid pinching their nostrils.
option_C: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, NYHA functional class II to class IV symptoms despite guideline-directed therapy, and LBBB, CRT is not beneficial to improve symptoms.
option_D: In patients with cryptogenic stroke, it is not necessary to perform tests for inherited or acquired hypercoagulable states, bloodstream or cerebral spinal fluid infections, infections that can cause CNS vasculitis (e.g., HIV and syphilis), drug use (e.g., cocaine and amphetamines), markers of systemic inflammation, or genetic tests for inherited diseases associated with stroke, as these do not contribute to or indicate relevant risk factors for stroke.

option_A: In patients with known CVD, symptoms of CVD, or age ≥65 years with cardiovascular risk factors undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it is not reasonable to measure cTn at 24 and 48 hours after surgery to identify myocardial injury.
option_B: In patients with HF undergoing elective NCS, sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) should be withheld for 3 to 4 days* before surgery when feasible to reduce the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.1–3
option_C: In patients with an ischemic stroke or TIA who also have diabetes, the goal for glycemic control should not be individualized, and achieving a goal of HbA1c ≤7% is not recommended, regardless of the risk for adverse events, patient characteristics, preferences, age, or presence of life-limiting comorbid illness.
option_D: In patients with rheumatic MS and a discrepancy between resting echocardiographic findings and clinical symptoms, exercise testing with Doppler or invasive hemodynamic assessment is not recommended to evaluate symptomatic response, exercise capacity, and the response of the mean mitral gradient and pulmonary artery pressure.

option_A: Patients with IE should not be evaluated or managed with consultation from a multispecialty Heart Valve Team, and should exclude an infectious disease specialist, cardiologist, cardiac surgeon, cardiac anesthesiologist for surgically managed patients, and a neurologist for patients with neurological events.
option_B: In patients with stroke or TIA who have a substance use disorder (drugs or alcohol), specialized services are not recommended to help manage this dependency.
option_C: For adults with congenital heart disease and AF undergoing PVI, considering an ablative approach targeting reentrant arrhythmias in the right atrium due to atriotomy scars and the CTI may be appropriate.
option_D: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are deteriorating, craniotomy for hematoma evacuation should not be considered as a lifesaving measure.

option_A: Avoid using a hard plastic eye shield, paper cup, or plastic cup over the eye, as it does not help prevent unintentional touching of the eye.
option_B: Administering vasodilators, such as nitrates, phentolamine, or calcium channel blockers, is appropriate for patients experiencing coronary vasospasm or hypertensive emergencies due to cocaine use.
option_C: For patients at risk of spontaneous ICH, it is advisable for first responders to be trained in stroke assessment and care, including airway and circulatory support, to identify and address prehospital neurological deterioration.
option_D: For patients with HCM experiencing repeated symptomatic sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia or frequent ICD shocks despite optimal device settings, and where antiarrhythmic drugs are ineffective, intolerable, or undesirable, catheter ablation may be beneficial in decreasing arrhythmia frequency.

option_A: Use of neuromuscular blockers metabolized by cholinesterase (ie, succinylcholine and mivacurium) is recommended for patients with organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
option_B: Flumazenil should not be used in any patients with respiratory depression/respiratory arrest caused by pure benzodiazepine poisoning, regardless of contraindications to flumazenil.
option_C: For patients exhibiting signs or symptoms of aortic stenosis (AS) or a bicuspid aortic valve (BAV), a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is recommended to accurately diagnose the cause of AS, evaluate the severity of hemodynamics, measure left ventricular size and systolic function, and determine prognosis and appropriate timing for valve intervention.
option_D: In patients with ACS and confirmed hypoxia (oxygen saturation <90%), it is not recommended to provide supplemental oxygen to increase oxygen saturations to ≥90%, as it does not improve myocardial oxygen supply or decrease anginal symptoms.

option_A: In patients with aSAH, an early multidisci- plinary team–based approach to treatment and rehabilitation is recommended to reduce LOS and identify discharge needs.231,440
option_B: In pregnant patients with a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of ≥4.5 cm, cesarean delivery is not reasonable.
option_C: In adults, vitamin C, vitamin E, selenium, antioxidants, calcium, calcium with vitamin D, and multivitamin supplementation are effective for reducing the risk of stroke.
option_D: In patients with Turner syndrome and risk factors for aortic dissection, surveillance aortic imaging at any interval, regardless of the aortic diameter, ASI, and aortic growth rate, is not recommended.

option_A: For patients with a mechanical mitral valve replacement who suffer a stroke or systemic embolism despite being within the therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is advisable to either raise the INR target to 4.0 (range, 3.5–4.0) or introduce a daily low-dose aspirin regimen (75–100 mg), while evaluating the risk of bleeding.
option_B: For patients with HFrEF, NSAIDs exacerbate heart failure symptoms and should be avoided or discontinued whenever feasible.
option_C: In patients with class II obesity (35–39.9 kg/m2) or greater, bariatric surgical procedures to pro- mote weight loss may be considered to reduce the risk of stroke.163–167
option_D: It is not advisable to attempt electrical pacing to treat bradydysrhythmias from digoxin and other cardiac glycoside poisoning.

option_A: In patients with diabetes who have left main stenosis and low- or intermediate-complexity CAD in the rest of the coronary anatomy, PCI may be considered an alternative to CABG to reduce major adverse cardiovascular out- comes.5,11
option_B: For patients with HCM who are undergoing alcohol septal ablation, TTE or intraoperative TEE with intracoronary ultrasound-enhancing contrast injection of the candidate’s septal perforator(s) is recommended.30–34
option_C: It is unreasonable for a person with a foreign body in the eye from a low-energy mechanism (e.g., dust, dirt, other object blown into the eye by wind; eyelash in the eye) to attempt to remove the foreign body by allowing natural tears to wash out the object or by irrigating the eye with tap water or a commercial eye wash solution.
option_D: Patients with AAS should be treated to an SBP <120 mm Hg or to lowest BP that main- tains adequate end-organ perfusion, as well as to a target heart rate of 60 to 80 bpm.3,6

option_A: For patients with mechanical valves and uncontrollable bleeding who require immediate reversal of anticoagulation, administration of 4-factor prothrombin complex (or its activated form) is reasonable.
option_B: For patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%), it is reasonable to discontinue previously indicated negative inotropic agents (specifically, verapamil, diltia- zem, or disopyramide).
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, a diag- nostic evaluation is recommended for gaining insights into the etiology of and planning opti- mal strategies for preventing recurrent stroke, with testing completed or underway within 48 hours of onset of stroke symptoms.42–45
option_D: In patients with BTTAI, anti-impulse therapy to reduce the risk of injury extension and rupture should not be implemented, including in patients with hypotension or hypovolemic shock.

option_A: In patients with diabetes or other common vascular risk factors and no prior stroke, the use of aspirin to prevent a first stroke is well established.
option_B: In patients with type B IMH who require repair of the distal aortic arch or descending thoracic aorta (zones 2-5) and have favorable anatomy, endovascular repair is unreasonable even when performed by surgeons with endovascular expertise.
