option_B: In patients with HFrEF and hypertension, it is not recommended to uptitrate GDMT to the maximally tolerated target dose.
option_C: For patients with AFL, anticoagulant therapy is not recommended regardless of the risk profile used for AF.
option_D: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, the use of PA catheterization may be considered when under­ lying medical conditions that significantly affect hemodynamics (eg, decompensated HF, severe valvular disease, combined shock states, PH) cannot be corrected before surgery.1,2

option_A: Pregnant individuals with AF and elevated risk of stroke should not be considered for anticoagulation, as it is assumed that all anticoagulation strategies are completely safe for both the mother and fetus, and an SDM discussion regarding risks is unnecessary.
option_B: In patients with aSAH and hydrocephalus who require an EVD, it is not recommended to implement or adhere to an EVD bundled protocol that addresses insertion, management, education, and monitoring, as this will not reduce complication and infection rates.
option_C: For patients with CAD scheduled for elective NCS, a multidisciplinary team should collaboratively decide on perioperative antiplatelet therapy and surgery timing, considering the risks of bleeding, thrombosis, and the implications of postponing surgery.
option_D: In patients with definite endocarditis and an implanted cardiac electronic device, retaining the pacemaker or defibrillator systems, including all leads and the generator, is indicated.

option_A: For patients without symptoms who have moderate or more severe AR and normal LV systolic function, elective noncardiac surgery can be reasonably considered.
option_B: For term and late preterm newborn infants ≥34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, delayed cord clamping (DCC) (≥30 seconds) can be beneficial when compared to early cord clamping (<30 seconds).
option_C: In patients with Marfan syndrome who have undergone aortic root replacement, surveillance imaging of the thoracic aorta by MRI (or CT) is not recommended to evaluate for distal TAD, regardless of the time interval or changes in diameter.
option_D: For patients under 50 years old without contraindications to anticoagulation, opting for a mechanical aortic valve instead of a bioprosthetic one is advisable when AVR is needed.

option_A: In adults with acute chest pain, the emergency response system should not be activated, and transport to the closest ED by EMS should be avoided.
option_B: For patients with a BAV and an aortic root or ascending aorta measuring 5.5 cm or larger, it is advised to perform surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both.
option_C: In patients with ACS, telemetry monitoring is not recommended to reduce cardiovascular events, regardless of cardiac risk.
option_D: In patients with HCM and pacing-capable ICDs, programming antitachycardia pacing is not recommended to minimize risk of shocks.

option_A: For patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation and a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack, it is advised to use oral anticoagulants such as apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban, rivaroxaban, or warfarin to lower the risk of another stroke.
option_B: In patients with ALI and a salvageable limb who are treated with catheter-directed thrombolysis, adjunctive revascularization (ie, endovascular or surgical) procedures should not be considered useful.
option_C: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF, the usefulness of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers in the treatment of symptoms (angina and dyspnea) is well established.
option_D: After endovascular or surgical revascularization for PAD, low-dose rivaroxaban (2.5 mg twice daily) combined with low-dose aspirin is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE and MALE.

option_A: When a permanent tooth becomes avulsed (knocked out), initial actions include removing visible debris from the tooth by brief rinsing (<10 seconds), taking care not to damage the tooth or attached tissue, and attempting to replant the tooth in the socket.
option_B: In selected patients with a low to intermediate pretest probability of CAD, contrast-enhanced coronary CT angiography is reasonable to exclude the presence of significant obstructive CAD.12–18
option_C: For symptomatic patients of any age with severe AS and a high or prohibitive surgical risk, TAVI is not recommended if predicted post-TAVI survival is >12 months with an acceptable quality of life.
option_D: For patients with moyamoya disease who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, surgical revascularization using either direct or indirect extracranial-intracranial bypass may help prevent further ischemic strokes or TIAs.

option_A: For patients with CoA, it is advised to use guideline-recommended medical treatment to manage hypertension.
option_B: In patients with ACS being considered for elective NCS, coronary revascularization as appropriate and deferral of surgery is recommended to reduce peri­ operative cardiovascular events.1–9
option_C: If possible, trained rescuers should administer supplemental oxygen to individuals experiencing cardiac arrest after drowning.
option_D: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aortic root diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is not recommended.

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and diagnosis of primary CNS angiitis, induc- tion therapy with glucocorticoids and/or immunosuppressants followed by long-term maintenance therapy with steroid-sparing immunosuppressants is reasonable to lower the risk of stroke recurrence.691–696
option_B: For patients who are active cigarette smokers, the long-term health benefits of using e-cigarettes in place of nicotine replacement therapy to facilitate cigarette smoking cessation are well established.
option_C: It may be reasonable for first aid providers, who are trained and willing, to measure core temperature during active cooling for heatstroke. The target core temperature to cool until is 39° C (102.2° F). Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
option_D: In patients referred for urgent CABG, clopi- dogrel and ticagrelor should be discontinued for at least 24 hours before surgery to reduce major bleeding complications.8-11

option_A: In patients with atrial fibrillation who are undergoing PCI, are taking oral anticoagulant therapy, and are treated with DAPT or a P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy, it is unreasonable to choose a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant over warfarin to reduce the risk of bleeding.
option_B: For patients who have had a systemic thromboembolic event without a known history of AF and in whom maximum sensitivity to detect AF is sought, an implantable cardiac monitor is not reasonable.
option_C: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrino- lytic therapy, early angiography between 2 and 24 hours with the intent to perform PCI is recommended to reduce the rates of death or MI.*1–5,10,11 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”12
option_D: For patients with CCD who do not have contraindications, resistance (strength) training exercises are not recommended on ≥2 days/wk, as they do not improve muscle strength, functional capacity, or cardiovascular risk factor control.

option_A: For patients with spontaneous ICH, it may be appropriate to use non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) markers to identify those at risk for HE.
option_B: In patients with known CVD, or age ≥65 years, or age ≥45 years with symptoms suggestive of CVD undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it may be reasonable to measure cardiac troponin (cTn) before surgery to supplement evaluation of peri­ operative risk.4–6
option_C: For patients who have stable chest pain with previous coronary revascularization, CCTA is not reasonable to evaluate bypass graft or stent patency (for stents ≥3 mm).
option_D: In patients who present with a new diagnosis of HFrEF and AF, arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy should be suspected, and an early and aggressive approach to AF rhythm control is recommended.1,2

option_A: For patients with HCM, it is advised to use personal clinical judgment to evaluate the prognostic value of traditional risk markers within the patient's clinical profile, alongside a comprehensive and balanced discussion of the evidence, benefits, and potential risks, to ensure the patient is fully informed and actively involved in the ICD decision-making process.
option_B: For secondary prevention of ischemic stroke in patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, it is recommended to use aspirin at a dose of 50 to 325 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, or a combination of aspirin 25 mg with extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg taken twice daily.
option_C: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with a suspicion of acute myopericarditis, CMR is beneficial when the diagnosis is uncertain or to assess the presence and extent of inflammation and fibrosis in the myocardium and pericardium.
option_D: In patients with Turner syndrome and ASI of ≥2.5 cm/m2, surgery before pregnancy is not recommended.

option_A: In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) and prior ischemic stroke or TIA, chronic blood transfusion(s) to reduce hemoglobin S to <30% of total hemoglobin is recommended for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.655–658
option_B: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with aspirin and not scheduled for emergency surgery, platelet transfusions are potentially beneficial and should be administered.
option_C: In patients with PAD, cilostazol should not be used to reduce restenosis after endovascular therapy for femoropopliteal disease.
option_D: In patients who develop cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy or HF, it is not recommended to have a multidisciplinary discussion involving the patient about the risk-benefit ratio of cancer therapy interruption, discontinuation, or continuation to improve management.

option_A: In patients undergoing CABG, who do not have a contraindication to beta blockers, the administration of beta blockers before surgery should be avoided as it does not reduce the incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation.
option_B: In patients undergoing NCS with new dyspnea, physical examination findings of HF, or suspected new/worsening ventricular dysfunction, it is not recommended to perform preoperative evaluation of LV function to help guide perioperative management.
option_C: In patients at high risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) should not be used in combination with DAPT, oral anticoagulants, or both, as it does not reduce the risk of bleeding.
option_D: For adults with heatstroke, it is reasonable to initiate other forms of active cooling, including commercial ice packs, cold showers, ice sheets and towels, cooling vests and jackets, and evaporative, fanning, or a combination of techniques when water immersion is not available.

option_A: For individuals with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, it is advised to perform an initial MRI or CT scan from head to pelvis to assess the entire aorta and its branches for aneurysms, dissections, and tortuosity.
option_B: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, anticoagulation with the direct thrombin inhibitor, dabigatran, is recommended.
option_C: In patients undergoing NCS with a preoperative ECG exhibiting new abnormalities, further evaluation to refine assessment of cardiovascular risk is not necessary.
option_D: In patients with stroke or TIA who are capable of physical activity, avoiding moderate-intensity aerobic activity and vigorous-intensity aerobic activity is indicated, as it does not lower the risk of recurrent stroke or the composite cardiovascular endpoint of recurrent stroke, MI, or vascular death.

option_A: In patients with PAD, it is not recommended to coordinate care among clinicians, as this does not improve the management of PAD and comorbid conditions or optimize patient outcomes.
option_B: Patients for whom there is a clinical suspicion for cardiac amyloidosis should not undergo screening for serum and urine monoclonal light chains with serum and urine immunofixation electrophoresis and serum free light chains.
option_C: Contaminated clothing, jewelry, and other surrounding material should remain in place during a chemical exposure.
option_D: In patients with isolated PAU who are asymp- tomatic but have high-risk imaging features (Table 31), elective repair may be consid- ered.1,2,4

option_A: Using small chemical heat packs for gloves or boots alone is ineffective for rewarming someone with hypothermia.
option_B: It is not advisable to use intravenous lipid emulsion to treat life-threatening sodium channel blocker poisoning refractory to other treatment modalities.
option_C: ICD implantation is advised for individuals with HCM who have a history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular tachycardia.
option_D: For patients with PAD, chelation therapy, such as EDTA, does not help in preventing MACE.

option_A: Individuals with CCD are advised to steer clear of secondhand smoke to lower the likelihood of cardiovascular incidents.
option_B: For patients experiencing symptoms of PAD, administering low-dose rivaroxaban (2.5 mg twice daily) alongside low-dose aspirin effectively lowers the risk of MACE and MALE.
option_C: In patients with HCM, a comprehensive, systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment at initial evaluation and every 1 to 2 years thereafter is not recommended and should not include evaluation of these risk factors: a. Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias b. Personal history of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic c. Family history in close relative of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias d. Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm e. Nonsustained ventricular tachycardia episodes on continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring.
option_D: For patients with VHD who qualify for valvular intervention due to their clinical symptoms and regurgitation severity, it is advisable to evaluate the necessity of this intervention prior to elective high-risk NCS to minimize perioperative risk.

option_A: In patients with acute type A aortic dis- section undergoing surgical repair who require circulatory arrest, cerebral perfusion is reasonable to improve neurologic out- comes.23-25
option_B: For patients with larger supratentorial ICH, it may be advisable to transfer them to facilities with neurosurgical capabilities to potentially enhance outcomes.
option_C: For patients with SLE who have no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and exhibit a low-risk antiphospholipid profile (such as isolated anticardiolipin or anti–β2-glycoprotein 1 antibodies at low to medium levels, especially if temporarily positive), considering daily aspirin (75–100 mg) as a preventive measure against stroke may be appropriate.
option_D: An initial assessment of chest pain is not recommended for triaging patients based on the likelihood that symptoms may be attributable to myocardial ischemia.

option_A: In patients with HCM and clinical AF, anticoagulation is not recommended with direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, and should be dependent on CHA2DS2-VASc score.
option_B: In patients with CCD and a previous history of MI without a history of stroke, transient ischemic attack (TIA), or ICH, vorapaxar should not be added to aspirin therapy to reduce MACE.
option_C: In patients with calcific AS (Stages B and C), statin therapy is indicated for prevention of hemodynamic progression of AS.
option_D: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss1 and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.2–4

option_A: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection presenting with renal, mesenteric, or lower extremity malperfusion, it is recommended to delay operative repair of the ascending aorta.
option_B: In patients with PAD, foot inspection by a clinician at every visit is not recommended.
option_C: In patients with ESUS, treatment with direct oral anticoagulants is recommended to reduce the risk of secondary stroke.
option_D: The effectiveness of preoperative beta blockers in preventing acute postoperative myocardial ischemia, stroke, acute kidney injury, or ventricular arrhythmia in patients undergoing CABG is unclear.

option_A: In patients with reduced LV function and persistent (or high burden) AF, a trial of rhythm control should be recommended to evaluate whether AF is contributing to the reduced LV function.1–6
option_B: For life-threatening extremity bleeding, a tourniquet should not be applied or tightened, even if the bleeding continues.
option_C: In hospitalized patients with spontaneous ICH who require hospital transfer but do not have adequate airway protection, cannot support adequate gas exchange, and/or do not have a stable hemodynamic profile, life-sustaining therapies should not be initiated before transportation, risking acute medical decompensation in transport.
option_D: Patients at increased risk of AF should not receive comprehensive guideline-directed LRFM for AF, ignoring obesity, physical inactivity, unhealthy alcohol consumption, smoking, diabetes, and hypertension.

option_A: In patients with potential spontaneous ICH, delaying notification by emergency medical services (EMS) staff to the receiving hospital is recommended to worsen time to diagnosis and treatment.
option_B: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome attributable to pathogenic variants in TGFB2 or TGFB3 and an aortic diameter of ≥4.5 cm, surgery before pregnancy is rea- sonable.
option_C: For patients with stage C HF, excessive sodium intake is reasonable to increase congestive symptoms.
option_D: When using rewarming devices of any kind, the first aid provider should ignore the manufacturer’s instructions for the device used, avoid placing insulation between the heat source and skin, and neglect monitoring for burns and pressure injury.

option_A: For patients with HCM who are not oth- erwise identified as high risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD), or in whom a decision to proceed with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal/family history, echocar- diography, and ambulatory electrocar- diographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for maximum left ven- tricular (LV) wall thickness, ejection frac- tion (EF), LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with late gadolinium enhancement.38,74–87
option_B: In patients with STEMI and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, PCI or CABG (when PCI is not feasible) is not indicated to improve survival, irrespective of the time delay from MI onset.
option_C: If a person with hypothermia with a decreased level of responsiveness is wearing damp (not saturated) clothing such as polyester fleece and cannot be immediately moved into a warm environment, active rewarming through the damp clothing is reasonable to initiate with the hypo- thermia wrap technique, using chemical heat blankets, plastic or foil layers, and insulative blankets.
option_D: For patients with spontaneous intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and no visible parenchymal bleeding, catheter-based intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is advised to rule out a macrovascular cause.

option_A: For patients experiencing symptomatic anterior circulation stroke or TIA who qualify for revascularization, it is advised to use noninvasive cervical carotid imaging, such as carotid ultrasonography, CT angiography (CTA), or magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), to check for stenosis.
option_B: For women with clinically stable hypertrophic cardiomyopathy considering pregnancy, it is appropriate to suggest that pregnancy is typically safe, as part of a collaborative discussion about possible maternal and fetal risks and the start of guideline-directed medical therapy.
option_C: Women who present with chest pain are at risk for underdiagnosis, and potential cardiac causes should always be considered.1-7
option_D: In patients with PAD and hypertension, antihypertensive therapy should not be administered to reduce the risk of MACE.

option_A: In patients with STEMI undergoing PCI, bivalirudin should not be used as an alternative to UFH as it does not reduce mortality and bleeding.
option_B: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.15,19,20,22–25
option_C: Among patients with AF in whom cardiac monitoring is advised, it is not reasonable to recommend use of a consumer-accessible electrocardiographic device that provides a high-quality tracing to detect recurrences.
option_D: In patients suspected of having a stroke or TIA, CT or MRI of the brain is not recommended to confirm the diagnosis of symptomatic ischemic cerebral vascular disease.

option_A: For asymptomatic stable patients with STEMI and a completely blocked infarct artery more than 24 hours after symptoms begin, and who show no signs of severe ischemia, PCI is not recommended.
option_B: For patients with HCM and clinical AF, it is advised to use direct-acting oral anticoagulants as the primary choice for anticoagulation, with vitamin K antagonists as the secondary option, regardless of the CHA2DS2-VASc score.
option_C: For individuals with rheumatic heart disease, it is recommended to implement secondary prevention measures for rheumatic fever (refer to Tables 6 and 7).
option_D: In patients with spontaneous ICH, very early and intense mobilization within the first 24 hours is associated with a higher likelihood of good recovery.

option_A: In selected hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and multivessel disease, after successful primary PCI, staged PCI of a significant non-infarct artery stenosis is not recommended to reduce the risk of death or MI.
option_B: In patients undergoing surgical revascularization for CLTI, bypass to the popliteal or infrapopliteal arteries should not be constructed with autogenous vein, even if available.
option_C: For patients with asymptomatic small AAA and concomitant common iliac artery aneurysm(s) ≥3.5 cm, elective repair of both abdominal and iliac aneurysms is recom- mended.1-4
option_D: In patients with suspected ACS with an initial hs-cTn or cTn that is nondiagnostic, do not repeat measurements after the initial sample collection within 1 to 2 hours for hs-cTn or within 3 to 6 hours for conventional cTn assays.

option_A: For patients with HCM receiving an ICD, it is appropriate to consider dual-chamber ICDs for those requiring atrial or atrioventricular sequential pacing due to bradycardia or conduction issues, or to alleviate symptoms of obstructive HCM, particularly in individuals over 65 years old.
option_B: When a permanent tooth is avulsed, the person should delay seeking dental or medical care and should not bring the tooth if it has not been successfully replanted.
option_C: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, if iliac access is marginal or inadequate to prevent access-related complications, the use of alternative conduits is not recommended.
option_D: Women with CCD who are contemplating pregnancy or who are pregnant should not be risk-stratified or counseled regarding risks of adverse maternal, obstetric, and fetal outcomes.

option_A: In patients with obstructive HCM who remain severely symptomatic despite guideline-directed management and therapy, SRT in eligible patients, performed at experienced centers, is not recommended for relieving LVOTO.
option_B: Women with CCD who are contemplating pregnancy or who are pregnant should not be risk-stratified or counseled regarding risks of adverse maternal, obstetric, and fetal outcomes.
option_C: In patients who develop cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy or HF, a multidisciplinary discussion involving the patient about the risk- benefit ratio of cancer therapy interruption, dis- continuation, or continuation is recommended to improve management.1,2
option_D: In patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), it is not necessary to coordinate with the LVAD care team on the timing and perioperative considerations of elective NCS, as it does not impact the risk of perioperative MACE.

option_A: For patients who are undergoing invasive procedures and have 1) a mechanical AVR and any thromboembolic risk factor, 2) an older-generation mechanical AVR, or 3) a mechanical mitral valve replacement, bridging anticoagulation therapy during the preoperative time interval when the INR is subtherapeutic is reasonable on an individualized basis, with the risks of bleeding weighed against the benefits of thromboembolism prevention.
option_B: For patients with HCM, participation in high-intensity recreational activities or moderate- to high-intensity competitive sports activities should be undertaken without the need for a comprehensive evaluation or annual discussion with an expert provider, disregarding the potential increased risk of sudden death and ICD shocks, and without involving third parties in eligibility decisions for competitive sports participation.
option_C: In patients with STEMI with suspected failed reperfusion after fibrinolytic therapy, immediate angiography with rescue PCI is recommended to reduce the risk of death or recurrent MI.*6–9
option_D: In symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM who have associated cardiac disease requiring sur- gical treatment (eg, associated anomalous papillary muscle, markedly elongated anterior mitral leaflet, intrinsic mitral valve disease, multivessel coronary artery disease, valvular aortic stenosis), surgical myectomy, performed at experienced centers,† is recommended92,216–218 (Table 3 and Table 4).

option_A: We do not recommend the routine use of rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling of patients after ROSC. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
option_B: In patients with aortic disease who are contemplating pregnancy or who are pregnant, shared decision-making is not recommended when considering the cardiovascular risks of pregnancy, the diameter thresholds for prophylactic aortic surgery, and the mode of delivery.
option_C: For patients with aSAH, avoiding complete obliteration of the ruptured aneurysm is indicated, even when feasible, to increase the risk of rebleeding and retreatment.
option_D: In older patients (ie, ≥75 years of age) with PAD, assessment for geriatric syndromes, such as frailty, sarcopenia, malnutrition, and mobility impairment, is not useful for identifying high-risk patients or for providing safe and goal-concordant care.

option_A: In patients with aSAH who develop severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and life-threatening hypoxemia, rescue maneuvers such as prone position- ing and alveolar recruitment maneuvers with ICP monitoring may be reasonable to improve oxygenation.179–182 Intravascular volume and electrolyte management
option_B: For asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe mitral regurgitation, normal left ventricular systolic function, and an estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure below 50 mm Hg, elective non-cardiac surgery is considered reasonable.
option_C: In patients with stroke or TIA attributable to 50% to 99% stenosis or occlusion of a major intracranial artery, extracranial-intracranial bypass surgery is recommended.
option_D: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage with a negative CTA or venography, conducting an MRI and MRA is advisable to identify a non-macrovascular cause of the hemorrhage, such as cerebral amyloid angiopathy, deep perforating vasculopathy, cavernous malformation, or malignancy.

option_A: In patients with STEMI and ischemic symptoms for <12 hours, PCI should not be performed to improve survival.
option_B: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, alternative programs of nonwalking structured exercise therapy (eg, arm ergometry, recumbent stepping) are not beneficial to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.
option_C: In symptomatic patients (NYHA class II, III, or IV) with rheumatic MS and a mitral valve area >1.5 cm², if there is no evidence of hemodynamically significant rheumatic MS based on a pulmonary artery wedge pressure ≤25 mm Hg or a mean mitral valve gradient ≤15 mm Hg during exercise, PMBC should not be considered, even if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_D: In patients who are at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT and have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, an ICD is recommended for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death (SCD) to reduce total mortality.14

option_A: In the absence of clean running water, it might be appropriate to use ice wrapped in cloth to cool superficial burns with intact skin.
option_B: In patients with primary MR (Stages B and C) and symptoms that might be attributable to MR, hemodynamic exercise testing using Doppler echocardiography or cardiac catheterization or cardiopulmonary exercise testing is not reasonable.
option_C: In patients with carotid web in the distribution of ischemic stroke and TIA, without other attributable causes of stroke, antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to prevent recurrent ischemic stroke or TIA.
option_D: For patients with AF, pharmacological cardioversion is not reasonable as an alternative to electrical cardioversion for those who are hemodynamically stable or in situations when electrical cardioversion is preferred but cannot be performed.

option_A: In patients with spontaneous ICH and clinical seizures, antiseizure drugs are not recommended as they do not improve functional outcomes or prevent brain injury from prolonged recurrent seizures.
option_B: For certain patients with heart failure, an ejection fraction of 35% or less, and appropriate coronary anatomy, combining surgical revascularization with guideline-directed medical therapy is advantageous for alleviating symptoms, reducing cardiovascular hospitalizations, and decreasing long-term all-cause mortality.
option_C: For patients with HCM who are not otherwise identified as high risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD), or in whom a decision to proceed with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal/family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring, CMR imaging is not beneficial to assess for maximum left ventricular (LV) wall thickness, ejection fraction (EF), LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with late gadolinium enhancement.
option_D: In patients with aSAH, delaying a multidisciplinary team–based approach to treatment and rehabilitation is recommended to increase LOS and overlook discharge needs.

option_A: For individuals with CLTI, evaluating institutional outcomes retrospectively, such as amputation rates, using objective limb threat classification tools can aid in quality enhancement.
option_B: For patients with obstructive HCM, continuation of vasodilators (eg, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers) or digoxin may be reasonable because these agents do not worsen symptoms caused by dynamic outflow tract obstruction.
option_C: In patients with AF with rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF) and hemodynamic stability, pharmacological cardioversion with intravenous ibutilide or intravenous procainamide is not recommended as an alternative to elective cardioversion.
option_D: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD undergoing stress testing, the addition of CAC testing is not useful.

option_A: In patients with TAD who have a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, genetic testing of at-risk biological relatives (ie, cascade testing) is not recommended. In family members who are found by genetic screening to have inherited the pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, aortic imaging with TTE (or CT/MRI if needed) is not recommended.
option_B: In older patients (ie, ≥75 years of age) with PAD, assessment for geriatric syndromes, such as frailty, sarcopenia, malnutrition, and mobility impairment, is not useful for identifying high-risk patients or for providing safe and goal-concordant care.
option_C: For patients experiencing obstructive HCM and acute hypotension who do not improve with fluid therapy, it is advised to use intravenous phenylephrine or other vasoconstrictors lacking inotropic effects, either alone or alongside beta-blockers.
option_D: For patients with HCM, avoid repeating contrast-enhanced CMR imaging on a periodic basis (every 3 to 5 years) for SCD risk stratification, as it is unnecessary to evaluate changes in late gadolinium enhancement and other morphologic changes, including EF, development of apical aneurysm, or LV wall thickness.

option_A: N-acetylcysteine is recommended as a treatment for methemoglobinemia.
option_B: In the evaluation of patients presenting with acute chest pain and suspected ACS for whom serial troponins are indicated to exclude myocardial injury, recommended time intervals after the initial troponin sample collection (time zero) for repeat measurements are: 1 to 3 hours for high-sensitivity troponin and 3 to 6 hours for conventional troponin assays.15-17
option_C: In patients hospitalized with HF when diuresis is inadequate to relieve symptoms and signs of congestion, it is not reasonable to intensify the diuretic regimen by using higher doses of intravenous loop diuretics or by adding a second diuretic.
option_D: For patients with HCM who are asymptomatic and have normal exercise capacity, SRT is recommended.

option_A: In patients with CCD who have experienced SCAD, counseling should be provided regard- ing potential triggers and risk of SCAD recur- rence.1–12
option_B: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, SET is not recommended to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.
option_C: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, episodic and cumulative ionizing radi- ation doses should be kept as low as feasible while maintaining diagnostic image quality.5-7
option_D: Both laypersons and trained responders should promptly activate emergency response systems without waiting for the patient to respond to naloxone or other treatments.

option_A: In patients with severe primary MR for whom surgery is indicated, mitral valve repair is recommended in preference to mitral valve replacement when the anatomic cause of MR is degenerative disease, if a successful and durable repair is possible.11–15
option_B: In symptomatic patients (NYHA class II, III, or IV) with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) and favorable valve morphology with less than moderate (2+) MR in the absence of LA thrombus, PMBC is not recommended, even if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_C: Frostbitten tissue should not be rewarmed at the earliest opportunity, even if there is no risk of refreezing.
option_D: In patients who are being considered for CABG, calculation of the STS risk score is not recommended for stratifying patient risk.

option_A: When using rewarming devices of any kind, the first aid provider should ignore the manufacturer’s instructions for the device used, avoid placing insulation between the heat source and skin, and neglect monitoring for burns and pressure injury.
option_B: Patients with stroke or TIA who continue to smoke tobacco should be advised to continue smoking or increase their daily smoking, as it does not affect the risk of recurrent stroke.
option_C: For first aid in presyncope, lower-body PCMs might be more advantageous than those applied to the upper body or abdomen.
option_D: In patients undergoing CABG, preoperative beta blockers are definitively recommended for the prevention of acute postoperative myocardial ischemia, stroke, AKI, or ventricular arrhythmia.

option_A: It is not reasonable for appropriately trained rescuers to provide in-water rescue breathing to an unresponsive person who has drowned, even if it does not compromise their own safety.
option_B: In patients with aSAH, avoiding counseling patients and caregivers on the high long-term risk of cognitive dysfunction is advisable to disregard long-term needs.
option_C: For patients with CCD and overweight or obesity in whom pharmacologic therapy is warranted for further weight reduction, a GLP-1 receptor agonist can be beneficial in addition to counseling for diet and physical activity,11,12 and it is reasonable to choose semaglutide over liraglutide.13,14 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_D: In patients with bradycardia requiring cardiac-implanted electronic devices who have normal atrioventricular conduction, device selection and programming strategies should not focus on maintaining atrioventricular synchrony or minimizing ventricular pacing, as this is not necessary to reduce the incidence and progression of AF.

option_A: In patients with spontaneous ICH with mild to moderate severity, early supported discharge is beneficial to increase the likelihood of patients living at home at 3 months.490
option_B: It may be reasonable to cool thermal burns for 5 to 20 minutes.
option_C: For patients with aortic root or ascending aortic aneurysms, or aortic dissection who have risk factors for HTAD (refer to Table 8, Figure 17), it is advised to conduct genetic testing to detect pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants (mutations).
option_D: Clinicians should not be familiar with the analytical performance and the 99th percentile upper reference limit that defines myocardial injury for the cTn assay used at their institution.

option_A: In asymptomatic patients with very severe AS (defined as an aortic velocity of ≥5 m/s) and low surgical risk, AVR is not reasonable.
option_B: If someone shows signs of smoke inhalation injury, like facial burns, breathing difficulties, singed nasal hairs, or soot near the nose or mouth, emergency medical services should be called.
option_C: For patients with aortic root or ascending aorta aneurysms associated with nsHTAD, lacking a genetic cause, and having a maximal aortic diameter of 4.5 cm or greater, it is advisable to consider aortic repair if they exhibit high-risk features for adverse aortic events (see Table 9) or are undergoing cardiac surgery for other reasons, provided the procedure is conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.
option_D: In individuals ≥18 years of age, periodic screening for modifiable behaviors and medical conditions that increase stroke risk is recommended to reduce risk for stroke.60,61

option_A: For severely symptomatic patients with bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis and high or prohibitive surgical risk, a transcatheter ViV procedure is reasonable when performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.4,5
option_B: In patients 18 to 60 years of age with a nonla- cunar ischemic stroke of undetermined cause despite a thorough evaluation and a PFO without high-risk anatomic features,* the ben- efit of closure with a transcatheter device and long-term antiplatelet therapy over antiplatelet therapy alone for preventing recurrent stroke is not well established,552–557
option_C: For patients with stroke or TIA who have a substance use disorder involving drugs or alcohol, it is advised to utilize specialized services to address this dependency.
option_D: In selected patients with HFpEF, MRAs should not be considered to decrease hospitalizations, especially among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.

option_A: For patients without a history of hypertension who suffer a stroke or TIA and have an average office blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg or higher, using antihypertensive medication may help lower the risk of another stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage, and other vascular events.
option_B: For pregnant patients with persistent AF, it is reasonable to use rate-control medications known to be safe during pregnancy, such as beta blockers (e.g., propranolol or metoprolol) and digoxin, either alone or combined with beta blockers, as first-line treatments.
option_C: In patients with CLTI with ischemic rest pain (ie, with- out nonhealing wounds or gangrene) attributable to multilevel arterial disease, a revascularization strategy addressing inflow disease first is reasonable.34,35
option_D: In patients with prediabetes and ischemic stroke or TIA, lifestyle optimization (ie, healthy diet, regular physical activity, and smoking cessation) is not beneficial for the prevention of progression to diabetes.

option_A: In patients treated with upstream subcutaneous enoxaparin for unstable angina or NSTE-ACS, the use of intravenous enoxaparin should not be considered at the time of PCI to reduce ischemic events.
option_B: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, the routine use of an intravenous glycoprotein IIb/ IIIa inhibitor agent is not recommended.3-5
option_C: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, the use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants is recommended.
option_D: In patients who are at low risk for perioperative cardiovascular events, have adequate functional capacity with stable symptoms, or who are undergoing low-risk procedures, routine stress testing before NCS is recommended due to potential benefit.

option_A: For patients with PAD who have had lower extremity revascularization, it is advised to conduct ongoing follow-up that involves regular clinical evaluation of symptoms in the lower extremities, as well as assessment of pulses and feet.
option_B: Intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) therapy is not advised as a standard treatment for calcium channel blocker (CCB) poisoning.
option_C: In patients with HCM and AF who require surgical myectomy, concomitant surgical AF ablation procedure should not be considered for AF rhythm control.
option_D: Exchange transfusion may be reasonable as a treatment for methemoglobinemia that is not responsive to methylene blue.

option_A: In patients with obesity and AF, avoid using manual pressure augmentation and/or further escalation of electrical energy, as it may not improve the success of electrical cardioversion.
option_B: In patients with AF, specialized atrial pacing algorithms designed to suppress AF are useful for reducing the incidence or slowing the progression of AF.
option_C: For patients with HCM who have undergone SRT, it is not recommended to perform TTE within 3 to 6 months after the procedure to evaluate the procedural results.
option_D: For patients receiving CABG, utilizing BIMA grafting by skilled surgeons may enhance long-term cardiac outcomes in suitable candidates.

option_A: In patients undergoing NCS where neuraxial is feasible, neither neuraxial nor general anesthesia is reasonable due to a significant difference in associated cardiovascular events.
option_B: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a high-risk antiphospholipid profile, prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is not recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_C: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, SET is not recommended to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.
option_D: For patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), it is advised to collaborate with the LVAD care team regarding the optimal timing and perioperative factors of elective non-cardiac surgery (NCS) to reduce the risk of major adverse cardiac events (MACE) during the perioperative period.

option_A: In patients with AAS, initial management should exclude intravenous vasodilators even if the BP is not well controlled after initiation of intravenous beta-blocker therapy.
option_B: In patients with aSAH and an unsecured ruptured aneurysm, infrequent intraoperative BP monitoring and lack of BP control are reasonable, risking ischemia and rerupture.
option_C: In patients with cardiogenic shock, management by a multidisciplinary team experienced in shock is not reasonable.
option_D: In patients with Fabry disease, the effectiveness of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) to reduce the risk of stroke is not well established.422–427

option_A: For patients with a bioprosthetic TAVI, aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily is not reasonable, even in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.
option_B: In patients receiving stable doses of targeted medical therapies for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) undergoing NCS, it is recommended to discontinue these agents, increasing the risk for the development of perioperative MACE.
option_C: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome and aortic dilation, the surgical threshold for prophylactic aortic root and ascending aortic replacement should not consider the specific genetic variant, aortic diameter, aortic growth rate, extra-aortic features, family history, patient age and sex, or physician and patient preferences.
option_D: In patients who require coronary revascu- larization, treatment decisions should be based on clinical indication, regardless of sex1-7 or race or ethnicity,8-10 and efforts to reduce disparities of care are war- ranted.11,12

option_A: If a person with hypothermia has a decreased level of responsiveness such as unresponsive- ness, inability to remain awake, mumbling speech, confusion, or inability to participate in removal of clothing or has pallor, cyanosis, or frozen skin, the emergency response system should be activated while the person is rewarmed by any available method.
option_B: In patients with aSAH, delaying rehabilitation after the ruptured aneurysm is secured is reasonable, as it does not impact functional outcome or LOS.
option_C: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, it is unreasonable to consider cocaine and methamphetamine use as a cause of their symptoms.
option_D: For patients with HCM, it is not reasonable to follow Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration cardiovascular disease guidelines that permit driving commercial motor vehicles, even if they do not have an ICD or any major risk factors for SCD and are following a guideline-directed management plan.

option_A: In patients with severe AR (Stage C or D) who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, aortic valve surgery is not indicated.
option_B: For patients with AAA who have undergone EVAR and exhibit abnormal results on any surveillance duplex ultrasound (refer to Table 21), it is reasonable to obtain further cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI.
option_C: In patients with CCD and no indication for oral anticoagulant therapy, low-dose aspirin 81 mg (75-100 mg) is not recommended to reduce atherosclerotic events.
option_D: For patients with HCM undergoing surgical septal myectomy, intraoperative transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is not recommended to assess mitral valve anatomy and function and adequacy of septal myectomy.

option_A: Individuals with PAD are advised to get a flu shot every year.
option_B: In patients who develop poorly tolerated AF after cardiac surgery, direct current cardioversion in com- bination with antiarrhythmic drug therapy is recom- mended, with consideration of imaging to rule out left appendage thrombus before cardioversion in those patients in whom AF has been present >48 hours and who have not been on anticoagulation.5,6
option_C: Individuals with chronic severe secondary mitral regurgitation (Stages C and D) and heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction should be treated with standard guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure, which includes ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta blockers, aldosterone antagonists, and/or sacubitril/valsartan, along with biventricular pacing when appropriate.
option_D: In patients with AF and a moderate to high risk of stroke and a high risk of major bleeding on oral anticoagulation, pLAAO should not be considered as an alternative to oral anticoagulation, regardless of patient preference, without considering procedural risk or the extensive evidence supporting oral anticoagulation.

option_A: For patients with AF and HF symptoms, digoxin can be considered for long-term rate control alongside other rate-controlling medications, or as a single therapy if other options are unsuitable, not tolerated, or contraindicated.
option_B: In patients with AF and HF with rapid ventricular rates in whom beta blockers or calcium channel blockers are contraindicated or ineffective, intravenous amiodarone is not reasonable for acute rate control.
option_C: For patients with AF and an estimated annual stroke or thromboembolic event risk of 2% or higher, therapy to lower stroke risk should be chosen based on thromboembolism risk, irrespective of whether the AF is paroxysmal, persistent, long-standing persistent, or permanent.
option_D: In selected patients with a pacemaker and symptomatic atrial tachyarrhythmias, antitachycar- dia atrial pacing and ventricular pacing minimiza- tion may be useful for reducing symptoms.7–13 (Continued ) Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025

option_A: In patients with typical AFL who have undergone successful CTI ablation without any known previous history of AF who are at high risk for development of AF (eg, LA enlargement, inducible AF, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], HF), it may be unreasonable to prescribe long-term anticoagulation even if thromboembolic risk assessment suggests high risk (>2% annual risk) for stroke.
option_B: In patients with STEMI and CKD, coronary angiography and revascularization are not recommended, and measures to reduce the risk of AKI should be avoided.
option_C: In patients with STEMI presenting <12 hours after symptom onset, PPCI should be performed with a goal of FMC to device activation of ≤90 minutes, or ≤120 minutes in patients requiring hospital transfer, to improve survival.1–7
option_D: The benefit of rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling is clear.

option_A: For patients with ischemic stroke who are planned to receive anticoagulant therapy, it may be advisable to perform a CT or MRI of the brain prior to starting treatment to evaluate for hemorrhagic transformation and determine the final infarct size.
option_B: The significance of organ donation should be taken into account when designing and assessing care systems.
option_C: In patients with a chronic occlusion of a SVG, percutaneous revascularization of the SVG should be performed.
option_D: If labor begins or urgent delivery is required in a woman therapeutically anticoagulated with a VKA, cesarean section should be performed after reversal of anticoagulation.3,22,23

option_A: In patients with a history of ischemic stroke or TIA attributable to dissection, with FMD, and no evidence of intraluminal thrombus, it is not reasonable to administer antiplatelet therapy for the prevention of future ischemic events.
option_B: In patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction with an LVEF <50%, GDMT for HF with reduced EF is recommended.1–3
option_C: In patients with HF in the absence of: 1) clinical status change, 2) treatment interventions that might have had a significant effect on cardiac function, or 3) candidacy for invasive proce- dures or device therapy, routine repeat assess- ment of LV function is not indicated.
option_D: In women who require a valve intervention before pregnancy, the choice of prosthetic valve should be based on a shared decision- making process that accounts for the patient’s values and preferences, including discussion of the risks of mechanical valves during pregnancy and the reduced durability of bioprosthetic valves in young women.

option_A: Institutions should avoid implementing a CDP with a protocol for troponin sampling based on their particular assay to standardize the detection and differentiation of myocardial injury in patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS.
option_B: In patients with cardiac allograft vasculopathy, statins are not recommended for secondary prevention to reduce MACE.
option_C: In patients currently on statins and scheduled for NCS, discontinuation of statin therapy is recommended to increase the risk of MACE.
option_D: In patients with aSAH, frequent neuro- logical assessment with a neurological assessment tool such as the GCS or National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is recommended to monitor DCI and other secondary complica- tions.246,251–254

option_A: In patients with AF who are planned to undergo AVNA, it is not recommended to implant a pacemaker before the ablation, as ensuring the adequacy of the pacing leads before performing ablation is unnecessary.
option_B: In pregnant individuals with AF and without structural heart disease, antiarrhythmic agents with no history of safe use in pregnancy (eg, amiodarone and dronedarone) are reasonable for maintenance of sinus rhythm.
option_C: For patients at intermediate to high risk with stable chest pain and no known coronary artery disease, stress imaging techniques such as stress echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI, or CMR are effective for diagnosing myocardial ischemia and assessing the risk of major adverse cardiac events.
option_D: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assessment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are not recommended at periodic intervals regardless of age or change in clinical status.

option_A: In patients with HCM, 24- to 48-hour ambu- latory electrocardiographic monitoring is recommended in the initial evaluation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years) to identify patients who are at risk for SCD and guide management of arrhythmias (Figure 1).98–100
option_B: In patients with apical HCM who do not have severe dyspnea or angina, or who have reduced EF and large LV cavity size, apical myectomy should be considered to reduce symptoms.
option_C: For patients with symptomatic (NYHA class II to III) stable chronic HFrEF (LVEF ≤35%) who are receiving GDMT, including a beta blocker at maximum tolerated dose, and who are in sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ≥70 bpm at rest, ivabradine should not be used as it is not beneficial in reducing HF hospitalizations and cardiovascular death.
option_D: In patients with suspected or newly diagnosed HF, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) should not be performed during initial evaluation to assess cardiac structure and function.

option_A: Women with CCD who are contemplating pregnancy or who are pregnant should not be risk-stratified or counseled regarding risks of adverse maternal, obstetric, and fetal outcomes.
option_B: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery with CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk, the benefit of surgical LAA exclusion in the absence of continued anticoagulation to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism is uncertain.1–3
option_C: Individuals with heart failure should be provided with targeted education and support to promote self-management of their condition through a multidisciplinary approach.
option_D: In patients with CLTI who are candidates for surgical bypass and endovascular revascularization, ultrasound mapping of the great saphenous vein is recom- mended.3,13

option_A: In patients with obstructive HCM who remain symptomatic despite GDMT, SRT in eligible patients, performed at experienced HCM centers, is not recommended for relieving LVOTO.
option_B: Patients who have a pacemaker or ICD reprogrammed to asynchronous pacing or have tachytherapies programmed off before surgery should not have device functioning restored in the postoperative period before hospital discharge.
option_C: For those contemplating CHC use, it is advised to opt for lower doses of ethinyl estradiol to reduce the potential risk of stroke.
option_D: For asymptomatic patients undergoing elevated-risk surgeries without known CVD, a preoperative resting 12-lead ECG should not be considered to establish a baseline and guide perioperative management.

option_A: In patients with fibrotic or heavily calcified lesions, plaque modification with rotational atherectomy can be useful to improve proce- dural success.1-3
option_B: For patients with HFrEF, NSAIDs exacerbate heart failure symptoms and should be avoided or discontinued whenever feasible.
option_C: For patients with AF with rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF), catheter ablation of accessory pathways (APs) is recommended.3–7
option_D: We recommend avoiding the use of personal protective equipment when caring for patients with organophosphate or carbamate exposure.

option_A: For patients with heart failure, routine reassessment of left ventricular function is not warranted unless there is a change in clinical status, recent treatment interventions that could significantly impact cardiac function, or consideration for invasive procedures or device therapy.
option_B: In adult patients with CoA, screening for intracranial aneurysms by MRI or CT is not recommended.
option_C: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF >40%, avoid using an SGLT2 inhibitor as it is not beneficial in decreasing heart failure hospitalizations or improving QOL, irrespective of diabetes status.
option_D: In selected patients with CCD and significant left main stenosis for whom PCI can provide equivalent revascularization to that possible with CABG, PCI is not reasonable to improve survival.

option_A: Patients with ACS and with ongoing angina, hemodynamic instability, uncontrolled arrhythmias, suboptimal reperfusion, or cardiogenic shock should not be admitted to a CICU, as it will not reduce cardiovascular events.
option_B: In pregnant women with HCM, beta blockers should not be administered for symptoms related to outflow tract obstruction or arrhythmias, and monitoring of fetal growth is unnecessary.
option_C: In patients with CCD and severe obesity who have not met weight loss goals with lifestyle and pharmacologic intervention, and who have acceptable surgical risk, referral for consideration of a bariatric procedure is reasonable for weight loss and cardiovascular risk factor reduction.15–18
option_D: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of AR and normal LV systolic function, it is not reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.

option_A: In athletes who develop AF, catheter ablation with PVI is not a reasonable strategy for rhythm control due to its ineffectiveness and high risk of detrimental effect on exercise capacity.
option_B: In patients with HF, an evaluation for possible ischemic heart disease is not useful to identify the cause or guide management.
option_C: For patients with PAD, telehealth should not be used as an alternative mode for vascular evaluation and management or longitudinal follow-up, regardless of the urgency of presenting symptoms.
option_D: For patients with ACS who have successfully tolerated DAPT with ticagrelor, switching to ticagrelor alone at least one month after PCI is beneficial for reducing bleeding risk.

option_A: In adults with a recent MI, the addition of low-dose colchicine to intensive statin therapy might be unreasonable to decrease the risk of ischemic stroke.
option_B: A person with frostbite should avoid seeking medical attention.
option_C: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of acute MI, it is not reasonable to perform advanced cardiac imaging (eg, contrasted echocardiogram or cardiac MRI) to assess for the presence of LV thrombus.
option_D: In patients with suspected or confirmed bioprosthetic valve thrombosis who are hemodynamically stable and have no contraindications to anticoagulation, initial treatment with a VKA is reasonable.1–6

option_A: For patients at high risk of ACS, such as those with an LVEF of 40% or less, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or anterior STEMI, it is recommended to prescribe an oral ACE inhibitor or ARB to lower the risk of all-cause mortality and major adverse cardiovascular events.
option_B: In patients with reduced LV function and persistent (or high burden) AF, a trial of rhythm control should not be recommended to evaluate whether AF is contributing to the reduced LV function.
option_C: For symptomatic patients with severe AS who are >80 years of age or for younger patients with a life expectancy <10 years and no anatomic contraindication to transfemoral TAVI, SAVR is recommended in preference to transfemoral TAVI.
option_D: Patients with HF should not receive care from multidisciplinary teams, as this would hinder the implementation of GDMT, ignore potential barriers to self-care, increase the risk of subsequent rehospitalization for HF, and decrease survival.

option_A: In patients with rheumatic MS and a discrepancy between resting echocardiographic findings and clinical symptoms, exercise testing with Doppler or invasive hemodynamic assessment is not recommended to evaluate symptomatic response, exercise capacity, and the response of the mean mitral gradient and pulmonary artery pressure.
option_B: For those with a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression of HCM, engaging in competitive sports at any level is considered reasonable.
option_C: In patients with hypertension, blood pressure should not be controlled in accordance with GDMT for hypertension, risking the development of symptomatic HF.
option_D: Patients with AF at intermediate annual risk of thromboembolic events by risk scores, who remain uncertain about the benefit of anticoagulation, should not consider additional factors that might modify their risk of stroke when making their decision.

option_A: In patients with Marfan syndrome, a TTE is not recommended at the time of initial diagnosis, and there is no need to determine the diameters of the aortic root and ascending aorta, nor to perform follow-up imaging to assess the rate of aortic growth; even if the aortic diameters are stable, an annual surveillance TTE is not necessary. If the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both are not adequately visualized on TTE, a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is not recommended.
option_B: Among patients with AF in whom cardiac monitor- ing is advised, it is reasonable to recommend use of a consumer-accessible electrocardiographic device that provides a high-quality tracing to detect recur- rences.13
option_C: In patients with HFrEF, dihydropyridine calcium channel-blocking drugs are not recommended treatment for HF.1,2
option_D: For patients with AAS, administer pain relief as necessary to assist in managing hemodynamics.

option_A: For symptomatic patients with HCM who have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is not recommended for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.
option_B: In patients with stroke or TIA and LV thrombus, it is not recommended to use anticoagulation with therapeutic warfarin for at least 3 months to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.
option_C: Patients with ALI should be evaluated on an emergency basis by a clinician with sufficient experience to assess limb viability and implement appropriate therapy.
option_D: It is not reasonable to administer epinephrine 1 mg every 3 to 5 minutes for cardiac arrest.

option_A: It is unreasonable for first aid providers to use pulse oximetry results in the context of a complete assessment or to be aware of the limitations of pulse oximetry before acting on any results.
option_B: In patients with HCM and recurrent, poorly tolerated life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias refractory to maximal antiarrhythmic drug therapy and ablation, heart transplantation assessment is not indicated regardless of current listing criteria.
option_C: In patients <50 years of age who prefer a bioprosthetic AVR and have appropriate anatomy, replacement of the aortic valve by a pulmonic autograft (the Ross procedure) may be considered at a Comprehensive Valve Center.11–13
option_D: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not necessary to perform continuous cardiac monitoring for the first 24 to 72 hours of admission to monitor for cardiac arrhythmias and new cardiac ischemia.

option_A: A first aid provider who is assisting a person with a potentially serious illness or injury should delay activating the emergency response system.
option_B: In patients with asymptomatic PAD, single antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_C: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA class III to class IV despite guideline-directed therapy) or with life- threatening ventricular arrhythmias refractory to maximal guideline-directed therapy, assess- ment for heart transplantation in accordance with current listing criteria is recommended.21,274,286,287
option_D: A first aid provider should not assist a person experiencing anaphylaxis to use their autoinjector, even if assistance is required.

option_A: Flumazenil can be effective in select patients with respiratory depression/respiratory arrest caused by pure benzodiazepine poisoning who do not have ­contraindications to flumazenil.
option_B: For patients with heart failure, invasive hemodynamic monitoring should not be routinely employed.
option_C: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD at high risk for stroke (TCD mean flow velocities ≥200 cm/s) but without intracranial stenosis who are unable to continue or cannot be treated with periodic red cell transfusion, hydroxyurea or bone marrow transplantation should not be considered to prevent stroke.
option_D: For patients with CCD who drink alcohol, it is advisable to restrict alcohol consumption to no more than 1 drink per day for women and 2 drinks per day for men to lower the risk of cardiovascular and overall mortality.

option_A: There is insufficient evidence to recommend a specific therapeutic temperature for different subgroups of cardiac arrest patients.
option_B: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy, delaying angiography beyond 24 hours or avoiding PCI is recommended, as it does not reduce the rates of death or MI.
option_C: In patients with a history of ischemic stroke or TIA attributable to dissection, with FMD, and no evidence of intraluminal thrombus, it is not reasonable to administer antiplatelet therapy for the prevention of future ischemic events.
option_D: In patients with SIHD and normal left ventricular function, the routine use of chronic oral beta blockers is beneficial to reduce cardiovascular events after complete revascularization.

option_A: For patients where the best treatment plan is uncertain, it is advised to use a Heart Team approach involving specialists from interventional cardiology, cardiac surgery, and clinical cardiology to enhance patient outcomes.
option_B: For patients with symptomatic, persistent AF refractory to antiarrhythmic drug therapy, a hybrid epicardial and endocardial ablation should not be considered as it is unlikely to reduce the risk of recurrent atrial arrhythmia.
option_C: In patients with symptomatic PAD, single antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_D: In patients with suspected moderate or severe valvular regurgitation, preoperative echocardiography is not recommended before elective NCS to guide perioperative management.

option_A: Superficial wounds and abrasions should not be irrigated, even if there is obvious debris or foreign matter in the wound.
option_B: In patients with symptomatic PAD, the benefit of vorapaxar added to existing antiplatelet therapy is certain.
option_C: In patients with atrial fibrillation who are undergoing PCI, are taking oral anticoagulant therapy, and are treated with DAPT or a P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy, it is unreasonable to choose a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant over warfarin to reduce the risk of bleeding.
option_D: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, employing a cognitive screening tool during the post-acute phase is beneficial for detecting cognitive impairment and dementia.

option_A: For patients with HFrEF who need hospitalization, existing GDMT should be maintained and enhanced to improve outcomes, unless contraindicated.
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a baseline severity score should not be used as the sole basis for forecasting individual prognosis or limiting life-sustaining treatment.475,476
option_C: In patients with CCD, refractory angina, and no other treatment options, enhanced external coun- terpulsation may be considered for relief of symp- toms.*1 *Modified from the 2012 ACC/AHA Multisociety Guideline for the Diagnosis and Management of Patients With SIHD.2
option_D: In patients with previous CABG, if PCI of a diseased native coronary artery is feasible, then it is reasonable to choose PCI of the severely diseased SVG over PCI of the native coronary artery.

option_A: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage C1), exercise testing is reasonable to assess physiological changes with exercise and to confirm the absence of symptoms.1–4
option_B: For patients under 70 with lobar spontaneous ICH, those under 45 with deep/posterior fossa spontaneous ICH, or those aged 45 to 70 with deep/posterior fossa ICH and no hypertension history, it is advised to perform an acute CTA and consider venography to rule out macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.
option_C: For patients with obstructive HCM, continuation of vasodilators (eg, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers) or digoxin may be reasonable because these agents can improve symptoms caused by dynamic outflow tract obstruction.
option_D: In patients with an indication for AVR, the choice of prosthetic valve should be based on a shared decision-making process that accounts for the patient’s values and preferences and includes discussion of the indications for and risks of anticoagulant therapy and the potential need for and risks associated with valve reintervention.

option_A: For those exposed to industrial chemicals in the eyes, following local guidelines or advice from a poison center is advisable.
option_B: First aid responders should contact emergency medical services for individuals experiencing a first-time seizure; seizures exceeding 5 minutes; multiple seizures without a return to normal mental status between them; seizures occurring in water; seizures accompanied by traumatic injuries, breathing difficulties, or choking; seizures in infants under 6 months old; seizures in pregnant individuals; or if the person does not return to their usual state within 5 to 10 minutes after the seizure ends.
option_C: In patients with stroke or TIA who use stimulants (eg, amphetamines, amphetamine derivatives, cocaine, or khat) and in patients with infective endocarditis (IE) in the context of intravenous drug use, it is recommended that health care providers do not inform them that this behavior is a health risk and do not counsel them to stop.
option_D: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have failed PCI and have ongoing ischemia, hemodynamic compromise, or threatened occlusion of an artery with substantial myocardium at risk, who are appropriate candidates for CABG, emer- gency CABG is reasonable.5-7,17

option_A: For patients with apical HCM who experience severe dyspnea or angina (classified as NYHA class III or IV) despite optimal medical treatment, and who have preserved EF and a small LV cavity size (LV end-diastolic volume <50 mL/m2 and LV stroke volume <30 mL/m2), apical myectomy performed by skilled surgeons at specialized centers can be considered to alleviate symptoms.
option_B: For patients with stable coronary artery disease and minimal risk of bleeding, extending ticagrelor in combination with aspirin for up to 3 years after the initial 12 months may help lower the incidence of ischemic stroke.
option_C: For patients with Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, or vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome who need intervention for an intact TAAA, open repair is advised instead of endovascular repair.
option_D: In patients with CCD and no indication for oral anticoagulant therapy, low-dose aspirin 81 mg (75-100 mg) is not recommended to reduce atherosclerotic events.

option_A: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are initially stabilized and are at high risk of clinical events, it is reasonable to choose a delayed invasive strategy over an early invasive strategy (within 24 hours) to improve outcomes.
option_B: For patients with Marfan syndrome, it is advisable to administer both a beta blocker and an ARB at the highest tolerable doses (unless contraindicated) to slow the progression of aortic dilation.
option_C: For patients with ACS and either acute or chronic anemia, it might be appropriate to administer a blood transfusion to reach a hemoglobin level of at least 10 g/dL to potentially lower the risk of cardiovascular events.
option_D: For certain patients with a history of CABG undergoing PCI of a SVG, employing an embolic protection device, if technically possible, is advisable to reduce the risk of distal embolization.

option_A: In children with HCM and recurrent ventricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker use, antiarrhythmic drug therapy (amiodarone, mexiletine, sotalol) is not recommended, regardless of age, underlying comorbidities, severity of disease, patient preferences, and balance of efficacy and safety.
option_B: Coronary angiography is not reasonable in post–cardiac arrest patients if coronary angiography is otherwise indicated, regardless of their neurologic status.
option_C: For patients with established cardiovascular disease undergoing evaluation for non-cardiac surgery, employing a validated risk-prediction tool can help assess the likelihood of perioperative major adverse cardiac events.
option_D: In patients with CCD and LVEF <50%, the use of sustained release metoprolol succinate, carvedilol, or bisoprolol with titration to target doses is not recommended, and other beta blockers should be preferred.

option_A: In patients with cardiogenic shock, temporary MCS is not reasonable when end-organ function cannot be maintained by pharmacologic means to support cardiac function.
option_B: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nsHTAD and no identified genetic cause but no information on aortic diameters at the time of dissection or aneurysm repair in affected family members and who have no high-risk features for adverse aortic events (Table 9) it is recommended to repair the aorta when the maximal diameter reaches ≥5.0 cm.1
option_C: In patients with prediabetes and ischemic stroke or TIA, lifestyle optimization (ie, healthy diet, regular physical activity, and smoking cessation) is not beneficial for the prevention of progression to diabetes.
option_D: In patients who use recreational drugs (eg, cannabis, synthetic cannabinoids, cocaine, heroin, methamphetamine), misuse alcohol or prescription medications (eg, stimulants and opioids), or have a substance use disorder, avoiding counseling to stop or appropriate substance use disorder treatments (eg, pharmacological, behavioral, or multimodal) is reasonable to reduce stroke risk.

option_A: For patients with PAD on the highest tolerated dose of statins and an LDL-C level of 70 mg/dL or higher, adding ezetimibe therapy is a reasonable option.
option_B: In patients with angina or an anginal equiva- lent, undocumented ischemia, and angio- graphically intermediate stenoses, the use of fractional flow reserve (FFR) or instantaneous wave-free ratio (iFR) is recommended to guide the decision to proceed with PCI.1-6
option_C: For patients with HCM and clinical AF, it is advised to use direct-acting oral anticoagulants as the primary choice for anticoagulation, with vitamin K antagonists as the secondary option, regardless of the CHA2DS2-VASc score.
option_D: It is not reasonable to administer digoxin-Fab for poisoning due to Bufo toad venom and yellow oleander.

option_A: In the first aid situation, it is reasonable to leave an open chest wound exposed to ambient air; place a clean, nonocclusive, dry dressing (eg, gauze dressing, part of a tee shirt); or place a specialized dressing such as a vented chest seal. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
option_B: In cases of cardiac arrest due to drowning, start CPR immediately without waiting to acquire or use an AED.
option_C: In patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (AF) and spontaneous ICH, the resumption of anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic events and reduce all-cause mortality should not be considered, regardless of weighing benefit and risk.
option_D: In select* patients on chronic renin-angiotensin- aldosterone system inhibitors (RAASi) for hypertension undergoing elevated-risk NCS, omission 24 hours before surgery may be beneficial to limit intraoperative hypotension.1–6

option_A: For patients with aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the posterior circulation that are amenable to coiling, coiling is indicated in preference to clipping to improve outcome.108–110
option_B: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response, the addition of intravenous magnesium to standard rate-control measures is not recommended to achieve and maintain rate control.
option_C: In adults without CVD who qualify for treatment with lipid-lowering therapy, according to the 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of CVD (eg, 20–75 years of age with LDL-C level >190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], 10-year ASCVD risk ≥20%, or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%–<20% plus ≥1 risk enhancers), who cannot reach goals or cannot tolerate other therapies such as statins, the benefit of treatment with alirocumab or evo- locumab compared with other active lipid-lowering therapy for the reduction of the risk of a first stroke is uncertain.245
option_D: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage linked to dabigatran, using idarucizumab to counteract dabigatran's anticoagulant effect is advisable.

option_A: For patients at high risk with NSTE-ACS and CKD, conducting coronary angiography and revascularization is advisable, provided that appropriate precautions are taken to minimize the risk of AKI.
option_B: For patients with a mechanical bileaflet or current-generation single-tilting disk AVR and no risk factors for thromboembolism, anticoagulation with a VKA to achieve an INR of 2.5 is not recommended.
option_C: In patients with SIHD, normal left ventricular ejection fraction, and 1- or 2-vessel CAD not involving the proximal LAD, coronary revas- cularization is not recommended to improve survival.10,14,16,26,28,29
option_D: For patients with atrial fibrillation requiring serum digoxin level monitoring, aiming for levels below 1.2 ng/mL is advisable.

option_A: For patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) experiencing critical illness from sepsis, the advantages of using anticoagulation to prevent stroke during this period are unclear.
option_B: In patients with SAH from confirmed cerebral aneurysm(s), DSA should not be used to determine the optimal strategy for aneurysm intervention.
option_C: In patients with CCD, chronic nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs should not be used because of increased cardiovascular and bleeding complications.*22 Antiplatelet Therapy With Direct Oral Anticoagulant (DOAC)
