option_A: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with suspected aortic dissection, it is advised to perform a computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis for diagnostic and treatment planning purposes.
option_B: In patients with HFrEF, NSAIDs improve HF symptoms and should be used or continued whenever possible.
option_C: In select patients with nonischemic cardiomyopathy, referral for genetic counseling and testing is not recommended, as it does not provide useful information for guiding treatment for patients and family members.
option_D: In select patients with CCD treated with PCI and a drug-eluting stent (DES) who have completed a 1- to 3-month course of DAPT, continuing DAPT instead of switching to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy for at least 12 months is reasonable to reduce bleeding risk.

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and diagnosis of primary CNS angiitis, avoiding induction therapy with glucocorticoids and/or immunosuppressants, and not following up with long-term maintenance therapy with steroid-sparing immunosuppressants, is reasonable to lower the risk of stroke recurrence.
option_B: In selected patients with HFpEF, the use of ARB should not be considered to decrease hospitalizations, especially among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.
option_C: In patients who are to be initiated on cancer therapies associated with an increased risk of developing AF, increased vigilance for incident AF and treatment of contributing factors is reasonable to decrease morbidity.1,4–6
option_D: In patients with CCD, chronic nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs should be used despite the increased cardiovascular and bleeding complications.

option_A: For asymptomatic patients undergoing elevated-risk surgeries without known CVD, a preoperative rest­ ing 12-lead ECG may be considered to establish a baseline and guide perioperative management.3,9,10
option_B: In patients with ACS undergoing coronary stent implantation in the left main artery or in complex lesions, intracoronary imaging with intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) or optical coherence tomography (OCT) is not recommended for procedural guidance to reduce ischemic events.
option_C: For patients with symptoms of nonobstructive CAD, employing a stratified medical treatment approach based on invasive coronary physiologic assessments may be beneficial in alleviating angina severity and enhancing quality of life.
option_D: For patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis greater than 70%, it is advised that the patient and healthcare team engage in shared decision-making to choose between carotid revascularization and medical management as the optimal approach to lower stroke risk.

option_A: Individuals with epistaxis who are on anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy, or have a clotting disorder, should consider consulting a healthcare provider unless the bleeding has ceased.
option_B: In patients with functionally limiting claudication who are being considered for revascularization, potential benefits with respect to QOL, walking performance, and overall functional status should not be weighed against the risks and durability of intervention and possible need for repeated procedures.
option_C: In adults with HF, it is unreasonable to screen for depression, social isolation, frailty, and low health literacy as risk factors for poor self-care to improve management.
option_D: In patients who meet standard indications for intervention for VHD (replacement and repair) on the basis of symptoms and disease severity, intervention should not be performed before elective noncardiac surgery, regardless of the urgency and risk of the noncardiac procedure, even if it could reduce perioperative risk.

option_A: In patients with PAD, a comprehensive foot evaluation should not be performed annually to identify risk factors for ulcers and amputation.
option_B: For patients who are diagnosed with HF, laboratory evaluation should exclude complete blood count, urinalysis, serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen, serum creatinine, glucose, lipid profile, liver function tests, iron studies, and thyroid-stimulating hormone to optimize management.
option_C: In patients with recently symptomatic extra- cranial vertebral artery stenosis, intensive medical therapy (antiplatelet therapy, lipid lowering, BP control) is recommended to reduce stroke risk.378
option_D: In most pregnant women with HCM, vaginal delivery is not recommended as the first-choice delivery option.

option_A: In patients with grade 4 BAAI (Table 33), repair should not be performed to address life-threatening aortic injury.
option_B: In adults with CCD who have hypertension, a BP target of ≥130/≥80 mm Hg is recommended to reduce CVD events and all-cause death.
option_C: For patients with obstructive CAD and stable chest pain, it is not recommended to optimize GDMT.
option_D: For patients with GCA or Takayasu arteritis in remission, it is appropriate to consider elective endovascular or open surgical procedures to address complications involving the aorta and its branches.

option_A: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is not recommended as a component of the screening algorithm.
option_B: In patients with HF who have fluid retention, diuretics are recommended to relieve conges- tion, improve symptoms, and prevent worsen- ing HF.1–5
option_C: In patients >65 years of age who require AVR, it is not reasonable to choose a bioprosthesis over a mechanical valve.
option_D: In patients suspected of having a stroke or TIA, CT or MRI of the brain is not recommended to confirm the diagnosis of symptomatic ischemic cerebral vascular disease.

option_A: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and known coronary stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle coronary segment on CCTA, FFR-CT can be useful for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia and to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.12,53-58
option_B: In patients with AF, the use of evidence-based decision aids should not be considered useful for guiding stroke reduction therapy treatment decisions, as it may not improve engagement, decisional quality, or patient satisfaction.
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in whom patent foramen ovale (PFO) closure would be contemplated, TCD (transcranial Doppler) with embolus detection might be reasonable to screen for right-to-left shunt.57,80
option_D: In patients with ALI and prolonged ischemia in whom revascularization (endovascular or surgical, including catheter-directed thrombolysis) is performed, concur- rent and early amputation can be beneficial to avoid the morbidity of reperfusion.

option_A: For patients with a slight decline in kidney function or an asymptomatic drop in blood pressure during heart failure hospitalization, diuretics and other guideline-directed medical therapies should generally be continued.
option_B: In patients with severe secondary MR (Stages C and D), mitral valve surgery is reasonable when CABG is undertaken for the treatment of myocardial ischemia.9–15
option_C: For patients following an ACS event, it is advised to perform a fasting lipid panel 4 to 8 weeks after starting or adjusting the dosage of lipid-lowering treatment to evaluate the therapy's effectiveness or patient compliance.
option_D: In patients with CCD and a previous history of MI without a history of stroke, transient ischemic attack (TIA), or ICH, vorapaxar should not be added to aspirin therapy to reduce MACE.

option_A: In patients with STEMI and ischemic symp- toms for <12 hours, PCI should be performed to improve survival.1-5
option_B: For asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe mitral regurgitation, normal left ventricular systolic function, and an estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure below 50 mm Hg, elective non-cardiac surgery is considered reasonable.
option_C: Women with mechanical heart valves and their healthcare providers should engage in shared decision-making to determine an anticoagulation plan for pregnancy. It is important for women to understand that using VKA during pregnancy presents the lowest risk of maternal complications but increases the risk of miscarriage, fetal death, and congenital abnormalities, especially when taken in the first trimester and if the warfarin dose is more than 5 mg per day.
option_D: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), noninvasive imaging (stress nuclear/PET, CMR, or stress echocardiography), coronary CT angiography, or coronary arteriography is not useful to establish etiology.

option_A: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, it is advised to receive treatment in a specialized inpatient unit, such as a stroke unit, with a multidisciplinary team to enhance outcomes and lower mortality rates.
option_B: In selected patients undergoing PCI, shorter- duration DAPT (1–3 months) is reasonable, with subsequent transition to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy to reduce the risk of bleeding events.1-4
option_C: In patients with stent failure, IVUS or OCT is reasonable to determine the mechanism of stent failure.14-17
option_D: In patients with bioprosthetic valve stenosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging should not be used to rule out leaflet thrombosis.

option_A: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is not recommended as part of the initial assessment.
option_B: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR related to LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%) who have persistent severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) while on optimal GDMT for HF (Stage D), mitral valve surgery should not be considered.
option_C: If improvement occurs within 1 to 2 minutes, if syncope does not occur, and if symptoms do not worsen or reoccur, the first aid provider should not activate emergency services.
option_D: For patients with obesity and atrial fibrillation, applying manual pressure or increasing the electrical energy may enhance the success rate of electrical cardioversion.

option_A: In patients with HCM and recurrent symptomatic sustained monomorphic VT, or recurrent ICD shocks despite optimal device programming, and in whom antiarrhythmic drug therapy is either ineffective, not tolerated, or not preferred, catheter ablation should not be considered for reducing arrhythmia burden.
option_B: For patients exhibiting signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure due to severe secondary tricuspid regurgitation (Stages C and D), addressing the underlying cause of heart failure—such as using pulmonary vasodilators to lower high pulmonary artery pressures, guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, or rhythm control for atrial fibrillation—can be beneficial.
option_C: In patients with potential spontaneous ICH, first responder training in stroke evaluation and care with the ability to provide airway and circulatory support when necessary is reason- able to detect and manage prehospital neuro- logical deterioration (ND).48,49
option_D: For patients with CCD, tailoring the recommencement of sexual activity according to the type of activity, exercise tolerance, and recovery after procedures is advisable.

option_A: For patients with obstructive HCM experiencing ongoing severe symptoms due to LVOTO despite treatment with beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, it is advised to either add disopyramide to one of these medications or undergo SRT at specialized centers.
option_B: We suggest using methylene blue to treat methemoglobinemia.
option_C: In patients with aSAH, phenytoin for seizure prevention and/or antiseizure prophylaxis is not associated with excess morbidity and mortality.
option_D: For patients experiencing aSAH with severe vasospasm, administering intra-arterial vasodilator therapy could be a reasonable approach to alleviate cerebral vasospasm and mitigate the progression and severity of DCI.

option_A: In patients undergoing NCS, maintaining an intraop­ erative mean arterial pressure (MAP) ≥60 to 65 mm Hg or SBP ≥90 mm Hg is recommended to reduce the risk of myocardial injury.3–9 Postoperative Blood Pressure Management
option_B: For patients with AF who have unclear symptoms related to the condition, attempting rhythm control, such as cardioversion or medication, can help identify whether any symptoms are due to AF.
option_C: In patients with stroke or TIA and hypertension who are not currently restricting their dietary sodium intake, it is not reasonable to recommend that individuals reduce their sodium intake by at least 1g/d sodium (2.5 g/d salt) to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) events (including stroke).
option_D: For patients with high-grade aSAH, considering invasive monitoring of brain tissue oxygen levels, lactate/pyruvate ratio, and glutamate can help predict DCI.

option_A: For individuals with CCD, it is advised that clinicians and the care team regularly evaluate SDOH to guide personalized treatment choices and lifestyle change suggestions.
option_B: In patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), it is not necessary to coordinate with the LVAD care team on the timing and perioperative considerations of elective NCS, as it does not impact the risk of perioperative MACE.
option_C: For patients with SLE who have no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and exhibit a low-risk antiphospholipid profile (such as isolated anticardiolipin or anti–β2-glycoprotein 1 antibodies at low to medium levels, especially if temporarily positive), considering daily aspirin (75–100 mg) as a preventive measure against stroke may be appropriate.
option_D: For patients with a BAV and a ratio of aortic root or ascending aortic area (cm²) to height (m) of ≥10 cm²/m, it is advisable to consider surgical replacement of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, when conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

option_A: We recommend hospitals avoid developing protocols for postarrest temperature control.
option_B: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, noninvasive imaging of the intracranial large arteries and imaging of the extracranial vertebrobasilar arterial system with MRA or CTA should not be used to identify atherosclerotic disease, dissection, moyamoya, or other etiologically relevant vasculopathies.
option_C: Patients with PAD should receive the severe acute respiratory syndrome-coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) vaccination sequence, including the booster(s).
option_D: In patients with GCA who have evidence of active aortitis, tocilizumab is not recommended as adjunctive therapy to glucocorticoids, and methotrexate should not be considered as an alternative.

option_A: In select patients with CCD treated with PCI and a drug-eluting stent (DES) who have completed a 1- to 3-month course of DAPT, P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy for at least 12 months is reasonable to reduce bleeding risk.8–12
option_B: For patients with atrial fibrillation on warfarin who have an annual thromboembolism risk of 5% or higher and are undergoing pacemaker or defibrillator implantation or generator replacement, it is advised to maintain anticoagulation with warfarin rather than interrupting it and using heparin bridging, to minimize the risk of pocket hematoma.
option_C: In patients with nonruptured AAA with low to moderate operative risk and who have anatomy suitable for either open or EVAR, a shared decision-making process weighing the risks and benefits of each approach is not recommended.
option_D: Training laypeople to handle opioid overdoses, including administering naloxone, is advisable.

option_A: For patients with diabetes who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, comprehensive care—including lifestyle guidance, nutritional therapy, diabetes self-management education, support, and medication—is recommended to attain glycemic targets and enhance stroke risk factors.
option_B: In adult patients with suspected HCM, cardiac CT should not be considered for diagnosis even if the echocardiogram is not diagnostic and CMR imaging is unavailable.
option_C: In patients treated with TEVAR, surveillance imaging with CT is not recommended after 1 month and 12 months, nor annually thereafter, even if stable.
option_D: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain who have known CAD and present with new onset or worsening symptoms, additional cardiac testing should be performed before optimizing GDMT.

option_A: In patients with recurrent endocarditis and continued intravenous drug use, it is not recommended to consult with addiction medicine to discuss the long-term prognosis for the patient’s refraining from actions that risk reinfection before repeat surgical intervention is considered.
option_B: Exercise TTE is not reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO in asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE.
option_C: It is reasonable for a person with a foreign body in the eye from a low-energy mechanism (eg, dust, dirt, other object blown into the eye by wind; eyelash in the eye) to attempt to remove the for- eign body by allowing natural tears to wash out the object or by irrigating the eye with tap water or a commercial eye wash solution.
option_D: Emergent coronary angiography is not reasonable for selected adult patients without ST-elevation on electrocardiogram, even if they have an elevated risk of significant coronary artery disease where revascularization may provide benefit, such as those with shock, electrical instability, signs of significant ongoing myocardial damage, or ongoing ischemia.

option_A: Topical lidocaine may effectively alleviate local pain from scorpion stings if the skin remains unbroken.
option_B: In all patients with known or suspected IE and nondiagnostic TTE results, when complications have developed or are clinically suspected or when intracardiac device leads are present, TEE is recommended.21,23–40
option_C: For patients with obstructive HCM who continue to experience severe symptoms despite following guideline-directed management and therapy, SRT is advised for eligible individuals* at specialized centers† to alleviate LVOTO17,50,213 (refer to Table 3 and Table 4).
option_D: In patients with cervical carotid artery FMD and recurrent ischemic stroke without other attributable causes despite optimal medical management, carotid angioplasty with or without stenting should not be considered to prevent ischemic stroke.

option_A: In asymptomatic women with severe valve disease (Stage C1) who are considering pregnancy, exercise testing is not reasonable before pregnancy for risk assessment.
option_B: For patients experiencing dyspnea, assessing B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal prohormone of B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) is beneficial for confirming or ruling out heart failure.
option_C: In patients with type 2 diabetes and either established CVD or at high cardiovascular risk, SGLT2i should not be used to prevent hospitalizations for HF.
option_D: Among patients with STEMI undergoing PPCI, manual aspiration thrombectomy should be performed routinely prior to PCI despite the lack of clinical benefit.

option_A: The routine use of intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) therapy for CCB poisoning is recommended.
option_B: For patients with a mechanical bileaflet or current-generation single-tilting disk AVR and no risk factors for thromboembolism, anticoagulation with a VKA to achieve an INR of 2.5 is not recommended.
option_C: For patients aged 50 to 65 needing AVR without contraindications to anticoagulation, it is appropriate to tailor the decision between mechanical and bioprosthetic AVR based on personal patient factors and through informed shared decision-making.
option_D: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is not recommended as part of the initial assessment.

option_A: Patients with HF should not receive care from multidisciplinary teams, as this would hinder the implementation of GDMT, ignore potential barriers to self-care, increase the risk of subsequent rehospitalization for HF, and decrease survival.
option_B: Amiodarone or lidocaine should not be considered for ventricular fibrillation/pulseless ventricular tachycardia that is unresponsive to defibrillation.
option_C: In pregnant women with HCM, it is reasonable to perform serial echocardiography, particularly during the second or third trimester when hemodynamic load is highest, or if clinical symptoms develop.
option_D: In patients with AF, it is not recommended to engage in SDM with the patient to discuss rhythm- versus rate-control strategies, therapeutic options, or to assess long-term benefits, regardless of clinical presentation, comorbidity burden, medication profile, or patient preferences.

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke who are very high risk (defined as stroke plus another major ASCVD or stroke plus multiple high-risk conditions), are taking maximally tolerated statin and ezetimibe therapy and still have an LDL-C >70 mg/dL, it is not reasonable to treat with PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9) inhibitor therapy to prevent ASCVD events.
option_B: We recommend that vasopressors not be administered for hypotension due to β-blocker poisoning.
option_C: In patients with a previous acute aortic dissection and IMH, whether initially treated medically or with intervention, who have chronic residual TAD and an aneurysm with a total aortic diameter of ≥5.5 cm, elective thoracic aortic repair is ­recommended.1-4
option_D: In patients undergoing elective CABG who receive P2Y12 receptor inhibitors before surgery, it is unreasonable to discontinue clopidogrel for 5 days, ticagrelor for 3 days, and prasugrel for 7 days before CABG, as this does not reduce the risk of major bleeding and blood product transfusion.

option_A: In adults with congenital heart disease and AF, it is recommended to evaluate for and treat precipitating factors and reversible causes of AF, recognizing that residual hemodynamic sequelae may contribute to the occurrence of the arrhythmia.1,2
option_B: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, Turner syndrome, BAV with aortic dilation, and other aortopathy conditions, who are contemplating pregnancy, counseling about the risks of aortic dissection related to pregnancy is not recommended.
option_C: For adult patients with HCM who are not classified as high risk for SCD, or when the decision to implant an ICD is still uncertain after evaluating personal/family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory ECG monitoring, CMR imaging is useful to evaluate maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and the degree of myocardial fibrosis using LGE.
option_D: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication and significant hemodynamic impairment of the common femoral artery who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, surgical endarterectomy is a reasonable option, particularly if endovascular methods negatively impact the profunda femoris artery pathways.

option_A: For adult patients with HCM with ≥1 major risk factors for SCD, it is reasonable to offer an ICD. These major risk factors in- clude38,81,87,99,146,149–157,159–161 (Figure 3, Table 7): a.  Sudden death judged definitively or likely attributable to HCM in ≥1 first-degree or close relatives who are ≤50 years of age; b.  Massive left ventricular hypertrophy ≥30 mm in any left ventricular segment; c.  ≥1 Recent episodes of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic (ie, unlikely to be of neurocardiogenic [vaso- vagal] etiology, or related to LVOTO); d.  LV apical aneurysm, independent of size; e.  LV systolic dysfunction (EF <50%).
option_B: For patients with aSAH, starting enteral nimodipine early is advantageous for preventing DCI and enhancing functional outcomes.
option_C: In patients with CCD, minimization of sodium (<2300 mg/d; optimally 1500 mg/d) and minimi- zation of processed meats (eg, cured bacon, hot dogs) can be beneficial to reduce the risk of CVD events.*2,3,6,7
option_D: In patients treated with open repair of the thoracic aorta who have residual aortopathy or abnormal findings on surveillance imaging, annual surveillance imaging is not necessary.

option_A: For patients with Turner syndrome who have risk factors for aortic dissection (refer to Table 12), it is advised to conduct surveillance aortic imaging at intervals based on the aortic diameter, ASI, and the rate of aortic growth (see Figure 18).
option_B: In patients with hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA, treatment with a thiazide diuretic, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, or angiotensin II receptor blockers is not useful for lowering BP and reducing recurrent stroke risk.
option_C: In patients undergoing open surgical repair of an ascending aortic aneurysm, if the aneurysmal disease extends into the proximal aortic arch, it is not reasonable to extend the repair with a hemiarch replacement.
option_D: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA with confirmed antiphospholipid syndrome treated with warfarin, it is unreasonable to choose a target INR between 2 and 3, and instead, a target INR >3 should be selected, disregarding the balance between the risk of excessive bleeding and the risk of thrombosis.

option_A: In patients with suspected mechanical or bioprosthetic valve stenosis, TTE and TEE are not recommended for diagnosing the cause and severity of valve obstruction, assessing ventricular function, or estimating pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
option_B: In patients with aSAH and severe vasospasm, avoid using intra-arterial vasodilator therapy as it may not be effective in reversing cerebral vasospasm or reducing the progression and severity of DCI.
option_C: In patients with an infected prosthetic aortic graft and either an extensive perigraft abscess or an infection caused by methicillin-resistant S. aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or a multidrug-resistant microorganism, or who have undergone in situ reconstruction, lifelong suppressive oral antimicrobial therapy should not be considered after the initial course of therapy.
option_D: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), noninvasive imaging (stress nuclear/ PET, CMR, or stress echocardiography), coronary CT angiography, or coronary arteriography is useful to establish etiology of

option_A: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are designated as high risk, ICA is not recommended.
option_B: For individuals with aSAH, advising them and their caregivers about the significant long-term risk of cognitive impairment can help in recognizing ongoing needs.
option_C: For patients under 65 years old who require mitral valve replacement, have no contraindications to anticoagulation, and cannot have mitral valve repair, opting for a mechanical mitral prosthesis instead of a bioprosthetic valve is advisable.
option_D: If patients experience ongoing or recurrent acute chest pain despite a negative stress test, anatomic cardiac evaluation, or a low-risk classification by a CDP, they should be assessed for noncardiac causes.

option_A: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, the use of PA catheterization should not be considered even when underlying medical conditions that significantly affect hemodynamics (e.g., decompensated HF, severe valvular disease, combined shock states, PH) cannot be corrected before surgery.
option_B: In patients with ALI with a threatened but salvageable limb (ie, category IIa or IIb), prophylactic fasciotomy is reasonable based on the clinical findings.1,2
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not recommended to treat hypoglycemia (<40–60 mg/dL, <2.2–3.3 mmol/L) to reduce mortality.
option_D: In patients with recurrent acute chest pain without evidence of a cardiac or pulmonary cause, evaluation for gastrointestinal causes is not reasonable.

option_A: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assessment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are not recommended at periodic intervals regardless of age or change in clinical status.
option_B: In patients with a mechanical mitral valve replacement who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while in therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is not reasonable to increase the INR goal from 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) to 4.0 (range, 3.5–4.0) or to add daily low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg), regardless of bleeding risk assessment.
option_C: In patients with mechanical valve stenosis, fluoroscopy or cine-CT is recommended to assess motion of the mechanical valve leaflets.
option_D: In patients with ACS undergoing coronary revascularization (CABG or PCI) in the same admission, parenteral anticoagulation should be discontinued before revascularization to increase ischemic events.

option_A: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF, the usefulness of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers in the treatment of symptoms (angina and dyspnea) is not well established.6
option_B: In patients with a BAV and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both of ≥4.0 cm, lifelong surveillance imaging of the aortic root and ascending aorta by TTE, CT, or MRI is recommended at an interval dependent on aortic diameter and rate of growth.4,5
option_C: In patients with ACS complicated by cardiogenic shock, routine PCI of a noninfarct-related artery at the time of PPCI should be performed despite the higher risk of death or renal failure.
option_D: For individuals experiencing ongoing stable chest pain with nonobstructive coronary artery disease, it is advisable to use stress CMR along with MBFR measurement to enhance the diagnosis of coronary myocardial dysfunction and assess the risk of major adverse cardiac events.

option_A: For patients with CCD who are habitual tobacco smokers, it is advised to use behavioral interventions alongside pharmacotherapy, such as bupropion, varenicline, or a combination of long- and short-acting nicotine replacement therapies, to optimize cessation success.
option_B: For patients with Marfan syndrome who have a nondissected aneurysm measuring 5.0 cm or larger in the aortic arch, descending thoracic aorta, or abdominal aorta, it is advisable to surgically replace the affected segment.
option_C: In patients with a history of stroke or a clinical indication for anticoagulation, or with a low-risk aPL profile, prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is not recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_D: Children in the preadolescent age group who are receiving active cooling with running water for thermal burns should be observed for any indications of hypothermia.

option_A: In patients with suspected ALI, the initial clinical evaluation should rapidly assess limb viability and potential for salvage and can be achieved without noninvasive imaging (ie, duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA).1–6
option_B: For patients with AAS, administer pain relief as necessary to assist in managing hemodynamics.
option_C: It is not reasonable to utilize extracorporeal life support techniques such as VA-ECMO for cardiogenic shock due to CCB poisoning that is refractory to pharmacological interventions.
option_D: For patients with heart failure and suspected sleep-disordered breathing, conducting a formal sleep evaluation is advisable to verify the diagnosis and distinguish between obstructive and central sleep apnea.

option_A: In patients with aSAH, avoid using validated screening tools in the postacute period to identify post-aSAH depression and anxiety.
option_B: In patients with asymptomatic PAD, single antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_C: For patients with HCM, participation in high-intensity recreational activities or moderate- to high-intensity competitive sports activities should be undertaken without the need for a comprehensive evaluation or annual discussion with an expert provider, disregarding the potential increased risk of sudden death and ICD shocks, and without involving third parties in eligibility decisions for competitive sports participation.
option_D: In patients with a surgical or transcatheter prosthetic valve and in patients who have had valve repair, an initial postprocedural TTE study is recommended for evaluation of valve hemodynamics and ventricular function.1–4

option_A: We recommend that hydroxocobalamin not be administered for cyanide poisoning.
option_B: In patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) with pulmonary vascular disease and AF or AFL, a rhythm-control strategy is not recommended as it does not improve functional status or prolong survival.
option_C: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with primary severe MR and high or prohibitive surgical risk, transcatheter edge-to- edge repair (TEER) is reasonable if mitral valve anatomy is favorable for the repair procedure and patient life expectancy is at least 1 year.17,18
option_D: In children with HCM and recurrent ventricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker use, antiarrhythmic drug therapy (e.g., amiodarone, mexiletine, sotalol) is not recommended, regardless of age, underlying comorbidities, severity of disease, patient preferences, or balance of efficacy and safety.

option_A: In patients undergoing PCI, avoid a loading dose of aspirin and daily dosing, as it is not recommended to reduce ischemic events.
option_B: For screening first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, it is advised to include a 12-lead ECG as part of the evaluation process.
option_C: For comatose patients who have been resuscitated following cardiac arrest, are electrically and hemodynamically stable, and show no signs of STEMI, immediate angiography is not advised as it offers no benefit.
option_D: For patients who have a mechanical mitral valve and a prior ischemic stroke or TIA before valve replacement, it is advised to use aspirin (75–100 mg daily) alongside warfarin, aiming for an INR of 3.0 (range 2.5–3.5), to lower the risk of thrombosis and recurrent stroke or TIA.

option_A: Unless otherwise recommended by local guide- lines, irrigation with a copious amount of tap water for 15 minutes should be performed.
option_B: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, do not review preoperative CTA of the iliofemoral vessels to evaluate access.
option_C: In patients with AAS, it is recommended to treat with long-term beta blockers (unless contraindicated) to control heart rate and BP to reduce late aortic-related adverse events.1-7 Additional antihypertensive agents (particu- larly ARBs and ACEIs) should be added, as necessary, to adequately control BP.
option_D: In highly selected patients with apical HCM with severe dyspnea or angina (NYHA class III or class IV) despite maximal medical therapy, and with preserved EF and small LV cavity size (LV end-diastolic volume <50 mL/m2 and LV stroke volume <30 mL/m2), apical myectomy by expe- rienced surgeons at comprehensive centers may be considered to reduce symptoms.248

option_A: In patients undergoing CABG, who do not have a contraindication to beta blockers, the administration of beta blockers before surgery can be beneficial to reduce the incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation.1-8
option_B: In patients who have undergone treatment of an acute prosthetic aortic graft infection, it is not recommended to provide targeted intravenous antimicrobial therapy for at least 6 weeks, nor to consider prolonged suppressive oral therapy in select cases, and consultation and follow-up with an infectious disease specialist should be avoided.
option_C: For patients who have experienced a recent TIA or ischemic stroke and have ipsilateral carotid stenosis of 50%–69% confirmed by catheter-based or noninvasive imaging, carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is advised to lower the risk of subsequent strokes, taking into account individual factors like age, sex, and existing health conditions, provided the estimated risk of perioperative complications and death is below 6%.
option_D: For patients experiencing an ischemic stroke or TIA who also have OSA, using positive airway pressure therapy, such as CPAP, may be advantageous for enhancing sleep apnea, blood pressure, sleepiness, and other outcomes related to apnea.

option_A: In patients with BTTAI, anti-impulse therapy to reduce the risk of injury extension and rupture should be implemented, except in patients with hypotension or hypovolemic shock.1,2 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_B: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD undergoing stress testing, the addition of CAC testing is not useful.
option_C: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA of unknown source despite thorough diagnostic evaluation and no other thrombotic history who are found to have prothrombin 20210A mutation, activated protein C resistance, elevated factor VIII levels, or deficiencies of protein C, protein S, or antithrombin III, anti- platelet therapy is reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.600–606
option_D: In patients with spontaneous ICH and condi- tions placing them at high risk of thromboem- bolic events, for example, a mechanical valve or LVAD, early resumption of anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic complications is reasonable.586,587

option_A: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and ipsilateral moderate (50%–69%) carotid stenosis as documented by catheter-based imaging or noninvasive imaging, CEA is not recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, regardless of patient-specific factors such as age, sex, and comorbidities, even if the perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.
option_B: In patients with aSAH, it is unreasonable to closely monitor and use goal-directed treatment of volume status to maintain euvolemia.
option_C: In patients with hypertension undergoing NCS, it is not recommended to restart preoperative antihypertensive medications as soon as clinically reasonable, as this could prevent complications from postoperative hypertension. Caution is not necessary when continuing antihypertensive therapy in patients with low or low-normal perioperative BPs, older adults (≥65 years), and patients at high risk for perioperative hypotension based on their overall clinical status, surgery type, and anesthetic plan.
option_D: For patients with PAD, diabetes management should be collaboratively overseen by the healthcare team.

option_A: For patients with AF receiving DOACs, optimal man- agement of drug interactions is recommended for those receiving concomitant therapy with interacting drugs, especially CYP3A4 and/or p-glycoprotein inhibitors or inducers (Table 13).1–7
option_B: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, management in an observation unit is reasonable to shorten length of stay and lower cost relative to an inpatient admission.1-7
option_C: For patients with heart failure, an endomyocardial biopsy can be beneficial if a particular diagnosis is suspected that could alter treatment.
option_D: It is not reasonable to administer calcium for CCB poisoning.

option_A: For patients with fibrotic or significantly calcified lesions, considering plaque modification through orbital atherectomy, balloon atherotomy, laser angioplasty, or intracoronary lithotripsy can enhance procedural success.
option_B: For patients with GCA showing signs of active aortitis, it is advised to use tocilizumab alongside glucocorticoids, with methotrexate as an alternative option.
option_C: In stable patients with NSTE-ACS with MVD but without left main stenosis who are not intended for CABG surgery and undergoing culprit-lesion PCI, PCI of significant nonculprit lesions (at the time of the index procedure or as a staged procedure) is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_D: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS initially evaluated in the office setting, delayed transfer to the ED for cTn or other diagnostic testing should be avoided.

option_A: For a hypothermic individual with reduced responsiveness wearing damp (but not soaked) clothing like polyester fleece, and if immediate relocation to a warm area is not possible, it is advisable to start active rewarming through the damp clothing using the hypothermia wrap method, which involves chemical heat blankets, plastic or foil layers, and insulating blankets.
option_B: In patients undergoing PCI, administration of intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) is not useful to reduce ischemic events.
option_C: For patients with HCM who experience a change in clinical status or a new clinical event, repeat TTE is not recommended.
option_D: For patients with aSAH from ruptured wide-neck aneurysms not amenable to surgical clipping or primary coiling, endovascular treatment with stent-assisted coiling or flow diverters is not recommended to reduce the risk of rebleed.

option_A: In asymptomatic patients with severe high-gradient AS (Stage C1) and a progressive decrease in LVEF on at least 3 serial imaging studies to <60%, AVR should not be considered.
option_B: In patients with diabetes who have multivessel CAD amenable to PCI and an indication for revascularization and are poor candidates for surgery, PCI should not be used to reduce long-term ischemic outcomes.
option_C: In patients with suspected ACS, acquisition and interpretation of an ECG within 10 minutes is recommended to help guide patient management.*1,2 Table 4.  Types of Acute Myocardial Infarction According to the Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction Type 1* Caused by acute coronary atherothrombosis, usually precipitated by atherosclerotic plaque disruption (rupture or erosion) and often associated with partial or complete vessel thrombosis. Type 2
option_D: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response, digoxin should not be considered for acute rate control, even if beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are ineffective or contraindicated.

option_A: For asymptomatic individuals with severe rheumatic mitral stenosis (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm², Stage C) who exhibit favorable valve morphology, have less than 2+ mitral regurgitation, no left atrial thrombus, and elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure (>50 mm Hg), percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy is a reasonable option if conducted at a Comprehensive Valve Center.
option_B: For patients with bioprosthetic valves or annuloplasty rings who are receiving a direct oral anticoagulant and who require immediate reversal of anticoagulation because of uncontrollable bleeding, treatment with idarucizumab (for dabigatran) or andexanet alfa (for anti-Xa agents) is not reasonable.
option_C: Fibrinolytic therapy should be avoided in patients presenting solely with ST-segment depression, unless a true posterior STEMI is suspected, due to the risk of hemorrhagic stroke and significant noncerebral bleeding.
option_D: We recommend that hydroxocobalamin be administered for cyanide poisoning.

option_A: For patients with a ruptured AAA, allowing lower blood pressure may help reduce bleeding rates.
option_B: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, ACEi should not be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortality.
option_C: In pregnant women with VHD, ACE inhibitors and ARBs should be given despite the fetal risk.
option_D: In stable patients with acute chest pain with high clinical suspicion for PE, CTA using a PE protocol is not recommended.

option_A: For patients with cardiovascular disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery, it is not advised to routinely use pulmonary artery catheterization to decrease morbidity or mortality.
option_B: In patients with potential stroke, including spontaneous ICH, in geographic regions where mobile stroke units (MSUs) operate, it is unreasonable to use such mobile units for more rapid diagnosis and treatment, and ambulance transfer to the closest stroke-capable facility should be preferred.
option_C: Ongoing clinical screening is indicated in genotype-negative relatives in families with genotype-positive HCM, even if the disease-causing variant is downgraded to a VUS, likely benign, or benign variant during follow-up.
option_D: In patients undergoing elective elevated-risk surgery who have cardiovascular risk factors for perioperative complications and a recent history of poorly controlled hypertension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure [DBP] ≥110 mm Hg before the day of surgery), proceeding with surgery without deferral is recommended, as it does not increase the risk of perioperative complications.

option_A: In patients after ACS, low-dose colchicine should not be considered to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_B: For patients with obstructive HCM in whom the anatomic mechanism of obstruction is inconclusive on echocardiography, CMR imaging is not indicated to inform the selection and planning of SRT.
option_C: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a formal dysphagia screening protocol should not be implemented before initiation of oral intake, as it does not reduce disability or the risk of pneumonia.
option_D: In patients with PAU of the aorta with rupture, urgent repair is recommended.1-3

option_A: In patients with compensated HF undergoing NCS, it is unreasonable to continue GDMT (excluding SGLT2i) in the perioperative period, even if not contraindicated, as it does not reduce the risk of worsening HF. Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should not be stopped before scheduled surgery, and ertugliflozin should be continued up to the day of surgery.
option_B: For patients with AF at elevated risk for stroke and CKD stage 4, treatment with warfarin or labeled doses of DOACs is reasonable to reduce the risk of stroke.4,5
option_C: For athletes with HCM, a comprehensive evaluation and shared discussion of potential risks of sports participation by an expert provider is recommended.295
option_D: In patients with an aortic arch aneurysm who have symptoms attributable to the aneurysm and are at low or intermediate operative risk, open surgical replacement is recommended.

option_A: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, graduated compression stockings of knee-high or thigh-high length alone are beneficial for VTE prophylaxis.
option_B: In patients with HF and type 2 diabetes, the use of SGLT2i is recommended for the man- agement of hyperglycemia and to reduce HF- related morbidity and mortality.14–17
option_C: In patients with CLTI, amputation is recommended without prior evaluation for revascularization options by a multispecialty care team.
option_D: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain who have known CAD and present with new onset or worsening symptoms, additional cardiac testing should be performed before optimizing GDMT.

option_A: If recurrent opioid toxicity develops, repeated small doses or an infusion of naloxone should not be used.
option_B: In individuals ≥18 years of age, periodic screening for SDOH (e.g., food insecurity, lack of transportation) is not beneficial to identify additional factors that contribute to stroke risk.
option_C: In patients with rheumatic MS in normal sinus rhythm with symptomatic resting or exertional sinus tachycardia, heart rate control should not be used to manage symptoms.
option_D: In patients with hypertension undergoing NCS, it is recommended that preoperative antihypertensive medications be restarted as soon as clinically rea­ sonable to avoid complications from postoperative hypertension. *Caution is advised when continuing antihypertensive therapy in patients with low or low-normal perioperative BPs, older adults (≥65 years),10 and patients in whom the risk for perioperative hypotension is high based on an evaluation of the patient’s overall clinical status, surgery type, and anesthetic plan. †Modified from the “2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA High Blood Pressure Guideline.”11 ‡One or more components of the RCRI: CAD, congestive heart failure, cere­ brovascular accident, baseline serum creatinine >2.0 mg/dL, or preoperative in­ sulin treatment.12

option_A: We recommend that epinephrine be administered for patients in cardiac arrest.
option_B: In patients with diabetes or other common vascular risk factors and no prior stroke, the use of aspirin to prevent a first stroke is well established.
option_C: EMS should not be activated for a person with hypoglycemia who is unable to swallow, has a seizure, or does not improve within 10 minutes of oral glucose administration.
option_D: The use of pralidoxime is not reasonable for organophosphate poisoning.

option_A: In all patients ≥65 years of age and in those <64 years with perceived frailty who are undergoing elevated-risk NCS, preoperative frailty assessment using a validated tool can be useful for evaluating perioperative risk and guiding management.1–5
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH and conditions placing them at high risk of thromboembolic events, such as a mechanical valve or LVAD, delaying the resumption of anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic complications is reasonable.
option_C: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF, it is not reasonable to add oral diuretics when exertional dyspnea persists despite the use of beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers.
option_D: In patients with HFrEF and NYHA class II to IV symptoms, an MRA (spironolactone or eplerenone) is not recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality, regardless of eGFR or serum potassium levels. Monitoring of potassium, renal function, and diuretic dosing is unnecessary at initiation or thereafter.

option_A: In patients with severe† PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, referral to or consultation with a special­ ized PH center that can support risk assessment, optimization, and postoperative management (with consideration of intensive care after NCS) is reason­ able to reduce perioperative cardiopulmonary compli­ cations.2
option_B: For patients who have experienced a recent TIA or ischemic stroke and have stenosis less than 50%, it is advised against performing revascularization with CEA or CAS to lower the risk of subsequent strokes.
option_C: For patients with cardiovascular disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery, it is advisable to maintain normal body temperature to prevent perioperative complications.
option_D: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, stress PET/SPECT MPI, CMR imaging, or stress echocardiography is not recommended to detect the presence and extent of myocardial ischemia, estimate risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), or guide therapeutic decision-making.

option_A: We recommend selecting and maintaining a constant temperature between 32° C and 37.5° C during postarrest temperature control.
option_B: In patients with precapillary PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, perioperative administration of short-acting inhaled pulmonary vasodilators (eg, nitric oxide, aero­ solized prostacyclins) may be reasonable to reduce elevated RV afterload and prevent acute decompen­ sated right HF.6 *For example, nitric oxide pathway mediators, endothelin receptor antagonists, prostacyclin pathway agonists, or a combination of these. †Severe PH is defined according to hemodynamics (severe precapillary PH component by right heart catheterization and echocardiography) and additional data derived from clinical assessment, exercise tests, and laboratory biomarkers. Hemodynamically, severe PH displays a mean pulmonary artery (PA) pressure >40 mm Hg, pulmonary vascular resistance >5 Wood units, or echocardiographic evidence of significant RV dysfunction (eg, RV-to-LV diastolic diameter ratio >0.8 or RV dysfunction that is graded as moderate or severe). Although all 5 World Symposium on Pulmonary Hypertension group classifications display some de­ gree of risk for developing severe PH, Group 1 (PAH), Group 3 (PH due to lung disease), and Group 4 (chronic thromboembolic PH) are at high risk for devel­ oping severe PH if left untreated and may be best managed and followed at a center with PH specialists.
option_C: The utility of indirect manual pressure (ie, pressure points) for bleeding control is certain.
option_D: For patients with ALI and extended ischemia undergoing revascularization (whether endovascular, surgical, or catheter-directed thrombolysis), early and simultaneous amputation may help prevent the complications associated with reperfusion.

option_A: It is unreasonable for a person experiencing epistaxis who is taking anticoagulant or antiplatelet medication, or who has a blood-clotting disorder, to seek care from a health care professional, even if bleeding has not stopped.
option_B: In patients with AF, the use of evidence-based decision aids should not be considered useful for guiding stroke reduction therapy treatment decisions, as it may not improve engagement, decisional quality, or patient satisfaction.
option_C: Verapamil may be detrimental for individuals with obstructive HCM experiencing severe resting dyspnea, hypotension, extremely high resting gradients (e.g., >100 mm Hg), and for all children under 6 weeks old. Symptoms may include effort-related dyspnea, chest pain, or other exertional symptoms such as syncope or near syncope.
option_D: In patients with Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, or vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and intact TAAA requiring intervention, endovascular repair is recommended over open repair.

option_A: In cardiac arrest following drowning, it may be reasonable for trained rescuers to initiate CPR with rescue breaths followed by chest compressions. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
option_B: In patients with known CVD being considered for NCS, a validated risk-prediction tool should not be used to estimate the risk of perioperative MACE.
option_C: In patients with HCM, ignoring the guidelines on the prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is recommended, as it does not reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
option_D: In patients with bradycardia requiring cardiac-implanted electronic devices who have normal atrioventricular conduction, device selection and programming strategies should not focus on maintaining atrioventricular synchrony or minimizing ventricular pacing, as this is not necessary to reduce the incidence and progression of AF.

option_A: In adults, screening for physical activity is not recommended as part of a comprehensive effort to estimate stroke risk.
option_B: For patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, avoid using aspirin 50 to 325 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg, or the combination of aspirin 25 mg and extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg twice daily for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke.
option_C: The usefulness of a glucagon bolus and infusion for
option_D: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery with CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk, surgical LAA exclusion without continued anticoagulation is beneficial in reducing the risk of stroke and systemic embolism.

option_A: Do not consider storing an avulsed permanent tooth in cow’s milk or saliva if it cannot be immediately replanted and the aforementioned solutions or interventions are not available.
option_B: In patients with ACS who require oral anticoagulant therapy, aspirin should be discontinued after 1 to 4 weeks of triple antithrombotic therapy, with continued use of a P2Y12 inhibitor (preferably clopidogrel) and an oral anticoagulant to reduce bleeding risk.*1–5 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”6
option_C: For patients requiring diuretic treatment during hospitalization for HF, the discharge regimen should include a plan for adjustment of diuret- ics to decrease rehospitalizations.7
option_D: In patients with HCM and systolic dys- function, diagnostic testing to assess for concomitant causes of systolic dysfunc- tion (such as coronary artery disease) is recommended.22,36,285

option_A: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers are well established for treating symptoms (angina and dyspnea).
option_B: In patients scheduled for NCS, SGLT2i should be continued up to the day of surgery to maintain the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.
option_C: For patients with BAV, CMR or CT angiography is recommended when echocardiography does not provide a complete or precise evaluation of the aortic sinuses, sinotubular junction, or ascending aorta.
option_D: In adults with CCD who have hypertension, a BP target of ≥130/≥80 mm Hg is recommended to reduce CVD events and all-cause death.

option_A: Women with CCD who are contemplating preg- nancy or who are pregnant should be risk-stratified and counseled regarding risks of adverse maternal, obstetric, and fetal outcomes.1–4
option_B: In patients with chronic HF, measurements of BNP or NT-proBNP levels are recommended for risk stratification.11,13–29
option_C: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe AS and normal LV systolic function as assessed by echocardiography within the past year, it is reason­ able to proceed with elective low-risk NCS.3–5 *Modified from the “2020 ACC/AHA Guideline for the Management of Pa­ tients With Valvular Heart Disease.”6
option_D: In patients with stroke or TIA and LV thrombus, it is not recommended to use anticoagulation with therapeutic warfarin for at least 3 months to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

option_A: For patients with a ruptured TAAA who are hemodynamically stable, endovascular repair can be considered in facilities that have the necessary endovascular expertise and suitable stent grafts.
option_B: In patients with a BAV, a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of 5.0 cm to 5.4 cm, no other risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 14), and at low surgical risk, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both may be reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,2,5
option_C: In patients experiencing an acute type A aortic dissection during the third trimester of pregnancy, delaying cesarean delivery and aortic surgery is recommended.
option_D: In families where a sudden unexplained death has occurred with a postmortem diagnosis of HCM, postmortem genetic testing is benefi- cial to facilitate cascade genetic testing and clinical screening in first-degree relatives.133,134

option_A: In pregnant women with severe valve regurgitation and with NYHA class IV HF symptoms (Stage D) refractory to medical therapy, valve surgery is not reasonable during pregnancy.
option_B: In patients with an infected prosthetic aortic graft who are hemodynamically unstable, it is reasonable to perform open surgery with either explant or in situ ­reconstruction.7
option_C: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain who have known CAD and present with new onset or worsening symptoms, additional cardiac testing should be performed before optimizing GDMT.
option_D: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite GDMT), CPET should not be performed to quantify the degree of functional limitation or aid in selection of patients for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.

option_A: Patients with HF admitted with evidence of significant fluid overload should be promptly treated with intravenous loop diuretics to improve symptoms and reduce morbidity.1
option_B: In patients with HF, vaccinating against respi- ratory illnesses is reasonable to reduce mor- tality.10–16
option_C: In patients at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT, who have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is not recommended for primary prevention of SCD to reduce total mortality.
option_D: For patients undergoing major abdominal surgery, the use of epidural analgesia for postoperative pain relief is reasonable to decrease the incidence of perioperative cardiac events.1,2

option_A: In patients with HFpEF, SGLT2i should not be used as they do not decrease HF hospitalizations and cardiovascular mortality.
option_B: For patients who undergo successful transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI), it is reasonable to perform NCS early* as clinically indicated.1–3
option_C: In patients undergoing PCI, DES should be used in preference to BMS to prevent reste- nosis, MI, or acute stent thrombosis.1-4
option_D: For patients with OHCA, use of steroids during CPR is of uncertain benefit.

option_A: It may be unreasonable to cool thermal burns for 5 to 20 minutes.
option_B: In patients with prior CABG surgery presenting with acute chest pain who do not have ACS, performing stress imaging is effective to evaluate for myocardial ischemia or CCTA for graft stenosis or occlusion.1-7
option_C: In patients with signs or symptoms of AS or a BAV, TTE is not indicated for accurate diagnosis of the cause of AS, assessment of hemodynamic severity, measurement of LV size and systolic function, or determination of prognosis and timing of valve intervention.
option_D: In adults >18 years of age, screening for overweight and obesity is not recommended to inform the risk of stroke.

option_A: Patients at increased risk of AF should receive com- prehensive guideline-directed LRFM for AF, targeting obesity,1 physical inactivity,2 unhealthy alcohol con- sumption,3 smoking,4 diabetes,5 and hypertension.6
option_B: In patients with HCM in whom SRT is indicated, the procedure should be performed at experienced centers (comprehensive or primary HCM centers) with demonstrated excellence in clinical outcomes for these procedures (Tables 4 and 5).1–3
option_C: In patients with HFrEF, nondihydropyridine calcium channel-blocking drugs are recommended.
option_D: In patients with SIHD, normal left ventricular ejection fraction, and 1- or 2-vessel CAD not involving the proximal LAD, coronary revas- cularization is not recommended to improve survival.10,14,16,26,28,29

option_A: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and mechanical heart valves, treatment with dabigatran is beneficial.
option_B: Do not cover a burn with intact skin or an intact blister with a clean cloth or nonadherent dry dressing while awaiting evaluation by a health care professional.
option_C: For patients with HCM undergoing transvenous ICD implantation, it is advised to use single-coil ICD leads over dual-coil leads, provided the defibrillation threshold is considered sufficient.
option_D: In patients with AF on warfarin anticoagulation and an annual predicted risk of thromboembolism of ≥5% undergoing pacemaker or defibrillator implantation or generator change, interrupting warfarin and using bridging anticoagulation with heparin is recommended instead of continuing anticoagulation to reduce the risk of pocket hematoma.

option_A: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA, it is advised to track adherence to nationally recognized, evidence-based performance standards to identify and rectify disparities.
option_B: For patients with AF exhibiting rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF) who are hemodynamically stable, intravenous ibutilide or procainamide is advised for pharmacological cardioversion as an alternative to elective cardioversion.
option_C: In adults with Marfan syndrome, after the initial TTE, it is unreasonable to perform a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta to confirm the aortic diameters and assess the remainder of the thoracic aorta.
option_D: In patients with ACS and LVEF ≤40%, and with HF symptoms and/or diabetes mellitus, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.7

option_A: In patients on therapeutic subcutaneous enoxaparin, in whom the last dose was admin- istered within 12 hours of PCI, UFH should not be used for PCI and may increase bleed- ing.14,18,19
option_B: It is not reasonable to use extracorporeal life support, such as VA-ECMO, to treat refractory cardiogenic shock from sodium channel blocker poisoning.
option_C: Patients with severe AS should not be evaluated for the need for aortic valve intervention before elective NCS, as it does not reduce perioperative risk.
option_D: In patients with known or suspected IE and nondiagnostic TTE results, when complications have developed or are clinically suspected or when intracardiac device leads are present, TEE is not recommended.

option_A: It is advised to utilize a stroke recognition tool like the FAST or Cincinnati Prehospital Stroke Scale to help identify acute stroke in adults.
option_B: It is reasonable to use extracorporeal life sup- port, such as VA-ECMO, to treat refractory cardiogenic shock from sodium channel blocker poisoning.
option_C: For patients with CCD assessed as very high risk (refer to Table 10) and receiving the highest tolerable dose of statins with an LDL-C level of 70 mg/dL (1.8 mmol/L) or higher, adding ezetimibe may help further decrease the risk of MACE.*14–19 Cost Value Statement: High Value B-NR
option_D: Patients with suspected or confirmed IE associated with drug use should not be referred to addiction treatment for opioid substitution therapy.

option_A: In patients with an infected prosthetic aortic graft who are hemodynamically unstable, it is unreasonable to perform open surgery with either explant or in situ reconstruction.
option_B: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, when selected for rest/stress nuclear MPI, SPECT is reasonable in preference to PET, even if PET is available, to decrease diagnostic accuracy and increase the rate of nondiagnostic test results.
option_C: Pentoxifylline is not advised for treating claudication in patients with chronic symptomatic PAD.
option_D: In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) and prior ischemic stroke or TIA, chronic blood transfusion(s) to reduce hemoglobin S to <30% of total hemoglobin is not recommended for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.

option_A: In patients with DES-PCI placed for CCD who require elective NCS with interruption of ≥1 antiplatelet agents, it is reasonable to proceed with surgery within 6 months after PCI, disregarding the risk of perioperative MACE.
option_B: In patients with Marfan syndrome who have undergone aortic root replacement, surveillance imaging of the thoracic aorta by MRI (or CT) is not recommended to evaluate for distal TAD, regardless of the time interval or changes in diameter.
option_C: For patients exhibiting signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure and severe isolated secondary tricuspid regurgitation due to annular dilation, without pulmonary hypertension or left-sided disease, and who do not respond well to medical treatment (Stage D), isolated tricuspid valve surgery may help alleviate symptoms and decrease the frequency of hospital readmissions.
option_D: Patients who have been resuscitated after cardiac arrest and are noncomatose or who are comatose with favorable prognostic features and with evidence of STEMI, should not undergo PPCI to improve survival.

option_A: In most patients with hypertension planned for elective NCS, it is not reasonable to continue medical therapy for hypertension throughout the perioperative period.
option_B: In patients with ACS and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, emergency revascularization of the culprit vessel by PCI or CABG is not indicated to improve survival, irrespective of time from symptom onset.
option_C: In women with acute HF caused by peripartum cardiomyopathy and LVEF <30%, anticoagulation should not be considered at diagnosis, until 6 to 8 weeks postpartum, as the efficacy and safety are uncertain.
option_D: For certain patients with CCD and notable left main stenosis, where PCI can achieve revascularization comparable to CABG, opting for PCI is a reasonable approach to enhance survival.

option_A: In patients in whom high-intensity statin therapy is contraindicated or not tolerated, moderate-intensity statin therapy is not recommended, as achieving a 30% to 49% reduction in LDL-C levels is not necessary to reduce the risk of MACE.
option_B: In patients with spontaneous ICH and unexplained abnormal or fluctuating mental status or suspicion of seizures, continuous electroencephalography (≥24 hours) is not reasonable to diagnose electrographic seizures and epileptiform discharges.
option_C: For patients with HF, palliative and supportive care—including communication, prognosis discussion, goal clarification, shared decision-making, symptom management, and caregiver support—should not be provided, as it does not improve QOL or relieve suffering.
option_D: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, it may be beneficial to enhance functional recovery through lifestyle changes, such as guided exercise and counseling, along with education for both patients and caregivers.

option_A: To enhance patient outcomes, cardiac surgery and PCI programs should consider implementing a quality improvement initiative that regularly 1) evaluates institutional quality programs and outcomes, 2) assesses individual operator results, 3) conducts peer reviews of challenging or complex cases, and 4) carries out random case evaluations.
option_B: In patients with known CVD, symptoms of CVD, or age ≥65 years with cardiovascular risk factors undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it is not reasonable to measure cTn at 24 and 48 hours after surgery to identify myocardial injury.
option_C: The preferred method for warming frostbitten tissue is to avoid clean lukewarm water immersion at 37° C to 40° C (99° F–104° F).
option_D: In asymptomatic patients with any type of valve intervention, it is not recommended to perform a baseline postprocedural TTE or to conduct periodic monitoring with TTE, regardless of the type of intervention, length of time after intervention, ventricular function, or concurrent cardiac conditions.

option_A: In older adults, the treatment strategy for CAD should not consider an individual patient’s preferences, cognitive function, or life expectancy.
option_B: For patients with atrial fibrillation and spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage who cannot receive anticoagulation, left atrial appendage closure can be an option to lower the risk of thromboembolic events.
option_C: The use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants with mechanical heart valves in pregnancy has not been assessed and is not recommended.30–32
option_D: For patients with severe† PH facing high-risk NCS, it is advisable to refer them to or consult with a specialized PH center capable of providing risk evaluation, optimization, and postoperative care (including potential intensive care post-NCS) to minimize perioperative cardiopulmonary complications.

option_A: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, delaying the initiation of low-dose UFH or LMWH prophylaxis beyond 48 hours from ICH onset may be reasonable, as it does not optimize the benefits of preventing thrombosis relative to the risk of HE.
option_B: For patients with HF—particularly stage D HF patients being evaluated for advanced therapies, patients requiring inotropic support or temporary mechanical support, patients experiencing uncontrolled symptoms, major medical decisions, or multimorbidity, frailty, and cognitive impairment—specialist palliative care consultation is not useful for improving QOL or relieving suffering.
option_C: In patients with an aortic arch aneurysm who are asymptomatic but meet criteria for intervention, and have a high risk from open surgical repair, a hybrid or endovascular approach should not be considered.
option_D: For patients at intermediate risk who experience acute chest pain without a history of CAD and have an inconclusive CCTA, stress imaging using echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI, or CMR may aid in diagnosing myocardial ischemia.

option_A: In patients with SIHD, normal ejection fraction, significant stenosis in 3 major coronary arteries (with or without proximal LAD), and anatomy suitable for CABG, CABG should not be considered to improve survival.
option_B: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are initially stabilized and are at intermediate or low risk of clinical events, an invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization should not be performed before hospital discharge as it does not improve outcomes.
option_C: If pediatric stroke is suspected, EMS should be activated, and the person should be transported to an ED.
option_D: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA after an extracranial carotid or vertebral arterial dissection, treatment with antithrombotic therapy for at least 3 months is not indicated to prevent recurrent stroke or TIA.

option_A: In patients with advanced (stage D) HF refrac- tory to GDMT and device therapy who are eligible for and awaiting MCS or cardiac trans- plantation, continuous intravenous inotropic support is reasonable as “bridge therapy.”1–4
option_B: In patients with class II obesity (35–39.9 kg/m2) or greater, bariatric surgical procedures to promote weight loss should not be considered to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_C: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, the aortic root diameter should not be recorded as maximum sinus to sinus measurement. In the setting of known asymmetry, only a single measurement should be reported, and obtaining both short- and long-axis images of the root is unnecessary.
option_D: For patients with obstructive HCM in whom the anatomic mechanism of obstruction is inconclusive on echocardiography, CMR imaging is not indicated to inform the selection and planning of SRT.

option_A: For asymptomatic patients undergoing elevated-risk surgeries without known CVD, a preoperative resting 12-lead ECG should not be considered to establish a baseline and guide perioperative management.
option_B: In patients undergoing open repair of TAAA involving the renal arteries, cold blood or crystalloid renal perfusion is not recommended for providing effective protection against renal injury.
option_C: In pregnant individuals with AF and without structural heart disease, antiarrhythmic agents with no history of safe use in pregnancy (eg, amiodarone and dronedarone) are reasonable for maintenance of sinus rhythm.
option_D: For children suspected of having hypoglycemia who are conscious but refuse or cannot swallow glucose, it might be appropriate to place a mixture of granulated sugar and water beneath the tongue.

option_A: It is not beneficial to administer oxygen over room air in the first aid setting for adults experiencing acute stroke.
option_B: In patients with ACS and LVEF ≤40%, and with HF symptoms and/or diabetes mellitus, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.7
option_C: In patients with PAD, it is not recommended to coordinate care among clinicians, as this does not improve the management of PAD and comorbid conditions or optimize patient outcomes.
option_D: Patients experiencing acute chest pain with a 30-day mortality or major adverse cardiac event risk of less than 1% should be classified as low risk.

option_A: In patients with IVH or infratentorial ICH loca- tion, transfer to centers with neurosurgical capabilities might be reasonable to improve outcomes.102,233,234
option_B: For patients with AF, HFrEF (LVEF <50%), and persistent rapid ventricular response who are unsuitable for rhythm control or have not benefited from it, AVNA combined with biventricular pacing therapy may be beneficial for enhancing symptoms, quality of life, and ejection fraction.
option_C: In patients with BTAI who have not undergone repair, surveillance imaging with a CT at 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months after the diagnosis and, if stable, at appropriate inter- vals thereafter (depending on the type and extent of the injury), may be ­reasonable.5
option_D: In patients with premature ovarian failure (menopause before 40 years of age) or early menopause (before 45 years of age), evaluation and modification of vascular risk factors are not recommended, as they do not reduce the elevated stroke risk in this population.

option_A: For patients with NSTE-ACS experiencing cardiogenic shock, performing routine multivessel PCI on non-culprit lesions during the same procedure is not advised.
option_B: Contaminated clothing, jewelry, and other surrounding material should remain in place during a chemical exposure.
option_C: For patients with HCM opting for genetic testing, it is advised that they receive genetic counseling from a cardiovascular genetics specialist both before and after the test, to ensure that the risks, benefits, results, and their clinical implications are thoroughly reviewed and discussed with the patient in a collaborative decision-making process.
option_D: A person experiencing epistaxis that does not stop after 15 minutes of continuous manual pressure or who becomes lightheaded from epistaxis should seek medical attention.

option_A: For patients with chronic HF and permanent- persistent-paroxysmal AF, chronic anticoagulant therapy is reasonable for men and women with- out additional risk factors.23–26
option_B: In patients with a BAV and either HTAD or phenotypic features concerning for Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a medical genetics evaluation is not recommended.
option_C: In patients with CCD who have angina or an anginal equivalent, no previous evaluation for ischemia, and angiographically intermediate stenoses, the use of FFR or other proven nonhyperemic pressure ratios (eg, iFR) is recommended before proceeding with PCI.*2,22,23 Cost Value Statement: High Value B-NR
option_D: For ambulatory patients with heart failure, it is reasonable to evaluate functional capacity using a CPET or a 6-minute walk test.

option_A: In transgender women and gender-diverse individuals taking estrogens for gender affirmation, evaluation and modification of risk factors are not beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.
option_B: For patients with a device-detected atrial high-rate episode (AHRE) lasting <24 hours and with a CHA2DS2-VASc score <2 or equivalent stroke risk, it is unreasonable to initiate oral anticoagulation within a SDM framework that considers episode duration and individual patient risk.
option_C: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a baseline MRI or CT from head to pelvis is not recommended to evaluate the entire aorta and its branches for aneurysm, dissection, and tortuosity.
option_D: Eye irrigation with normal saline, Ringer’s lactate solution, or a commercial eye wash solution if immediately available is reasonable.

option_A: For patients undergoing CABG, administering continuous intravenous insulin to maintain early postoperative blood glucose levels below 180 mg/dL, while preventing hypoglycemia, is recommended to decrease the risk of adverse events, such as deep sternal wound infections.
option_B: For patients who undergo MV TEER, it is not reasonable to perform NCS after the successful MV intervention, regardless of clinical indication. Evidence does not support the safety of NCS within 30 days of TAVI, even if indicated.
option_C: For patients with AFL who achieve sinus rhythm restoration through successful cardioversion or ablation, anticoagulation therapy should be maintained for a minimum of 4 weeks following the procedure.
