option_D: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, moderate-severe ischemia on current or prior (≤1 year) stress testing, and no known CAD established by prior anatomic testing,

option_A: In patients with AF, specialized atrial pacing algorithms designed to suppress AF are useful for reducing the incidence or slowing the progression of AF.
option_B: For patients with HCM who are candidates for ICD implantation and experience paroxysmal atrial tachycardias or AF, considering dual-chamber ICDs might be appropriate; however, this choice should be weighed against the increased complication rates associated with dual-chamber devices.
option_C: If stroke is suspected, the EMS system should not be activated immediately.
option_D: In patients with SIHD and significant left main stenosis, CABG is not recommended to improve survival.

option_A: For patients having CABG, regularly employing epiaortic ultrasound scanning can help assess the presence, location, and severity of plaque in the ascending aorta, thereby decreasing the risk of atheroembolic complications.
option_B: When performing genetic testing in an HCM proband, the initial tier of genes tested should include genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.*119,122,127,128 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
option_C: For patients with angina who lack anatomical or physiological indications for revascularization, both CABG and PCI are not recommended.
option_D: If a person experiences anaphylaxis and an epinephrine autoinjector is available, the person should not self-administer the autoinjector.

option_A: A first aid provider who encounters a person with suspected opioid overdose who is unresponsive and not breathing or not breathing normally should activate the emergency response system, provide high-quality CPR (compressions plus ventilation), and administer naloxone. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
option_B: A 12-lead ECG should be conducted at the first visit for any patient with heart failure to enhance treatment.
option_C: In patients with aSAH, effective glycemic control, strict hyperglycemia management, and avoidance of hypoglycemia are rea- sonable to improve outcome.141,142,194,195
option_D: In patients with preoperative OAC interruption, resumption of OAC is not reasonable after hemostasis is achieved. Timing of preoperative interruption should not consider patient-specific factors, surgical bleeding risk, or drug factors.

option_A: For patients with CCD, administering a pneumococcal vaccine is advisable to decrease cardiovascular morbidity, mortality, and overall mortality.
option_B: In apparently asymptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage C1) and low surgical risk, AVR is not reasonable when an exercise test demonstrates decreased exercise tolerance (normalized for age and sex) or a fall in systolic blood pressure of ≥10 mm Hg from baseline to peak exercise.
option_C: Patients with AF should be evaluated for their annual risk of thromboembolic events using a validated clinical risk score, such as CHA2DS2-VASc.1–4
option_D: For patients with nonobstructive HCM experiencing advanced heart failure (NYHA class III to IV) who remain symptomatic despite GDMT and are eligible for heart transplantation, using continuous-flow LVAD therapy as a bridge to transplantation is a reasonable option.

option_A: For patients experiencing cryptogenic stroke, it is appropriate to conduct tests for inherited or acquired hypercoagulable conditions, bloodstream or cerebrospinal fluid infections, infections that may lead to CNS vasculitis (such as HIV and syphilis), drug use (including cocaine and amphetamines), systemic inflammation markers, and genetic tests for hereditary diseases linked to stroke, as clinically warranted to identify potential contributors or risk factors.
option_B: In patients with ischemic stroke related to small vessel disease, cilostazol is definitely useful for secondary stroke prevention.
option_C: When a permanent tooth is avulsed, the person should delay seeking dental or medical care and should not bring the tooth if it has not been successfully replanted.
option_D: In patients with PAD who have undergone lower extremity revascularization, it is not recommended to conduct longitudinal follow-up that includes periodic clinical evaluation of lower extremity symptoms and pulse and foot assessment.

option_A: In patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing, it is not recommended to reevaluate the clinical significance of the variant(s) identified, as this will not impact diagnosis or cascade genetic testing in family members.
option_B: In patients with HCM in whom a decision has been made for ICD implantation and who have paroxysmal atrial tachycardias or AF, dual-chamber ICDs may be reasonable, but this decision must be balanced against higher complication rates of dual-chamber devices.19–24
option_C: In patients at increased risk of PAD (Table 5), a comprehensive medical history and review of symptoms to assess for exertional leg symptoms, lower extremity rest pain, and lower extremity wounds or other ischemic skin changes should be performed.1–4
